Posts.Content: PSA on the rise during last 14-years but I have easily ignored the issue until May 23 when my GP/Internist told me last PSA analysis was 9.2 Now my urologist tells me to wait another couple weeks for another PSA test and then another week before I can see him again. And then most likely a 3T MP MRI and still more waiting. Then I read about all the men with elevated or ever increasing PSA scores and negative biopsies who just have to "wait and see" I am not a "waiter", I am a numbers guy and a veteran of many invasive and high tech medical procedures, which clearly and quickly gave a well defined diagnosis and prognosis: - Knee x-rays and MRI confirm there is no cushion and it is 100% certain I need two new knees (after seven prior knee surgeries) - Radionuclide X-Ray study of heart after stress EKG provided 100% assurance I have great blood flow in heart after several A-fib events - Ultrasound with contrast proves 100% my heart is pumping efficiently after several tachycardia events - 21-day Holder EKG study demonstrated excellent heart rhythms after many potential AFib and tachycardia events with 100% assurance from cardiologist that my heart will not fail me - CT with contrast absolutely found no mass in upper GI tract after extreme rectal bleeding - Colonoscopy showed 100% I had suffered ischemic colitis and there was 0% chance of malignant growth in lower intestine - Endoscopy showed 100% that I had no mass or malignant growth in esophagus after strange swallowing events ... I could go on and on with more tests/images/exams but I've learned during the last 30-years that modern medicine can provide a pretty clear and certain diagnosis about a LOT of medical issues I've been conditioned to expect medical certainty but now, starting down the bumpy, winding, and uncertain elevated PSA path, I find I can only hope for 50% sensitivity and 80% specificity and lots of conflicting advice and information. And, my graduate and professional education and experience taught me that "more numbers / better analysis" would lead to clear statements, explanations, and plans. How do I now teach myself to not wake up in the middle of the night wondering and pondering "what if?" and to not wander off during the day into a mental fog of "what if?" How do I live with what appears to be a future of uncertainty and ambiguity regarding prostate health and prognosis?
Posts.Signature: DOB: July 1947 PSA: 2.0/2004 4.0/2010 5.8/2010 4.5/2012 5.6/2013 ALL Normal DRE 5/18 PSA: 9.2 6/18 PSA: 10.2 & 8.4% Free DRE small soft prostate w/no abnormalities 6/28 3T mpMRI PIRADS 3 18 cc gland=PSD 0.57 ng/cc 0.32 cc lesion in apical PZ with subtle T2 signal hypointensity mild restricted diffusion of contrast into lesion prostate unremarkable intact capsule 7/18 4KScore 34% Probability Gleason =>7 8/03/18 Bx: Adenocarcinoma 6 of 13 cores ONLY L lobe T1c / Grade II / unfavorable intermediate extent of G3-G4 tissue far greater than indicated by MRI G6 (3+3) 70% LL Base 50% L Lateral Mid 20% L Base G7 (3 +4) 100% LL Apex 20% L Mid 60% L Apex 8/15/18 Clear CT scan and Bone Scan RALP 8/23/18 pT3a, G7 (3+4), 20% involvement, SM+ (Focal 2mm G6), EPE(Focal G6)+, PNI+, LNI-, SVI-, LVI- 7g Tumor 20x size in MRI & biopsy report & in BOTH lobes not just L as biopsy reported PSA Post Surgery 10/3/18 0.021 01/4/19 0.018 04/03/19 0.022

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: Try to remain a little bit optimistic. My surgeon flat out said "looks like you will have radiation in your winter schedule" when he saw me 6-days post RALP due to my SM+ EPE+ and relatively high PSA density prior to surgery. But, he wanted to wait till my first µPSA test at six-weeks post RALP. That 6-week test came back 0.021 for me so he again said "your surgical pathology was not great but we can hope your PSA stays down" and told me to wait another 3-months for a 2nd µPSA, which came back 0.018. At this point I am seeing my medical oncologist who reviewed the surgeons notes and my post-RALP PSA and told me that "even with SM+ and EPE+ there is no reason to rush into SRT decision making. From now on you will be on a 3-month PSA schedule and we won't decide anything until you've got two tests above 0.10 ng/ml. Once you get one 0.1 we will start looking at genomics and genetic testing... but for now smile and wait." My pT3a and G7 SM+ EPE+ was not quite as sever as your results but it does appear that there is no need to rush if the PSA scores stay down.

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: You've received a lot of important information and advice here. I just want to add one more caution - as you proceed along the Prostate Cancer path you will find there are few black/white or clear cut decisions. You will learn that very intelligent, well informed, and experienced professionals and patients can come to differing or even conflicting opinions. That, IMHO, is the norm for we PCa patients and you will have to adapt to that ambiguity. My medical oncologist/urologist (25+years experience with over 1,000 open RP surgeries) who did the initial diagnosis, MRI, and biopsy insisted, after the 12-core TRUS biopsy, I begin primary treatment ASAP and in no case should I take longer than 4-weeks to start treatment. My MO referred me to a highly experienced RALP surgeon (1,600 RALPs and over 12-years experience doing them) whom the MO worked with on a daily basis. The RALP surgeon reviewed all my tests and told me there was No Hurry to make a decision and suggested I also talk with a Radiation Oncologist to learn more about RT as a primary treatment. The RALP surgeon said he would be comfortable waiting up to 4-months to do the surgery. The RO reviewed all my tests and talked with me several times. His attitude about the timing was - No rush, let's take our time and do the right thing. SO - it came down to a personal decision on my part as to when to have the primary RALP treatment. I chose sooner rather than later because I was way to emotional and confused to spend months trying to decide. The surgeon had a sudden opening in his schedule and I had the RALP done just 20-days after the biopsy. A minor detail to highlight the ambiguity in many of our decisions. A lot of folks on this forum have doctors tell them to wait 6-weeks or more after the biopsy to do the surgery because of the prostate trauma during Bx. My highly experienced MO said there was NO data to support that claim. My RALP surgeon said he knew of no data to support the claim but he "typically" did wait at least a month post Bx but had no real concerns about doing my RALP surgery just 20-days post-Bx.

Posts.Title: Adverse pathology results Decipher ordered

Posts.Content: You've received a lot of important information and advice here. I just want to add one more caution - as you proceed along the Prostate Cancer path you will find there are few black/white or clear cut decisions. You will learn that very intelligent, well informed, and experienced professionals and patients can come to differing or even conflicting opinions. That, IMHO, is the norm for we PCa patients and you will have to adapt to that ambiguity. My medical oncologist/urologist (25+years experience with over 1,000 open RP surgeries) who did the initial diagnosis, MRI, and biopsy insisted, after the 12-core TRUS biopsy, I begin primary treatment ASAP and in no case should I take longer than 4-weeks to start treatment. My MO referred me to a highly experienced RALP surgeon (1,600 RALPs and over 12-years experience doing them) whom the MO worked with on a daily basis. The RALP surgeon reviewed all my tests and told me there was No Hurry to make a decision and suggested I also talk with a Radiation Oncologist to learn more about RT as a primary treatment. The RALP surgeon said he would be comfortable waiting up to 4-months to do the surgery. The RO reviewed all my tests and talked with me several times. His attitude about the timing was - No rush, let's take our time and do the right thing. SO - it came down to a personal decision on my part as to when to have the primary RALP treatment. I chose sooner rather than later because I was way to emotional and confused to spend months trying to decide. The surgeon had a sudden opening in his schedule and I had the RALP done just 20-days after the biopsy. A minor detail to highlight the ambiguity in many of our decisions. A lot of folks on this forum have doctors tell them to wait 6-weeks or more after the biopsy to do the surgery because of the prostate trauma during Bx. My highly experienced MO said there was NO data to support that claim. My RALP surgeon said he knew of no data to support the claim but he "typically" did wait at least a month post Bx but had no real concerns about doing my RALP surgery just 20-days post-Bx.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: I sure don't want to forecast doom and gloom or to be overly pessimistic BUT... You can see in my signature that my PSA progression from age 63 to age 71 (5.8 to 10.2) was similar to yours. And, my June 28, 2018 3T mpMRI was more optimistic than yours. Based on the MRI findings I really wanted to postpone the TRUS biopsy but my medical urologist/oncologist convinced to have the biopsy done August 3, 2018. That biopsy convinced me to have a RALP procedure done on August 23. I received the pathology report yesterday. Staging upgraded from cT1c to pT3a but Gleason stayed the same 7 (3+4) The MRI report understated: - size of the lesion by FOUR orders of magnitude (0.32 cc in MRI -vs- 7g in the pathology lab) - size of prostate by a factor of 2 (18cc -vs- 35cc in the pathology lab) The MRI report missed: - ALL the cancerous cells in the right lobe - the EPE I ended up with 2mm positive surgical margins at the left posterior apex, which in my limited understanding, is due to the EPE in that location, which the MRI missed. I was very fortunate that my medical urologist was quite skeptical about the MRI reported tumor size. My PSA density of .57 was way TOO high given the MRI and TRUS prostate size (18 cc) and the MRI reported lesion size (0.32cc) so he convinced me to trust him and the surgeon. The pathology report confirmed his suspicions. The more I read and communicate with doctors who are not surgeons or radiologists the more I find that the 3T mpMRI can be good indicator but can also miss a lot of bad stuff. I don't know what you can do with my pessimistic experience but, that experience has really changed my believe that technology and imaging reveals the truth or even the partial truth.

AgeInfo.Phrase: my PSA progression from age 63 to age 71  5 8
from age 63 to age 71  5 8 to 10 2

Posts.Title: My 3T MRI Results Are In

Posts.Content: almost 71 years old Very active lifestyle in excellent health ride a high performance bicycle at least 100 miles a week sail (single hand / "by myself") a 40-foot sailboat I've always been a serious athlete and in excellent cardio-vascular health PSA results: 2.00 September 2004 Negative DRE 4.05 April 2010 Negative DRE Long hard bicycle ride before blood draw - No One had warned me about bicycle riding and PSA tests 5.80 November 2010 4.54 August 2012 Negative DRE 5.63 August 2013 Negative DRE 9.24 May 2018 long hard (HR averaged 147) bike ride 66-hours before May 2018 blood draw. I use a hard narrow "racing" saddle on the bike and my feet do not touch the ground for hours at a time The 2004, '10, '12, '13 tests were done at the same lab in Washington State The 2018 test was done at a lab in SW Florida I have NO physical symptoms, i.e. urination difficulties, frequent urination, incomplete emptying...etc. NO family history of prostate cancer (sibs, father, grandfathers, uncles) My GP ( a 50-year old female internist) wants me to consult with a urologist I want to wait another four months and make sure I do not do any bicycle riding for at least four days prior to the blood draw Any opinions? My real problem is that my wife is 10-years younger than me and comes from a family, where for many generations, the women have lived in good health past the century mark. I promised her, 44-years ago when we met and fell instantly in love, that I would out live her. I've tried everything I know since then to keep that promise. Does that change any opinions?

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Here is a relatively new article about Ductal Adenocarcinoma: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4779765/ It appears there are now known to be two types PURE and MIXED. The Mixed or PIN type has a much more favorable prognosis. "Moreover, serum PSA level is not associated with tumor staging, recurrence and metastasis, and might not be an ideal prognostic indicator for risk assessment and prediction of recurrence in PDA (1. In summary, PDA is a rare, but the second common histological variants of prostatic carcinoma. It has unique origin, histological features, and biological behavior. Due to its aggressive clinical course and high risk of disease progression, it is important for us to differentiate PDA from other mimickers." An even more current study in Oct 2017 Radiation Oncology (Ductal Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate Gland Treated With Radical Prostatectomy or Radiation Therapy: A Single Institutional Retrospective Review With Long-Term Follow-Up) https://www.redjournal.org/article/S...327-1/fulltext. The 5-year/10-year statitistics for 25 radical prostetectomy patients were: - progression-free probability (PFP) was 56%/49% - prostate-cancer-specific survival (PCSS) 100% / 86% - overall survival (OS) rates 100%/86%. Those numbers are only slightly worse than for my G7 (3+4) SM+ EPE+ cohort.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH I generally jog for ONE HOUR every day, which amounts to somewhere around 7-8 miles. I generally consider this to burn about 1200 calories. If you are able to jog -- and do it at a pace of around one mile in 8 minutes -- you can actually surpass those 900 calories. I would love to be able to run again! I was a life long runner and have run a lot of trail and road miles all over the world because I traveled for work 200-days a year 1984 - 1999. I've had seven knee surgeries with no cushion of any kind left in the knees, two crushed feet, a broken ankle, tib-fib fracture, and two crush injuries on the thigh which damaged the muscle. I ran for six years after the last pair of arthroscopic knee "port and polish" procedures but there is just nothing left. This fall was supposed to bring me two new knees - we'll see if the prostate interferes. I now have trouble walking more than a couple miles. My wife was also a superb runner for 30+ years who could do hours of 6:30s on hilly trails without breaking a sweat. She would run with me at my 7:30 pace for 40 or so minutes, then get bored and then take off for another hour on her own while I found my way home (in the car because we usually ran on trails in the country). She had to give up running last summer after an intetrochanteric femur/hip fracture (bike riding), which required two titanium rods to fix the bones for healing. She was also a very strong mountain and road bike rider but her orthopedic guy says her bones are so fragile now that even the slightest fall will shatter a bone. She has a Ti rod and four Ti screws ($2,500 apiece) in her humerus after a mountain biking accident in the San Diego foothills (2014). Getting old is not so much fun for us old jocks who defined their lives by athletics and other outdoor stuff. I love to read and work on the computer but really get antsy if I don't get my heart rate above 130 for an hour a day. Tough to be off the bike. A good alternative is swimming and/or the stairmaster at a local gym. I do swim everyday in our private pool but it is seven strokes, kick turn, seven strokes, and not that much fun. I am a strong swimmer and would like to swim in the canal we live on but the water is pretty dirty, has an alligator or three, and recently two really big dolphins. You have inspired me to check with the local gym to see if I can get a short term membership. Or - now that you have rattled my thinking- I can check with the YMCA down the street and see if my Florida Blue Shield Silver Sneakers card works there. Thanks for the inspiration!

AgeInfo.Phrase: with me at my 7 30 pace for 40 or so

Posts.Title: First Urologist appointment - not what I expected

Posts.Content: almost 71 years old Very active lifestyle in excellent health ride a high performance bicycle at least 100 miles a week sail (single hand / "by myself") a 40-foot sailboat I've always been a serious athlete and in excellent cardio-vascular health PSA results: 2.00 September 2004 Negative DRE 4.05 April 2010 Negative DRE Long hard bicycle ride before blood draw - No One had warned me about bicycle riding and PSA tests 5.80 November 2010 4.54 August 2012 Negative DRE 5.63 August 2013 Negative DRE 9.24 May 2018 long hard (HR averaged 147) bike ride 66-hours before May 2018 blood draw. I use a hard narrow "racing" saddle on the bike and my feet do not touch the ground for hours at a time The 2004, '10, '12, '13 tests were done at the same lab in Washington State The 2018 test was done at a lab in SW Florida I have NO physical symptoms, i.e. urination difficulties, frequent urination, incomplete emptying...etc. NO family history of prostate cancer (sibs, father, grandfathers, uncles) My GP ( a 50-year old female internist) wants me to consult with a urologist I want to wait another four months and make sure I do not do any bicycle riding for at least four days prior to the blood draw Any opinions? My real problem is that my wife is 10-years younger than me and comes from a family, where for many generations, the women have lived in good health past the century mark. I promised her, 44-years ago when we met and fell instantly in love, that I would out live her. I've tried everything I know since then to keep that promise. Does that change any opinions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ljames What was your 4K score. Any update from your Urologist? The doc is on vacation so I will not know my 4KScore until July 18 when I seem him again. As I said in my original post the doctor "repeatedly stressed that nothing he said and no test results we receive in the interim would diminish the need for a TRUS/12-core biopsy. " Now that the radiologist has isolated a suspicious 1.0 x 0.6 x 0.7 cm lesion on the 3T mpMRI imaging - the urologist will know exactly where to take a sample or two. The good news is that the potential lesion is a "subtle area" with "equivocal" radiological characteristics and the rest of the prostate is "unremarkable" as stated in the radiologists findings. I am trying to focus on that potentially positive news in that report and betting that the biopsy findings will define the lesion with no bad news.

Posts.Title: Amazing how ones perspective can change!

Posts.Content: First meeting with my 52-year old urologist to discuss diagnostic process for ever increasing PSA values. Discussed lifestyle and history. He had all medical data from my GP/Internist for last 18-months. And he had details about my PSA values, testing methods, and equipment for all values back to 2004. He then performed an extensive DRE, which found unusually small and soft prostate with no abnormalities, hard spots, or lumps. However, the prostate is small enough the the PSA density, (PSA value 9.24), is troubling. He wants me to abstain from sex and bike riding for two weeks and then have another PSA analysis, including Free PSA. His experience is that a week of abstinence, (bicycle riding and sex), is usually sufficient but with my particular anatomy, style of bike riding, and history he wants two full weeks to allow the prostate to calm after the exam and the three very hard bicycle rides I have done in the last four days. His alternative was to do the 3T MP MRI tomorrow but he is pretty sure that it will find nothing and I will still have to go two weeks for the next PSA blood draw. IF he thinks a biopsy is needed, after the next PSA result is known, he will order a 3T MP MRI prior to the biopsy. We discussed fusion / in bore biopsy but he is no fan. He has done a lot of them and was initially excited about them but know feels they provide little better sensitivity compared to a TRUS-biopsy done after careful examination of the prior 3T MP MRI. I asked about going direct to a Prostate Template biopsy (36 or 54 core) to avoid the low sensitivity of a TRUS-Biopsy. With my "quite small" prostate he thinks it would be hard to miss a lesion when doing a standard TRUS-biopsy while carefully consulting the prior MRI image. His extensive experience tells him that any small malignant mass in my particular case will be detected by a TRUS-Biopsy. He does a lot of 4KScoring after the biopsy and uses the other bio-marker analysis as well as genetic examination of the biopsy tumor specimens if found. His primary message was to avoid over diagnosis and certainly over treatment. His bottom line to me was "I've only lost one patient to an aggressive cancer that we could have caught earlier with a more aggressive diagnosis and treatment. We are learning to be much more cautious and calculating in our diagnosis and treatment plans and I see no need to rush anything in your case." I asked him about windows of treatment opportunity how long they stay open. He again stressed that few cancers that are undetectable with DRE and a PSA<10 would suddenly become aggressive. If - IF! - the MRI finds anything suspicious and then a biopsy yields cells to type, grade, and get genetic details from, he will then be able to determine if a sudden acceleration of tumor growth MIGHT be possible. But, for now we will wait and test again later in June. I guess we older men, or men with elevated PSA, and no biopsy details just have to learn to live with a fair amount of unpleasant uncertainty. No bicycle riding for two weeks is a real problem because that is over 200 miles and at least 14 hours riding, which burns 900 calories/hour. I can easily go two weeks with no sex but I cannot stop drinking beer for two weeks, which is what I would have to do if I don't burn that extra 900+ calories a day.

Posts.Title: First Urologist appointment - not what I expected

Posts.Content: Recovery from a RALP is tricky for old endurance jocks like us. Our history and experience leads us to think we "can just do it" but there is more to the recovery than one first realizes. I have had a lifetime of demanding physical endeavors - 10-years as a concrete laborer in the hot Virginia sun, long distance running, bicycling, hiking, back country ski expeditions, monumental alpine climbs... etc. I have always been used to and able to "push on through" to take one more step, to climb one more hill, over and over until the destination is achieved, no matter the cost. The RALP surgery leaves little external physical indication of the enormous stress your body has suffered and is continuing to endure. It is easy to look at your abdomen and compare it to old injuries that barely slowed you down. A couple days after the surgery I was apparently well on the way to recovery, from an external visual perspective, and felt like "no big deal" was the answer. But, internally your body is recovering from a lot of trauma and is spending vast amounts of energy repairing that damage. There were times when I just could not summon the energy to stand up and move or even to take those few steps to get a drink of juice - I was too tired! Not sore, not in pain - just exhausted. I felt like a failure when I compared my current state with how I felt after previous monumental physical efforts that seemed to require more of me. I guess the combination of many years abuse to the body and all the internal trauma makes the recovery much slower and more exhausting than external symptoms would lead us to believe.

Posts.Title: da Vinci surgery - recover on my own?

Posts.Content: I needed almost no help physically after my RALP. I drove 61-miles home from the hospital just 29-hours after the surgery. I was out walking around the neighborhood the 2nd day after the surgery. I drove to Walmart and stood in line for 10-minutes picking up a Rx on the 3rd day after surgery. I then drove myself 122-miles round trip to have the catheter removed 5-days post surgery. I was able to fix my own simple meals the 2nd day and was taking showers with no help the evening after the surgery. I slept in my own bed with no difficulties and sat at my desk and used the computer for hours each day, beginning the morning of the 2nd day. BUT... My loving wife of 44-years has attended me after eight major surgeries and was always standing by if I needed help. She and I have been through many medical and physical crises and I knew I could count on her if anything unexpected happened to me or to us. She was a great comfort when I was exhausted and too tired to get out of my recliner to find a drink or snack. She made sure my catheter stayed clean and that I was drinking enough water and juice. Most important - she was there to talk to me and steady my mind as I struggled with the intense exhaustion and fatigue that lasted several weeks. I was physically able to do anything I wanted but the mental strain was quite noticeable and I just always felt like everything was a struggle. Small practical details that would have been a burden and hard effort for me were simple and easy for her. I am sure I would have been very unhappy, and mentally exhausted, if I had to deal with even one of those a day. For example, my catheter bag leaked badly the first time I tried to empty it and made a mess in the master bathroom. She had to get down on her hands and knees to mop up behind the toilet. That would have been near impossible for me! Or - the garbage can need to be taken out to the street the 4th day after surgery. I could probably have done the job and probably would have hurt myself. It was easy for her. Physically - I needed no help and was able to care for myself. Mentally and Emotionally - I would not want to have spent the two weeks post surgery all alone. You do need someone to stand by, watch out, and provide an emotional crutch.

Posts.Title: da Vinci surgery - recover on my own?

Posts.Content: I had my 2nd appointment with a urologist today and was dreading it because my PSA had gone from 9.2 on May 18 to 10.2 on June 20. And, my Free PSA percentage was 8.4% on June 20. I used a prostate risk calculator (age, family history, PSA, Free PSA %), which said 35% chance high grade cancer and 46% chance low grade cancer, which I interpreted to mean 81% chance of having PCa. That seems like a BIG number to me! Summary result: “you need a biopsy but there is no rush and we’ve got a few other things to do first” His demeanor and attitude was calm and reeked of experience and certitude. He made it clear by word, expression, and tone that he had seen all this many times and knows exactly what to do and when to do it. His ONLY concern was that I commit to having the biopsy on the schedule he selected and, in the manner, he chooses. He was willing to discuss many topics and answer a lot of questions but he repeatedly stressed that nothing he said and no test results we receive in the interim would diminish the need for a TRUS/12-core biopsy. Forty minutes after entering his office, my wife and I left with a more positive and less stressed outlook. At the start of the appointment he gave me the June 20 PSA value (10.2). I asked about the Free PSA percentage and he plainly said “Free PSA is of no diagnostic value with a PSA score above 10. You ABSOLUTELY need a biopsy with a PSA 10 ng/ml and the Free PSA value will not change that fact.” He would venture no opinion about Free PSA % as an indicator/predictor of Lo-grade or Hi-grade PCa. He just stressed that with a PSA above 10 and having doubled in five years - a biopsy is mandatory and the grade, type, and amount of PCa would become more clear after the biopsy. I again stressed that “I don’t fear or worry about any procedures but do worry very much, even obsess, about consistently high PSA values with negative biopsies.” His response was “You learn to deal with it while understanding that I have many patients with a PSA consistently above 20 or 30 with no sign of PCa after more than six biopsies, some guided by a 3T MP MRI. Some men just have ‘PSA leakage’ which results in abnormally high PSA but we never find a cancer.” The Next Steps in my Journey: Today – 4KScore blood draw He believes the patient should have all possible information as early in the process as is possible. He finds the 4KScore is helpful in making the patient understand the nature of their problem. Tomorrow – 3T MP MRI with NO rectal antenna July 18 – another appointment to discuss 4K and MRI results. He will also obtain a rectal swap to determine which antibiotic(s) to take before, during, and after the biopsy Later in July – TRUS/12 Core biopsy using image (but not fused) prepared by his radiologist as a guide for sample locations. I use a rectal enema the morning of the biopsy. Antibiotic(s) may be given prior to the procedure, during the procedure (if necessary), and after the procedure based on the rectal swap results. He does the biopsy using Propofol sedation unless the patient asks not to be sedated. I am all for Propofol sedation. I’ve had two endoscopies, an AFib electro conversion (shock to the heart), and three colonoscopies under Propofol and really appreciate the peace of mind and lack of stress it provides. I’ve got a 13-year history of heart arrythmias and he wants a cardiologist to clear me for the Propofol prior to the biopsy. I had two Propofol sedated colonoscopies in fall 2016 ( I had 2-week serious colon cancer scare with severe rectal bleeding and mysterious lump in upper colon on a contrast CT scan ) so have no concern about the general anesthetic. My GP/Internist did a 12-lead EKG study last month and found no abnormalities so that may satisfy the anesthesiologist. The biopsy takes 10-minutes so I will be sedated for only 15-minutes and should be out of recovery in less than an hour. He has done over 3,000 biopsies using the same two pathologists during the last fifteen years and is very confident about their findings. But, he said they have automatic procedures to send all images and biopsy material to John Hopkins for a 2nd opinion if the patient requests or if he or the pathologist wants a 2nd opinion. The biopsy results will be available three business days after the procedure and he will see me five days after the biopsy to discuss results and potential tactics and/or treatments.

Posts.Title: da Vinci surgery - recover on my own?

Posts.Content: Recovery from a RALP is tricky for old endurance jocks like us. Our history and experience leads us to think we "can just do it" but there is more to the recovery than one first realizes. I have had a lifetime of demanding physical endeavors - 10-years as a concrete laborer in the hot Virginia sun, long distance running, bicycling, hiking, back country ski expeditions, monumental alpine climbs... etc. I have always been used to and able to "push on through" to take one more step, to climb one more hill, over and over until the destination is achieved, no matter the cost. The RALP surgery leaves little external physical indication of the enormous stress your body has suffered and is continuing to endure. It is easy to look at your abdomen and compare it to old injuries that barely slowed you down. A couple days after the surgery I was apparently well on the way to recovery, from an external visual perspective, and felt like "no big deal" was the answer. But, internally your body is recovering from a lot of trauma and is spending vast amounts of energy repairing that damage. There were times when I just could not summon the energy to stand up and move or even to take those few steps to get a drink of juice - I was too tired! Not sore, not in pain - just exhausted. I felt like a failure when I compared my current state with how I felt after previous monumental physical efforts that seemed to require more of me. I guess the combination of many years abuse to the body and all the internal trauma makes the recovery much slower and more exhausting than external symptoms would lead us to believe.

Posts.Title: da Vinci surgery - recover on my own?

Posts.Content: My recent experience beginning mid-May 2018: May 18 Internist reports PSA = 9.2 June 6 Urologist/Oncologist finds negative DRE and wants new PSA test one month after May test June 18 Urologist/Oncologist reports PSA = 10.2. He then orders more tests while telling me "there is no need to rush, PCa grows slowly, and I have never lost a patient to PCa due to his being slow and cautious" June 28 3T mpMRI finds PIRADS 3 "indeterminate" tumor in prostate July 17 Urologist/Oncologist reports my 4KScore and free PSA showing a high probability of PCA and about a 35% chance of "significant" PCa so orders 12-core TRUS biopsy to occur "soon." Various problems delay biopsy until August 3 which Urologist/Oncologist says is no problem and he still is not concerned about rushing my final diagnosis or treatment August 10 I meet with Urologist/Oncologist who has biopsy results showing significant G7 (3+4) PCA in one lobe but a considerable volume. He then decides we should "speed up" the process and wants me to have a Radical Prostatectomy ASAP with a maximum delay of less than 4-weeks. August 14 I meet with the RALP surgeon who reviews ALL the tests and images and states there is "no rush and no reason to hurry my decision about surgery or radiation." He goes on to say that I can safely take "a couple months" to make my decision. The surgeon reminds me he has treated over 1,600 men with PCa by removing their prostate and he knows for sure that my case does not demand a rush to treatment or even decision making August 23 I have the surgery which shows the PCa had escaped the prostate capsule. Neither doctor will tell me if I needed to rush the surgery. But, from my personal perspective - I am VERY GLAD I had the surgery done ASAP and thus diminished the time of worry and wondering if I was making the correct decision. Just one experience but everything worked OK for me!

Posts.Title: Length of time to wait for the biopsy checking for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Thank You so much for the link to the Men's Health article, which is a fantastic summary of the recent evolution of non-surgical/non-radiation prostate cancer therapy. I had no idea there was so much happening in the drug, hormone, and immunotherapy world that will help us prostate cancer survivors. Your story is truly an inspiration. And, it is very encouraging to a post-RALP patient with adverse pathology to know that so much research is moving forward and into commercial exploitation. I really enjoyed the story because it is so local for my wife and I. She grew up in Longview in a family business which supported the timber and logging industry. Her family owned a large Christmas Tree farm on the Toutle and she learned to ski and do crazy stuff on snow mobiles at Mt. St. Helens. I was a hard core Gorge board sailor '82 thru '99. One of my best friends lived and died in Chehalis. My first wife was from Vancouver, Wa. I lived in Tacoma for 38 years between 1965 and 2013.

Posts.Title: HI PSA post surgery

Posts.Content: All I want to do this week is schedule my da.. biopsy But am having no luck accomplishing that seemingly simple task. SO am posting here just to give myself somewhere to vent. Is it always so hard to keep the PCa process moving along at what, to the patient, seems like a reasonable pace, but to the medical specialists is just the normal, "no hurry here" pace? Or, does this patient have unreasonable expectations as to the pace of progress, diagnosis, and decision making? May 24 My Internist tells me my PSA has gone from 5.8 to 9.2 in a little less than 5-years and I need to see a urologist May 24 - May 28 Receive invaluable advice here, which convinces me to get biopsy ASAP May 29 Schedule first urologist appointment ASAP June 6 First urologist exam results in another PSA test scheduled for June 20 June 27 2nd Urologist visit where I learn PSA has increased to 10.2 with 8.4% Free PSA. Urologist Schedules MRI ASAP and draws blood for 4KScore and tells me he is on vacation until July 17 June 28 3T mpMRI July 6 receive copy of radiologist report 0.3cc lesion in 18cc prostate results in PIRADS 3 due to indeterminate tumor Up to this point I feel like I am making adequate and reasonable progress toward a diagnosis. But, I have to wait another 12-days because my urologist is on vacation. July 18 3rd Urologist visit (mid-morning) where I learn 4KScore shows 34% probability of Gleason 7 or greater. He wants to schedule TRUS 12-core biopsy ASAP but needs medical and cardio clearance from my Internist. Urologist thinks my May 24 EKG and lab results should be current enough for the clearance he needs. But, I must wait for his scheduler to call me and they will contact my Internist for clearance. July 19 Still no call from biopsy scheduler so I call that number and leave message but get no call back July 20 I leave two more messages for biopsy scheduler but get no call back. Finally at 3 PM I get a call, which tells me they cannot schedule the biopsy unitl they receive medical clearance from my Internist, which is new news to me and something I wished I had known because my Internist's back office is careless. Biopsy scheduler says they sent two faxes to my Internist but "don't think either one went thru because our machine was out of paper the first time and wasn't working the 2nd time." I offer to call my internist but get the answer "It is late on Friday and we won't do anything more until Monday morning." July 23 I Call my Internist but am not allowed to talk to the office staff so ask them to call me back about the missing Fax. I get no call back, despite sending another e-mail requesting help. I call biopsy scheduler who sends another FAX to my Internist. I call my internist at 11 AM and am told they have not received any of three faxes but tell me to come in for the EKG and medical exam at 3 PM. Internist will not sign off on medical release using EKG, blood tests, and physical exams that are more than 10-days old and does not care how the urologist feels about my May exams, labs, and EKG. July 23 3 PM My Internist and her office can find no copy of Fax sent to them from my Urologist. EKG is clear so I call my urologist who insists they sent three Faxes. My internist sends her RN out to search "everywhere" for the missing faxes while Internist attends rest of medical exam. My Internist then finds an infected wound on my ankle. I knew about it and told her it was two-weeks old and healing slowly but that is what happens with wounds down there. She agreed and said she would not mention it or consider the wound in the medical clearance decsion. RN returns with the missing faxes, which had a heading of "Pre-Procedure Insurance Clearance" but, since I had no scheduled procedure, the office staff discarded them. Whoops! Urologist clearance form plainly asks about open wounds and infections so my Internist cannot sign the form. She gives me Rx for 7-day antibiotic and treats the wound with topical antibiotic. She schedules another appointment for July 27 to see if wound has healed enough for her to give me clearance for the biopsy. I have suffered many serious lower leg injuries in the last ten years due to mountain bike crashes. All those wounds do heal but they take about 4-weeks to completely heal up. July 25 - I cannot get the biopsy scheduled until next week so I decide to go ahead with my semi-annual bi-lateral cortisone injections in my creaky old knees (7-surgeries over the last 55-years). My long time knee doc's PA sees the wound on my ankle and tells me that cortisone is out of the question because of it's negative effect on wound healing due to it diminishing lucocyte effectivetivness. She examines the wound in detail and tells me that it will be at least three-weeks until the wound and infection heals enough to have an invasive procedure such as a 12-core biopsy. I've sent a note to the urologist asking him if can do the biopsy after my 7-day antibiotic regimine, which ends noon Monday July 30 but have heard no answer. Given what I know now - my biopsy cannot be scheduled until at least August 17 which means I will not receive a diagnosis and Gleason score until at least August 25. Is this about the normal course of events (91 days from PSA results to biopsy results) in the early diagonstic stages of the PCa journey? Am I being impatient? I know PCa moves at a slower pace and is seldom an acute problem... BUT, is it humane to have over 3-months elapse from the time a patient is told PSA=9 with 1 in 3 probabilty of clinically significant PCa to the pathology report on that PCa? I guess the answer is - "It is what it is and I just need to accept it and continue to live with positive thoughts"... but that is hard to do! Rant over ... now I feel a little better.

Posts.Title: I am so frustrated while trying to schedule first biopsy! (Long Rant!)

Posts.Content: Thanks for the Medscape link. That was one of the many things I had read. What I find most interesting is the Kaiser Permanete Clinical Review ( https://provider.ghc.org/all-sites/c...df/4kscore.pdf ) prepared for their physicians in late 2017. There is insufficient evidence in the published medical literature to show that this service/therapy is as safe as standard services/therapies and/or provides better long-term outcomes than current standard services/therapies. And then provides many technical details that to my somewhat well trained statistical eye appear to actually confirm the test does provide very useful information to someone like me who is trying to decide about biopsy / no biopsy. The authors compared the predictive accuracy of the 4Kscore vs. a modified Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial Risk Calculator (PCPTRC) 2.0. The results showed that the 4Kscore had a significantly higher discrimination in detecting Gleason ≥7 cancer compared to modified PCPTRC 2.0 (AUC 0.82 versus 0.74, p<0.0001) Kaiser Permanente/Group Health is the largest HMO in the United States and employs more than 21,000 physicians. A new twist in my decision process is that the practice suggesting the 3T MP MRI as a first step assured me that the 4KScore test is covered by Medicare but they recommend the MRI as a first step and then the 4KScore can be used if the MRI reveals suspicious lumps and bumps in my prostate. I was sent a e-mail by the practice billing department to confirm Medicare does pay for the 4KScore test. A May 18, 2018 draft policy by Medicare administrative services provider Novitas Solutions recommends denying coverage for OPKO's 4Kscore test. That draft policy seemed to state that CMS (Medicare) will not pay for a 4KScore test. That draft policy is open for comments thru July 5, 2018 so who knows when the official CMS decision will occur.

Posts.Title: 4kScore -vs- 3TMPMRI

Posts.Content: Michael F said "Like a sailing regatta, navigate it one leg at a time. But be sure an expert URO MD is your navigator! " Having been a navigator in a factory sponsored race sailboat I do appreciate the value of such a person. However, I graduated to being a Tactician and realized that the best Navigator cannot overcome bad tactics. The Navigator gets us to where we want to go but I am concerned with knowing where to go. Will the next windshift be sufficient to counter the backeddy of the tidal shore current on the rhumb line or should we stay offshore and avoid the backeddy? If not - navigating to the point were the wind shift first occurs is of no value. At this point it seems to me that starting with the 3T MP MRI would give the best possible information about potential lesions and lumps hidden in the Prostate and can then be used for fused guidance if a biopsy is indicated subsequent to seeing the MRI picture. As you say - a biopsy is most likely in the next couple years so Why Not start with imaging that also serves as a guide for that most likely biopsy. Looking at your signature - Why did you have a biopsy with a PSA < 3.0? Was it the positive DRE? My family doc was a board certified internist and quite confident that they knew how to do a thorough DRE. With a PSA fluctuating up AND down between 4.0 and 5.8 for 3.5 years (age 63 - 65) but always a "normal" DRE they felt I was at a low risk of PCa and PSA/DRE testing every other year was sufficient. If a Urology practice tells me that Medicare/Florida Blue Plan F will pay 100% of the cost of a procedure/diagnostic test is it safe to believe them? I can find no way to verify that such an event is actually covered by Medicare.

AgeInfo.Phrase: for 3 5 years  age 63   65  but always a  normal

Posts.Title: 4kScore -vs- 3TMPMRI

Posts.Content: I have an appointment next Wednesday with a local urologist who is the senior partner in a large SW Florida practice. He wants to talk with my wife and I and review my PSA and family history as well as our attitudes and concerns. He will then recommend next steps. The practice website and patient testimonials indicate the use of pretty new technology and techniques. One of their more interesting diagnostic tools, from my perceptive, is the 4KScore blood analysis. I did a lot of professional work developing similar predictive scoring, based on historical measures, in a far different field. I have spent a lot of time studying the various validation studies for OPKO and 4KScore and think I have a good understanding of the advantages and potential problems. I have verified that Medicare will not pay the $400 cost of a 4KScore blood analysis. My other local option is to have a 3T Multiparametric MR Imaging & 3D Prostate Mapping procedure done by a different practice, which tells me is 100% covered by Medicare and my Florida Blue supplemental insurance. I am having trouble understanding the advantage of having the 4KScore , which only yields the probability of an aggressive cancer when the 3TMP MRI will actually show lesions and lumps and can subsequently be used for biopsy guidance in a fused situation. I like the idea of starting with another simple blood test but wonder what information I actually gain from that blood test. Does anyone have any 4KScore experience that can explain the 4KScore advantage over starting with a sophisticated MRI?

Posts.Content: Lost my father to a similar and rather unexpected problem. The last month of his life tore our family of four siblings apart and that rupture has not been repaired in 10-years. My father was a retired veterinarian who had led a wonderful and productive life. He was 91-years old and in good health when the grim prognosis was given. He had won a total remission from a quite rare lymphoma ten-years earlier. That was a cancer which had about a 1% 2-year survival rate so he was used to knowing bad news and planning for it. Dad made his wishes crystal clear: - no extraordinary measures - he wanted to die with dignity at home - he wanted to die in a state of peace and had the means to effect that - he wanted to die while he still had his mental facilities and was able to tell his family good-bye He told each and every one of his children and his four siblings the same thing "I want to die my way at my time" The family clearly understood and agreed. He was the eldest son and the most successful of his five brothers and sisters and was always the leader of the family. When his end time approached my sister panicked and got a court order to hospitalize him and to declare him mentally incompetent and made my sister his guardian. In the hospital (medical not hospice); he underwent many gruesome procedures which extended his end time by weeks. He was in pain, some physical but most mental, as he lay there in agony waiting to die. He called me, I lived 3,000 miles away, and begged for help because none of us brothers knew he had been institutionalized. We brothers retained an attorney to fight the court order but my sister's attorney was far more skilled at manipulating the Florida Baker act. End result - he died exactly the way he feared. But, he was able to kill himself while in the hospital. A truly terrible end to a near perfect life. The family has never recovered from the trauma of that last month of his life. We now know my father could have had even more explicit end of life instructions that would have prevented my sister from getting the court order. Please make sure you ALL know and agree about your fathers end time and how HE wants it to proceed. Sorry to be so dark and gloomy but it is hard to describe the misery we experienced during that last month of court battles and terrible hospital visits.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> He was 91 years old and in good

Posts.Title: Stage 4 prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Your numbers since 2014 and your thought process seem to be very similar to me and mine since 2004. Me . Age / PSA 57/2.0 .......... 62/4.0... 63/4.5 .. 66/5.6 ... no more tests until Age 70 years 10 months/9.2 70 years 11 months/10.2 71 years/10.4 YOU Age / PSA 59/2.6 60/3.1 62/3.4... 63/6.4 You can read my many postings here since late May when I was trying to avoid a biopsy and was looking for all kinds of tests and reasons to justify that avoidance. I had Free PSA and 4KScore tests and a 3T mpMRI. All of which gave me some ammunition to use in my struggle to avoid a biopsy. I had a 2 out of 3 chance of finding a Gleason 6 or less cell structure WHEN I finally decided to have a biopsy. Thankfully, Forum Brothers here let me understand the error of my thinking and analysis and my urologist convinced me to have the TRUS 12-Core biopsy guided by an external MRI image. Biopsy results were not so good and I need IMMEDIATE treatment, either prostatectomy or radiation. There is also about a 5% chance I have waited too long and the Gleason 7 cells have left the barn and are roaming about outside the prostate. The results from mine were totally unexpected, shocking, disturbing, and will make a huge difference in my future life. But, if I understand what my urologist told me yesterday - without the biopsy I would most likely have had metastatic disease within five years. I had pushed the window of easy treatment, which started in about 2010 with a PSA that went from 4.0 to 5.8 in 6-months, as far as I could. My life has now slid outside that easy treatment window. DO NOT wait! Your PSA doubling time is short and your PSA scores are high for your age. My biopsy was done with "conscious sedation" provided by Propofol. I was lying on the table having a nice chat with the doctor about college basketball, the nurse/anestheologist patted my arm and said "you'll relax for while now", and it seemed just a short moment later I was laying on same table in a nice recovery room with my wife holding my hand. NO pain, NO discomfort, no side effects, no infection, no urinary problems and I am 8-days post biopsy. There is absolutely no reason not to have that biopsy. At least the biopsy gave me a firm kick in the ass to move forward with treatment and to stop wishing and hoping things were different. PS - I have had six Propofol procedures in the last 15-years and they have all been non-events. I can find no good reason to not let Propofol remove any concerns you may have about biopsy discomfort or anxiety.

Posts.Content: During my January 9 post-RALP discussion with my MO we spent a bit of time on Ultrasensitive PSA tests (see my prior posting about that). My MO took the time and made the effort to explain that there is a PSA analogue, which is/can be detected by the µPSA test. I did not write down the specifics but in general the PSA analogue is produced by cells in the urinary tract (he gave me the technical name but ????), which have an embryological origin from the same source as normal prostate cells, which produce PSA. There is no way, at the .001 - .003 ng/ml measurement level to differentiate between PSA produced by stray prostate cells that were left behind after the surgery, PCa cells that escaped the capsule and were not removed during surgery, or those cells which produce the analogue PSA and are a normal part of the urinary tract. The amount of analogue PSA produced is highly individual. This was another reason he felt that Ultrasensitive PSA testing was not necessary in my case, and if I understood him correctly in this highly technical discussion, µPSA testing produces a third digit of noise. I have been unable to find any additional information about this topic.

Posts.Title: ExoDx (Ordered by PCP) Encouraging Score, and Urologist Initial Visit

Posts.Content: My biopsy results came back T1c / Grade II / Unfavorable Intermediate 3 of 13-cores Gleason 6 (3+3) 3 of 13-cores Gleason 7 (3+4) I had fully expected to ask my urologist, when we spent an hour discussing the biopsy, all the genetic and biomarker questions you raised in your first post here. I was PREPARED - I knew the lingo, I knew the statistics, I even understand much of the scientific underpinning. I wanted him to schedule all those neat tests so I could go into active surveillance. I described the discussion in another post here but the bottom line when I started talking about genetics and biomarkers was "even if your Gleason scores are all 3+3 you must have immediate treatment because of the PSA density and the 100% tissue involvement of a G7." That information could ONLY be acquired with a biopsy! My 3T mpMRI was, IMHO, optimistic with one very small (0.3 cc) area of unequivocal tissue and the remainder of the tissue "benign prostatic tissue." The biopsy clearly showed that over 50% of my left lobe was G6 or G7 - something that only the biopsy could demonstrate. Having been in your mind space, with similar PSA and blood test results, I can now say that I misinterpreted, because I wanted things to be OK, much of the scientific literature and sales literature associated with all those tests. I wanted to get to Active Surveillance and found an lot of obvious reasons to think it was possible. That is very disappointing to me - I have a graduate education in the design of scientific research, studied how the objective scientic process evolved and now works, and had 30+ years practice apply objective research methods backed by hard statistics. Yet - I let myself delude myself with all the anti-biopsy talk and numbers.

Posts.Title: ExoDx (Ordered by PCP) Encouraging Score, and Urologist Initial Visit

Posts.Content: Reading the guidelines has been a real eye opener for me. It confirms that many of our decisions are made with little statistical evidence to support them. I do understand the complexity of PCa treatment and do appreciate that clinical judgement and experience are critical to the decision making process. BUT - looking closely at just one guideline I have found some interesting information. I have SM+ and EPE+ with G7 (3+4) post RALP and will eventually have to make a decision as indicated in Guideline 2 below. My surgeon, with more than 1,600 RALP surgeries experience, is leaning strongly on Guideline 2. So, I am analyzing it in great detail, particularly in light of more current research, knowing the Guidelines were published six-years ago based on diagnostics, chemistry, and treatments, which are now at least seven-years old. I am mostly quoting from the Guidelines and have placed those quotes in italics AUOA Guideline 2. "Patients with adverse pathologic findings including seminal vesicle invasion, positive surgical margins, and extraprostatic extension should be informed that adjuvant radiotherapy, compared to radical prostatectomy only, reduces the risk of biochemical (PSA) recurrence, local recurrence, and clinical progression of cancer. They should also be informed that the impact of adjuvant radiotherapy on subsequent metastases and overall survival is less clear; one of two randomized controlled trials that addressed these outcomes indicated a benefit but the other trial did not demonstrate a benefit. However, the other trial was not powered to test the benefit regarding metastases and overall survival. (Clinical Principle)" Definition of Clinical Principal: "For some clinical issues, there was little or no evidence from which to construct evidence-based statements. Where gaps in the evidence existed, the Panel provides guidance in the form of Clinical Principles... with consensus achieved using a modified Delphi technique if differences of opinion emerged. A Clinical Principle is a statement about a component of clinical care that is widely agreed upon by urologists or other clinicians for which there may or may not be evidence in the medical literature." Discussion of Guideline 2: "All three trials documented significant improvements in biochemical recurrence-free survival (bRFS) with use of ART compared to RP only (pooled hazard ratio of 0.48" "SWOG 8794 and EORTC 22911 also both demonstrated improved clinical progression-free survival (defined as clinical or imaging evidence of recurrence or death but not including biochemical progression) at more than 10 years of follow up in ART patients compared to RP only patients. This difference was statistically significant in SWOG 8794 and borderline significant (p = 0.054) in EORTC 22911. The Panel also judged improved clinical progression-free survival as an important endpoint because it reflects lower rates of local and distant failure as well as lower death rates associated with the use of ART." My graduate school statistics professor, who was a student of Snedecor who developed the Fischer F-test (statistical significance) used to say "claiming a result is borderline significant (p = 0.054) is like betting on a horse to win a race and then trying to claim part of the prize because it only lost by a nose!" It is significant or it is not significant and anyone who claims borderline is not a real scientist. Therefore, IMHO, the statement "demonstrated improved clinical progression-free survival (defined as clinical or imaging evidence of recurrence or death" was not replicated by any study. "Therefore, in the context of offering ART to patients, it should be emphasized that there is less certainty regarding potential benefits in terms of preventing metastatic recurrence and improving overall survival." "Only SWOG 8794 demonstrated significantly improved overall survival (74% in ART patients compared to 66% for RP only patients) and significantly improved metastatic recurrence-free survival (defined as evidence of metastases or death from any cause; 71% for ART patients compared to 61% for RP only patients) with the use of ART compared to RP only at more than 12 years of follow-up. These findings did not replicate in EORTC 22911 at median 10.6 years of follow-up." AND... "Overall, the interpretation that ART leads to superior outcomes is difficult to make with certainty" AND... "Given these issues, the Panel concluded that it is not possible from the available evidence to address the question of the superiority of ART vs. SRT. A recent propensity score-matched, multi-institutional analysis has attempted to address this issue, reporting no difference in biochemical recurrence-free survival rates at 60 months between pT3N0 patients administered RT adjuvantly compared to those observed and treated with early SRT (with PSA ≤ 0.5 ng/ml)." Sounds to me like they are saying - We are statistically certain ART reduces the incidence of BCR but cannot find REPLICABLE studies that demonstrate better overall survival rates or even lower rates of metastic disease for ART patients. ART, with its wide range of long term side effects, does significantly reduce the occurrence of BCR but there seems to be little statistical evidence that long term survival, PCa Specific survival, or even clinical progression is reduced by the use of ART.

Posts.Content: "I would like to research the 3 month PSA post RALP, metrics and or determine my risk profile for Biochem return, elevated PSA metrics and plan accordingly." Not Possible! My 6-week post-RALP PSA was 0.021 and 19-week was 0.018 - all the nomograms give me a 71% chance of NO BCR in 5-years and 54% chance of NO BCR in 10-years. HOW do I plan for anything when there is 50-50 (approximately) probability of bio-chemical recurrence in the next 10-years? Near as I can tell - we post-RALP survivors just have to learn to live with the uncertainty of a 3-month and later on (IF we are lucky) a 6-month PSA testing cycle with all the anxiety that brings. I can play around with the nomogram inputs and try different 'what-if' scenarios but the bottom line seems, at least for me, to keep coming back to a half & half chance I will experience a biochemical recurrence before I am 80-years old. SO - my planning is to learn to accept the uncertainty and learn to reduce the semi-annual anxiety brought on by the PSA test cycle. Another part of my plan is to remember that radiotherapy technology is advancing at a phenomenal rate. Delivery methods are improving and side effects are diminishing. I plan to avoid radiotherapy for a few more years and then receive 75-Gy in 5 hypofractions with NO side effects while sipping a freshly brewed cupa' Columbia roasted coffee! AND - I always keep in the front of the discussion the fact that ALL the nomograms say I have less than a 2% chance of dying from PCa or metastatic disease in the next 15-years IF I aggressively treat any BCR.

AgeInfo.Phrase: anything when there is 50 50  approximately  probability of bio chemical
biochemical recurrence before I am 80 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Content: "7. Finally: Kaiser, where we have our coverage, refused to send out my samples for OncotypeDX. I'd heard they were notoriously tight-fisted when it came to these things, even though Medicare will pay for it. So either I cough up the $4K myself, or leave Kaiser during open enrollment in November and buy a likely quite expensive supplemental policy myself. I just turned 65 in November and must admit to not knowing too much about how all this works. " I chose a Plan F $0 deductible Medicare supplemental from Florida Blue. It costs me $212 per month which FIXES my cost, over and above my regular medicare premiums, at $2,544 per year. I've been thru two rather expensive cardiac events, knee treatments, and RALP in the last three years and have not paid a penny more than the $212 monthly supplemental premium. And, Florida Blue has not questioned a single charge, as long as Medicare paid the primary coverage. There is considerable question about the 2020 status of Plan F. It appears, at this time, that current Plan F subscribers will be able to maintain the plan AND those who are eligible for Plan F in 2019 but not yet signed up for it will be able to purchase Plan F in 2020 but those just becoming Medicare eligible in 2020 will not be able to purchase Plan F. OR - maybe something else will happen?

Posts.Content: "2- PSA test came back at 2.0 back in 12/2017 06/18/2018 = 2.62 09/05/2018 = 2.28 01/03/2018 = 3.12 01/07/2018 - 3.23" those dates are confusing - are they accurately posted? If so your PSA dropped 19% Early January 2018 too Early June 2018. That was followed by another drop of 13% from early January to early September 2018. That significant and rapid decline in PSA value does not sound like PCa but rather a prostate infection or ???. I've posted a lot of stuff about PIRADS 3 (my specifications) but in summary - about 70% of men with a PIRADS 3 are found not to have clinically significant PCa upon biopsy or surgery. The free PSA number is also getting high enough it too indicates a low probability of no clinically significant PCa (free PSA 20% to 25% about a 1 in 6 chance (16%) of having significant PCa), which is quite similar to the PIRAD s assessment. In May 2018, before I started this PCa adventure, I was very negative about prostate biopsy and had lots of "good" reason to resist getting one. My opinion now is the 12-core TRUS biopsy is very low risk and if done under Propofil is not a bit unpleasant or uncomfortable. The biopsy cannot tell you there is NO PCa (it misses about half?) but it can confirm there is PCa and help you decide about the appropriate next steps. If you really want to get confirmation then a biopsy might be a good idea but I would be looking at another PSA test in 6-months to see which trend your PSA is taking. IF - the dates on those PSA scores are not displayed correctly - then some of my ramblings here are of little value.

Posts.Title: New to this whole thing

Posts.Content: Propofol! In last 15-years I've had two endoscopies, three colonoscopies, a cardiac conversion, and prostate biopsy under the divine sedation of Propofol (Diprivan). Out like a light for five to 30-minutes and then suddenly awake and it's all over with no memory, pain, or agitation. I can think of no reason to have those somewhat unpleasant procedures done while fully conscious. As far as taking action now - I too am a action person who makes extensive decision trees prior to major life events, or even some minor ones. What to do, after the DRE, MRI, 4KScore, Free PSA tests was driving me crazy, literally CRAZY! I couldn't sleep, I could not concentrate, and found myself obsessing over diagnosis probabilities and treatment modalities. My MO hit me over the head several times and smacked me in the face once with "I've done this thousands of times, I've helped men down this road many times a month for over 25-years and really do know what I am doing. SO - please let me guide you as we get more information." He stressed that NO Decisions of any kind were necessary, in fact would not be appropriate, prior to getting the biopsy information back. He then stressed "I've never lost a patient, EVER, due to being cautious and taking our time to make an informed decision." He worked hard to make sure that I could talk with him as much as I wished after the biopsy as we then formulated a plan to deal with the biopsy results. He also told me that I would probably want to talk with other medical professionals about the biopsy results, e.g radiation guys, maybe HIFU proponents, and even, hopefully, active surveillance advocates. His main takeaway was that PCa treatment is complex and can take many unexpected twists and turns. All we, the patient, can do is take one more step with the one more bit of information we gain. Step -by- Step without looking too far into the future. It is a hard lesson - to take this journey step by step, but, at least in my case with my mental attitude, looking too far into the future is counter productive. And, I did learn that my MO really did anticipate ALL my questions and concerns and provided almost all the information I wanted and needed without me asking for it.

Posts.Title: Diagnosis question

Posts.Content: The most important thing you can do - ASK Questions - here and at the doctors office. I had a constantly increasing PSA score from 2004 until my prostatectomy in August 2018. My internist in May 2018 convinced me to pay attention and learn more about the disease and what I needed to do. Back then, late May when I first logged into this forum, I was the typical over educated "know it all" who really knew almost nothing and what I did know was mis-leading. The brothers here were patient and then aggressive about answering my questions, prodding me to take action, and forcing me to confront my disease. I am quite certain that without this forums guidance and prompting I would have not moved as quickly to rid my body of the cancer. Ask for help - debate - question - read - learn and let us help you move forward. No question or concern you might have is off limits, too simple, or too obvious. If you don't have the answers or information you want - ask for it!

Posts.Title: All alone with no support

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MIKEinCNY Thank you its a lot to take in. But how do I know its only in the prostate? They said stage T2b but that was just from the core samples I haven't had any other tests yet. That was the hardest part for me during the diagnosis phase of my PCa adventure. The uncertainty, the multiple options and decision points. You just have to live with uncertainty and making decisions with limited information. You can read all the studies, use the nomograms, calculate the odds but eventually you have to make a choice and it is you and only you who can make that choice. Do to the uncertainty of my diagnosis (there was way too much PSA given the identified size of the prostate and the suspected tumor so something was amisss) I chose the certainty of a RALP and the clear identification of the pathology post surgery. I have previously described (in other threads here) my mind set and confusion prior to the surgery and the clarity and reduction of my mental stress post surgery. All that uncertainly weighted heavily on my mind and spirits until the pathologist gave me a specific diagnosis of measured and weighed tissue. All you can do at this point is read, ask questions, and try to remember that 99% of men with G7 PCa are still alive and well after 10-years. The disease is treatable and manageable but knowing that only makes it a little easier to deal with the day to day anxiety as you wait for treatment options and decisions.

MF -Don't Know -Don't Know - 81mg Asprin once a day, strong IPA beer once a day, 24-ounces strong black coffee all day My CK levels (Creatine Kinase) level has varied between 600 and 1,100 for the last 15+ years (normal is ~20 to ~200?) . My cardiologist needs to find a baseline value, prior to statin regimen, because he monitors CK levels in his statin patients. He will not start me on any statin until he understands my CK measures.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: Does anyone have any experience with starting a statin regimen in the middle of a series of ultrasensitive PSA tests? I am confused about the interaction of statins and PSA, testosterone, androgen receptors, etc! I've reviewed several studies that seem to contradict each other and can find no recent threads on this forum about statins. The following article published by the Prostate Cancer Foundation seems to link statins with all kinds of prostate cancer and PSA effects: https://www.pcf.org/news/statins-pro...-magic-bullet/ A recent cardic stress test with radionuclide study found several "minor" blockages in my ventricular muscle blood flow. I am almost always asymptomatic for heart problems. Now my new cardiologist wants to put me on a statin regimen to reduce my cholesterol and thus reduce the plaque in those small heart blood vessels. I am reluctant to start down the statin path because my Total Cholesterol last spring was 176, HDL was 56, LDL was 74 and has been in that same range for at least 15-years. All my previous internists and cardiologists told me those were almost "optimum" cholesterol values for a semi-geriatric subject. This new (to me) cardiologist just told me that any LDL value over 70 in a patient with imaging results showing even minor blockages needs to have their LDL reduced to minimize the arterial plaque and significantly reduce the risk of stroke or myocardial infarction. My four month post RALP µPSA blood draw will be just after the first of the year. Should I wait until after that blood draw to start the statins? I don't know which statin I will be taking because my CK values have been three to five times normal for the last 10-years (600 to 1100). The cardiologist needs to determine why and what those values mean before starting the statins because CK is used to monitor statin toxicity. A little background detail: I am asymptomatic about 99.9% of the time. I ride my bicycle six or more hours a week with an average heart rate over 135 and can easily keep my heart over 155 for 30-minutes at a time. I've been riding that way since I was a teenager. BUT - I have a long history of rapid heart rates (HR > 160 at rest and >210 while exercising), sudden short lived hypertension (BP > 180/95), and irregular heart rythms (AFib or SVT depending on who is interpreting the data). Those events are annoying but until recently were of little concern. In October 2018 I experienced tachycardia, hypertension, and irregular rhythms almost continually for four days. I did go for a longish bike ride during the event and the sypmtoms vanished during my ride but returned a few hours after I cooled off. I partially "grayed out" making lunch the 4th-day so made my way to the ER where they diagnosed SVT wave form and injected lopressor, which immediately returned my heart to normal condition. Subsequent studies have identified "minor" blockages in some of the smaller ventricle blood vessels and a "2nd pathway" for the ventricle nerve signal that causes contraction. None of this is a surprise because the same things were identified in 2004 at which time my cardiologist, a fellow runner and bicycle rider, told me not to worry about it and to just live with the occasional cardiac events. He did say if those events lasted more than 48-hours to seek medical help - so I did, which resulted in the afore mentioned stress test.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: The most important thing you can do - ASK Questions - here and at the doctors office. I had a constantly increasing PSA score from 2004 until my prostatectomy in August 2018. My internist in May 2018 convinced me to pay attention and learn more about the disease and what I needed to do. Back then, late May when I first logged into this forum, I was the typical over educated "know it all" who really knew almost nothing and what I did know was mis-leading. The brothers here were patient and then aggressive about answering my questions, prodding me to take action, and forcing me to confront my disease. I am quite certain that without this forums guidance and prompting I would have not moved as quickly to rid my body of the cancer. Ask for help - debate - question - read - learn and let us help you move forward. No question or concern you might have is off limits, too simple, or too obvious. If you don't have the answers or information you want - ask for it!

Posts.Title: All alone with no support

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MIKEinCNY Thank you its a lot to take in. But how do I know its only in the prostate? They said stage T2b but that was just from the core samples I haven't had any other tests yet. That was the hardest part for me during the diagnosis phase of my PCa adventure. The uncertainty, the multiple options and decision points. You just have to live with uncertainty and making decisions with limited information. You can read all the studies, use the nomograms, calculate the odds but eventually you have to make a choice and it is you and only you who can make that choice. Do to the uncertainty of my diagnosis (there was way too much PSA given the identified size of the prostate and the suspected tumor so something was amisss) I chose the certainty of a RALP and the clear identification of the pathology post surgery. I have previously described (in other threads here) my mind set and confusion prior to the surgery and the clarity and reduction of my mental stress post surgery. All that uncertainly weighted heavily on my mind and spirits until the pathologist gave me a specific diagnosis of measured and weighed tissue. All you can do at this point is read, ask questions, and try to remember that 99% of men with G7 PCa are still alive and well after 10-years. The disease is treatable and manageable but knowing that only makes it a little easier to deal with the day to day anxiety as you wait for treatment options and decisions.

Posts.Title: All alone with no support

Posts.Content: "Are you worried about a statin "artificially" lowering your PSA? " I guess that is my concern? The surgeon who performed the RALP was pessimistic about my long term BCR prognosis due to SM+ and EPE+. At the time we talked about the 0.021 in mid-October he was concerned it would show some increase by January 2019. I am going to see my medical oncologist Jan 9 to review the ultrasensitive PSA for which I will have a blood draw in early January. The oncologist told me, prior to the RALP but after he did the biopsy, he thought there would be less than a 25% chance I would need adjuvant or salvage radiation post surgery. I don't want to get in the situation that the January 2019 µPSA is ~0.02? (not decreased since the early October test) and either doc worries the statin is holding the PSA level down and the January value is really an increase. As you suggest - it seems like waiting another 3-weeks to start the statin regimen is a reasonable idea. I have always heard bad words and feelings about statins (mother hated hers!) and wonder if they really have the side effects, about which I have heard and read so much.
