Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: Does anyone have any experience with starting a statin regimen in the middle of a series of ultrasensitive PSA tests? I am confused about the interaction of statins and PSA, testosterone, androgen receptors, etc! I've reviewed several studies that seem to contradict each other and can find no recent threads on this forum about statins. The following article published by the Prostate Cancer Foundation seems to link statins with all kinds of prostate cancer and PSA effects: https://www.pcf.org/news/statins-pro...-magic-bullet/ A recent cardic stress test with radionuclide study found several "minor" blockages in my ventricular muscle blood flow. I am almost always asymptomatic for heart problems. Now my new cardiologist wants to put me on a statin regimen to reduce my cholesterol and thus reduce the plaque in those small heart blood vessels. I am reluctant to start down the statin path because my Total Cholesterol last spring was 176, HDL was 56, LDL was 74 and has been in that same range for at least 15-years. All my previous internists and cardiologists told me those were almost "optimum" cholesterol values for a semi-geriatric subject. This new (to me) cardiologist just told me that any LDL value over 70 in a patient with imaging results showing even minor blockages needs to have their LDL reduced to minimize the arterial plaque and significantly reduce the risk of stroke or myocardial infarction. My four month post RALP µPSA blood draw will be just after the first of the year. Should I wait until after that blood draw to start the statins? I don't know which statin I will be taking because my CK values have been three to five times normal for the last 10-years (600 to 1100). The cardiologist needs to determine why and what those values mean before starting the statins because CK is used to monitor statin toxicity. A little background detail: I am asymptomatic about 99.9% of the time. I ride my bicycle six or more hours a week with an average heart rate over 135 and can easily keep my heart over 155 for 30-minutes at a time. I've been riding that way since I was a teenager. BUT - I have a long history of rapid heart rates (HR > 160 at rest and >210 while exercising), sudden short lived hypertension (BP > 180/95), and irregular heart rythms (AFib or SVT depending on who is interpreting the data). Those events are annoying but until recently were of little concern. In October 2018 I experienced tachycardia, hypertension, and irregular rhythms almost continually for four days. I did go for a longish bike ride during the event and the sypmtoms vanished during my ride but returned a few hours after I cooled off. I partially "grayed out" making lunch the 4th-day so made my way to the ER where they diagnosed SVT wave form and injected lopressor, which immediately returned my heart to normal condition. Subsequent studies have identified "minor" blockages in some of the smaller ventricle blood vessels and a "2nd pathway" for the ventricle nerve signal that causes contraction. None of this is a surprise because the same things were identified in 2004 at which time my cardiologist, a fellow runner and bicycle rider, told me not to worry about it and to just live with the occasional cardiac events. He did say if those events lasted more than 48-hours to seek medical help - so I did, which resulted in the afore mentioned stress test.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: A couple observations. Everything I read says PSA can vary 20% test to test (assuming it is always the same lab and same test) so going from 4.1 to 4.4 is not so worrisome if it is not the beginning of a trend. (0.3 increase is only a 7% increase). A six-month increase of 0.3 would give a doubling time of 6.8 years (off the 4.1 base) which is also not so worrisome. My PSA went from 4.0 to 5.8 back to 4.5 and back to 5.6 over a period of three years. FIVE years later my PSA was 9.2 and I was diagnosed with G7 (3+4) and EPE. Do you have more PSA history to show that increase of 0.3 is part of a trend? My urologist cautioned me that a 3T mpMRI is very good at finding major PCa tumors but not so good at finding smaller or less aggressive ones. I would not think a "clear" MRI would offer much peace of mind. You can see from my signature that my 3T mpMRI: - understated the tumor size by a factor of 20 - missed the extra-prostatetic extension - understated the prostate size by a factor of 2 thus leading to a PSA density measure over twice what it actually was - missed ALL the G7 tissue in the right lobe My summary for you is: - you need at least one more PSA test to get a trend line - you've had a negative biopsy - wait another three-months for another PSA Even with my G7 biopsy results - the RALP surgeon (1,600 procedures) said I could easily wait three or four months to have the prostate removed. Take your time and gather more data.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: Have not had a biopsy yet (next week I hope) but significant probability there will be a PCa treatment in my future. My wife tried to press the urologist about possible treatments (see note at end for the backstory on her real concern!). Urologist said that his most likely recommendation would be radiation rather than surgery. - I will be 71 next week with a life expectancy of 17 - 20 years - His opinion is that radiation has fewer significant side effects for us guys over 70 - Survival rates for radiation -vs- surgery at 15-years is identical - 20-year survival rate is marginally better for surgery - Surgery does not have enough potential positive lifespan benefits to outweigh near term negative impacts of surgery - He does not believe that a 71-year old in good health and physically fit/active is at any higher risk for surgical or anesthetic complication than a 55-year old I then asked about seeds -vs- external beam - My very small 18cc prostate is at the low end of the size where the seed radiation may damage tissue (bladder) external to the prostate - New robotic and focused external beams have even fewer side effects Dr. Blitz continually reminded me during this conversation: - 2 out of 3 men with my symptoms and test results only need active survellence - Treatment mode will depend on biopsy results - Treatment mode will be decided by joint consultation with: - Me - Wife - Medical Oncologist - Radiation Oncologist - Surgeon (Him) At this time, with what we know, there is no rush to judgement. I need to quit thinking so far ahead and concentrate on just the next step - THE BIOPSY! Wife Back Story: I am trying to buy a Melges MC Scow, which is a 16-foot serious racing sailboat. It is designed for one or two people and requires the operator to put their feet under straps on the centerline and lean back, way back, outside the boat to keep the boat on a 17 degree heel when sailing hard upwind in more than 10-knots. It is a strenuous exercise, which I have been doing for 35+ years, but she was very worried that I would buy the boat, have my gut cut open, and then not be able to sail the boat for six months to a year... she now needs a new reason to stop the purchase!

Posts.Title: Surgery -or- Radiation and Seeds -vs-External Beam

Posts.Content: I spent an hour with my selected surgeon today talking about RALP. He is friendly, open, explains things clearly and obviously wants me to understand and make the correct decision. He convinced me that RALP was the correct choice. He has done 1,600 RALP procedures as well as thousands of other urogenital robotic laparoscopic procedures. He says his 24-month incontinence rate, (defined as more than 2 dribble drops per event, more than twice a day) is less than 4%. He was also straight up about the left nerve will be sacrificed due to the 100% left lobe involvement. He thinks there is greater than a 50% chance of serious ED. My wife so so impressed that she signed me up for RALP next Thursday, Aug 23. And, I was greatly relieved to have made that decision. ... I think wife may have been pleased with the 50% ED number? BUT... I then spent 90+ minutes on the phone with a radiation oncologist who also had my mpMRi and biopsy results as well as all my lab/blood results. He was even more friendly and willing to share information in a form, (very technical and numeric), that I could easily grasp. We discussed much of the recent research comparing EBRT, Brachy, RP results. He pointed out that my numbers (T1c, Stage II, 100% positive left lobe cores 3 of which were 3+3 and 3 were 3+4 with one 100% 3+4 and one 60% 3+4) indicate at least a 35% probability of extra capsular extension (ECE). That number agrees with what Memorial Sloan Kettering website shows. My medical urologist (retired knife guy) discussed my path report with me last Friday and said he felt there was a 50% probability of ECE. Radiation guy says that means there is at least a 30% chance I will need some radiation therapy after the RP because that ECE will guarantee my PSA will not stay at 0.01 as everyone wants. Radiation guy also pointed out (strongly and vividly), that RP means the trans-prostate urethra is removed, the bladder pulleed down into the area voided by the prostate removal and then reconnected to the lower urethra. That is all normal delicate but easily done surgery. However! that means the lower part of the bladder is now over the prostate bed and will be heavily radiated with salvage radiation if the RP did not get all the cancer. The radiation guy is recommending 3-month oral ADT, EBRT (proton), and LDR brachytherapy to guarantee no biochemical recurrence. He did say the ADT benefit is marginal but, in his experience, oral ADT for just 3-months has minimal adverse side effects so he recommends it. I can stop the oral ADT if it becomes too upsetting to my wife or I. If I have a 30% chance of needing radiation AFTER the RP- then why not just start with the radiation and skip the surgery? Radiation guy claims less than 2% BCR (within prostate) at 10-years with a combination of EBRT & LDR brachy. Radiation guy makes a lot of sense to me but the RALP seems to be the safe and secure way to go with only a 1:3 chance of needing the additional radiation therapy. My wife is leaning towards the RP. ??

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate OTS, If you go with RT, the triple play of ADT, EBRT and BBT (brachy boost) appears to have some really good results. Actually, with BBT involved, the ADT may not make a difference. And (damn - more complications ) the boost can come from LDR-BT, HDR-BT, or SBRT. SBRT (Cyberknife or TrueBeam) was designed to supply the same Gy's as HDR-BT, without being invasive. All three of these boost treatments are available, and perhaps you should ask why this RO is preferring one type over the other two. We did discuss HDR-BT and SBRT in the context of doing that in addition to ADT and EBRT. I caught a little of what he said but the man took me at my word "give me the details, all the details, and the numbers to support those details" and he did ... for 90-minutes. Seldom am I overwhelmed when discussing very technical material but at that point, 70-minutes in, he had earned my trust and I let my mind relax a bit as he discussed HDR-BT and SBRT. He did a bit of them at other institutions and his facility can offer them but he prefers LDR . He gave me his personal cell number and his e-mail address and said to call or e-mail anytime. Already this evening, just 3-hours after I got off the phone, he has sent me three very technical and recent papers about combined RT, QOL, and long term toxicity. He seems genuinely interested in educating me and helping me make the right decision. Looks to be early '50s and has a strong academic and research background as well as clinical experience and leadership roles at some big cancer facilities.

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MIKEinCNY Thank you its a lot to take in. But how do I know its only in the prostate? They said stage T2b but that was just from the core samples I haven't had any other tests yet. That was the hardest part for me during the diagnosis phase of my PCa adventure. The uncertainty, the multiple options and decision points. You just have to live with uncertainty and making decisions with limited information. You can read all the studies, use the nomograms, calculate the odds but eventually you have to make a choice and it is you and only you who can make that choice. Do to the uncertainty of my diagnosis (there was way too much PSA given the identified size of the prostate and the suspected tumor so something was amisss) I chose the certainty of a RALP and the clear identification of the pathology post surgery. I have previously described (in other threads here) my mind set and confusion prior to the surgery and the clarity and reduction of my mental stress post surgery. All that uncertainly weighted heavily on my mind and spirits until the pathologist gave me a specific diagnosis of measured and weighed tissue. All you can do at this point is read, ask questions, and try to remember that 99% of men with G7 PCa are still alive and well after 10-years. The disease is treatable and manageable but knowing that only makes it a little easier to deal with the day to day anxiety as you wait for treatment options and decisions.

Posts.Title: All alone with no support

Posts.Content: I've described my coping process in other threads here but will try to briefly cover MY way of dealing with the fundamental life changes you describe. I do understand a bit of your anguish about the many changes occurring in short order. For me, and my wife of 44-years: - sudden onset of seemingly serious heart problems after years of being told those problems would never be important - now need to take medicine to control heart rhythms, which adversely affects ALL my athletic endeavors - wife suffered two life threatening and debilitating bicycle accidents which now prevent her from riding with me, which has been a very important part of our life for over 35-years - wife went thru five serious orthopedic surgeries in three years in attempt to repair shoulder, arm, hip, leg with not so good results - move from San Diego to SW Florida and all the changes (good and bad) that entails - owning a home for the first time in 18-years (had been living on our sailboat since mid-2000) - termination of relationship with sister after death of our parents and her theft of several hundred K dollars from the estate (she was executrix) - wife retired from a job she loved and had worked at for 35-years and found she really missed the work and friends (now 2,800 miles distant) My wife and I have been a strong team since 1974. We've gone thru a lot of counseling as a couple and as individuals. I did graduate work in counseling and she had some undergraduate classes in the same while studying to be a speech therapist and special ed teacher. Our prior experiences were not sufficient to get us through the trauma, physical and mental of all the changes, gravely exacerbated by my PCa diagnosis and treatment, since 2014. I was fortunate to find a Ph.D counselor with vast experience dealing with geriatric patients (I am 71 and wife is 63) experiencing fundamental changes due to physical and mental situations. She is in her mid-50s and is personally aware of many of the situations we here deal with. And, her 78-year old father has been battling PCa for 10-years (RP, ADT, radiation, metastatic disease) so she really understands the PCa aspects of our problems. She is the primary care giver for her father and has also counselled hundreds of other PCa men. While I was in the pre-RP, post-RP, and 'wait for the first post-RP µPSA' phase of my PCa journey I talked with her twice a week for a hour each time. I did not have to explain things - I could just vent with no concern about her feelings or judgement. That in itself was of great value but she was able to ask questions and turn around my statements and thoughts to allow me to understand what I was really worried about and what I really wanted to do. Additionally, due to her personal experience with her father, and with many dozen other PCa men, she had a lot of practical advice and was quite outspoken in offering it. And, she arranged for my wife and I to meet with a couples therapist who specializes in medical counselling and practical strategies for dealing with traumatic medical issues. I did not appreciate the degree of PTSD my wife was suffering after the two horrible bike accidents (2014 - she had to walk two miles out of a mountain canyon with a broken arm, dislocated shoulder, and severe concussion & 2016 she was unconscious for 6-days). That accident built on the PTSD she suffered 30-years ago when she had to walk 3-miles out of the Mt. Rainier woods with a broken illiac crest, broken forearm, and concussion. I was shocked at how little I understood where my wife was coming from and why she was being so cold about my whole PCa journey. The couples therapist was able to let wife and I understand and appreciate the others perspective on my PCa. I just did not know how freaked out the wife was about my disease. She was unable to talk about it until after the RP and was unable to say the word "cancer" until months after we began sessions with the counselor. My therapist also convinced me to try some anti-depressants and some anti-anxiety medication which, after a short while, allowed me to develop and practice new thought processes. I now understand that: - PCa is a 'rest of my lifetime' disease and will always be lurking in the background. - I am doing everything possible to manage my PCa - I will take the required next steps, whatever they are, if I suffer BCR - I can't do anything more than I am now doing - I cannot change my place in life - I must actively find things to do that give my life purpose and meaning - I discuss all my fears and worries with the wife who can now accept that I do have cancer

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Also consider the treatment options and outcomes if you encounter BCR after RT as your primary treatment. See this summary article provided by ASA in another thread (You omitted your age in your signature, but keep in mind that the newer the RT technique, the shorter the follow-up period studied.) That said, I'm not trying to dissuade you from RT, which is making big strides; just suggesting you continue to examine all alternative and possibilities. I know my age - how come everyone else doesn't? Thanks for pointing that out - I've now added it in... dumb oversight! Age 71 at end of July - every life expectancy calculator gives more than 80% chance of living at least another 20-years. I am in otherwise great health and am very active mentally and physically. I want three things from the treatment - get it done and not have to worry about future BCR or additional therapy - minimize bowel and other GI side effects - maximize possibility of another 10-years hard bicycle riding and sailing I am really leaning toward the combined radiation therapy but will do a bit more study of the recent research comparing RALP with EBRT+LDR brachytherapy The surgeon and the radiation guy both said I could safely take a month or six-weeks to make the decision but should get it done/started by mid-October at the latest Radiation place is 45-miles / 60-minutes drive one way from home. I don't look forward to doing that 5-days a week for nine or more weeks. But, looking at the next 20-years (1,000+ weeks), I guess I am just being short sighted and lazy when I let that time issue influence my decision.

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark H. Hi, I don't even know if it is possible to have a 9.5 without cancer, but I am a nervous wreck. It would seem that one should not delay action and while I think a PC3 test and imaging might be useful, would it not be safest to have an ASAP removal of my prostate and lymph nodes? I really don't care if I have ED, but I fear I have waited to long. Will the doctor insist on a full battery of tests before such a procedure? Also, Id appreciate any feed back on MRI vs. color Doppler and whether or not both would compliment each other? My August 2103 PSa was 5.8 and had been fluctuating up and down between 4.0 and 5.8 for about 3.5 years. My family doc/board certified Internist felt that it was nothing to be concerned about so I neglected all testing until my new internist in May 2018 insisted on a PSA test. It came back 9.2 which was a shock so I immediately consulted with a urologist who did not seem very concerned. He made me wait another month to get a 2nd PSA test which came back 10.2 I was really shocked but my urologist (26-years in practice and is using state of the art everything) said to stay calm and not be disturbed. My DRE was normal but my Free PSA was quite low. Again, he said he has hundreds of patients with higher PSA values who have had those high scores for years. They've had many biopsies with no PCa detected. He says "lots of men are leakers - they secrete unusual amounts of PSA into their blood but we never find a cancer. " He concluded "I've never lost a patient to a fast moving aggressive PCa by being cautious and conservative." My 3T mpMRI identified a 0.3cc PIRADS-3 lesion and my 4KScore gives me a 34% chance of a Gleason 7 or greater tumor when the biopsy samples are examined. However, it has been 30-days since those findings and I am still waiting for that biopsy to be scheduled. Two days ago my urologist told me that there is no concern about rushing the biopsy, and even with my rather dire blood tests, he is comfortable waiting another 30-days to do the biopsy so a nasty little wound on my ankle can heal. Again, he concluded by telling me that very little in the PCa diagnosis or treatment world moves quickly and there is seldom any need to rush anything. Summary - it appears it will be more than 90-days from the time I got a PSA 9.2 score to when my highly experienced urologist does the biopsy - NO NEED TO RUSH!

Summary - it appears it will be more than 90-days from the time I got a PSA 9.2 score to when my highly experienced urologist does the biopsy - NO NEED TO RUSH!

Posts.Title: How Bad is a PSA over 9?

Posts.Content: I've described my coping process in other threads here but will try to briefly cover MY way of dealing with the fundamental life changes you describe. I do understand a bit of your anguish about the many changes occurring in short order. For me, and my wife of 44-years: - sudden onset of seemingly serious heart problems after years of being told those problems would never be important - now need to take medicine to control heart rhythms, which adversely affects ALL my athletic endeavors - wife suffered two life threatening and debilitating bicycle accidents which now prevent her from riding with me, which has been a very important part of our life for over 35-years - wife went thru five serious orthopedic surgeries in three years in attempt to repair shoulder, arm, hip, leg with not so good results - move from San Diego to SW Florida and all the changes (good and bad) that entails - owning a home for the first time in 18-years (had been living on our sailboat since mid-2000) - termination of relationship with sister after death of our parents and her theft of several hundred K dollars from the estate (she was executrix) - wife retired from a job she loved and had worked at for 35-years and found she really missed the work and friends (now 2,800 miles distant) My wife and I have been a strong team since 1974. We've gone thru a lot of counseling as a couple and as individuals. I did graduate work in counseling and she had some undergraduate classes in the same while studying to be a speech therapist and special ed teacher. Our prior experiences were not sufficient to get us through the trauma, physical and mental of all the changes, gravely exacerbated by my PCa diagnosis and treatment, since 2014. I was fortunate to find a Ph.D counselor with vast experience dealing with geriatric patients (I am 71 and wife is 63) experiencing fundamental changes due to physical and mental situations. She is in her mid-50s and is personally aware of many of the situations we here deal with. And, her 78-year old father has been battling PCa for 10-years (RP, ADT, radiation, metastatic disease) so she really understands the PCa aspects of our problems. She is the primary care giver for her father and has also counselled hundreds of other PCa men. While I was in the pre-RP, post-RP, and 'wait for the first post-RP µPSA' phase of my PCa journey I talked with her twice a week for a hour each time. I did not have to explain things - I could just vent with no concern about her feelings or judgement. That in itself was of great value but she was able to ask questions and turn around my statements and thoughts to allow me to understand what I was really worried about and what I really wanted to do. Additionally, due to her personal experience with her father, and with many dozen other PCa men, she had a lot of practical advice and was quite outspoken in offering it. And, she arranged for my wife and I to meet with a couples therapist who specializes in medical counselling and practical strategies for dealing with traumatic medical issues. I did not appreciate the degree of PTSD my wife was suffering after the two horrible bike accidents (2014 - she had to walk two miles out of a mountain canyon with a broken arm, dislocated shoulder, and severe concussion & 2016 she was unconscious for 6-days). That accident built on the PTSD she suffered 30-years ago when she had to walk 3-miles out of the Mt. Rainier woods with a broken illiac crest, broken forearm, and concussion. I was shocked at how little I understood where my wife was coming from and why she was being so cold about my whole PCa journey. The couples therapist was able to let wife and I understand and appreciate the others perspective on my PCa. I just did not know how freaked out the wife was about my disease. She was unable to talk about it until after the RP and was unable to say the word "cancer" until months after we began sessions with the counselor. My therapist also convinced me to try some anti-depressants and some anti-anxiety medication which, after a short while, allowed me to develop and practice new thought processes. I now understand that: - PCa is a 'rest of my lifetime' disease and will always be lurking in the background. - I am doing everything possible to manage my PCa - I will take the required next steps, whatever they are, if I suffer BCR - I can't do anything more than I am now doing - I cannot change my place in life - I must actively find things to do that give my life purpose and meaning - I discuss all my fears and worries with the wife who can now accept that I do have cancer

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: I spent an hour with my selected surgeon today talking about RALP. He is friendly, open, explains things clearly and obviously wants me to understand and make the correct decision. He convinced me that RALP was the correct choice. He has done 1,600 RALP procedures as well as thousands of other urogenital robotic laparoscopic procedures. He says his 24-month incontinence rate, (defined as more than 2 dribble drops per event, more than twice a day) is less than 4%. He was also straight up about the left nerve will be sacrificed due to the 100% left lobe involvement. He thinks there is greater than a 50% chance of serious ED. My wife so so impressed that she signed me up for RALP next Thursday, Aug 23. And, I was greatly relieved to have made that decision. ... I think wife may have been pleased with the 50% ED number? BUT... I then spent 90+ minutes on the phone with a radiation oncologist who also had my mpMRi and biopsy results as well as all my lab/blood results. He was even more friendly and willing to share information in a form, (very technical and numeric), that I could easily grasp. We discussed much of the recent research comparing EBRT, Brachy, RP results. He pointed out that my numbers (T1c, Stage II, 100% positive left lobe cores 3 of which were 3+3 and 3 were 3+4 with one 100% 3+4 and one 60% 3+4) indicate at least a 35% probability of extra capsular extension (ECE). That number agrees with what Memorial Sloan Kettering website shows. My medical urologist (retired knife guy) discussed my path report with me last Friday and said he felt there was a 50% probability of ECE. Radiation guy says that means there is at least a 30% chance I will need some radiation therapy after the RP because that ECE will guarantee my PSA will not stay at 0.01 as everyone wants. Radiation guy also pointed out (strongly and vividly), that RP means the trans-prostate urethra is removed, the bladder pulleed down into the area voided by the prostate removal and then reconnected to the lower urethra. That is all normal delicate but easily done surgery. However! that means the lower part of the bladder is now over the prostate bed and will be heavily radiated with salvage radiation if the RP did not get all the cancer. The radiation guy is recommending 3-month oral ADT, EBRT (proton), and LDR brachytherapy to guarantee no biochemical recurrence. He did say the ADT benefit is marginal but, in his experience, oral ADT for just 3-months has minimal adverse side effects so he recommends it. I can stop the oral ADT if it becomes too upsetting to my wife or I. If I have a 30% chance of needing radiation AFTER the RP- then why not just start with the radiation and skip the surgery? Radiation guy claims less than 2% BCR (within prostate) at 10-years with a combination of EBRT & LDR brachy. Radiation guy makes a lot of sense to me but the RALP seems to be the safe and secure way to go with only a 1:3 chance of needing the additional radiation therapy. My wife is leaning towards the RP. ??

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate OTS, If you go with RT, the triple play of ADT, EBRT and BBT (brachy boost) appears to have some really good results. Actually, with BBT involved, the ADT may not make a difference. And (damn - more complications ) the boost can come from LDR-BT, HDR-BT, or SBRT. SBRT (Cyberknife or TrueBeam) was designed to supply the same Gy's as HDR-BT, without being invasive. All three of these boost treatments are available, and perhaps you should ask why this RO is preferring one type over the other two. We did discuss HDR-BT and SBRT in the context of doing that in addition to ADT and EBRT. I caught a little of what he said but the man took me at my word "give me the details, all the details, and the numbers to support those details" and he did ... for 90-minutes. Seldom am I overwhelmed when discussing very technical material but at that point, 70-minutes in, he had earned my trust and I let my mind relax a bit as he discussed HDR-BT and SBRT. He did a bit of them at other institutions and his facility can offer them but he prefers LDR . He gave me his personal cell number and his e-mail address and said to call or e-mail anytime. Already this evening, just 3-hours after I got off the phone, he has sent me three very technical and recent papers about combined RT, QOL, and long term toxicity. He seems genuinely interested in educating me and helping me make the right decision. Looks to be early '50s and has a strong academic and research background as well as clinical experience and leadership roles at some big cancer facilities.

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Thank you ALL for the words of encouragement and the sometimes necessary harsher words that forced me to first understand, and then accept my disease and diagnosis. I am quite certain that I would not have moved as quickly and with as much knowledge and understanding if ALL of you had not been here to guide me, encourage me, and when necessary push me along this inevitable path. I do hope my journey from denial in mid-May, to understanding in mid-July, to acceptance this week can help others who follow along. Going from the shock of "OMG - I have cancer" to "OMG I am going to be an impotent leaker" to "Oh - there is hope and a real possibility of several excellent long term outcomes" is painful and could only be accomplished with your help. So, now I hope my story, and all the others I read here, will help the next brother move along. A couple details about the surgery: - A Fleet Enema bowel prep is required at 8 PM the evening before the surgery - I was quite surprised that the RALP, as done by Dr. Ornstein & DaVinci, is a four-handed operation. He uses what his literature calls a "First Assistant" who handles two of the four Da Vinci arms and tools. The document I was given says the FA guides the non-cutting tools and manipulates all the robot settings and controls. The FA credentials ar RNFA, BSN, CNOR. Who Knew? - Clear liquid diet from 7 AM the day before the surgery, but this includes Crystal Lite (I drink a gallon a day), black coffee (another 1/2 gallon), and (I think) Beer - so that covers my three food groups! - I was surprised to see the pathology report will not be available for 5 to 7 business days after the surgery. He will call me with the results -I have a followup appointment scheduled 6-days after the surgery. His nurse said that almost all his patients my age and in good physical condition will have the catheter removed at that time and almost all have "pretty good" urninary control upon removal. I sure hope so! But, I must bring urinary pads or pull up diapers to that appointment. - Avoidance of coffee/caffeine and alcohol are two of the easiest ways to regain good urinary control early in the healing process. As I said I live on coffee during the day and the sun will not set if I don't have a beer to help it go down. - A big reason for scheduling the surgery ASAP was to get it done, and all the followup visits done before Thanksgiving when all the SnowBirds return to Naples, Ft Myers, Cape Coral here in SW Florida. The hospital is 61-miles from home and the surgeons primary office is 55-miles from home. We can make those trips in about 75 (or less) minutes June thru mid-November. By late December the time would exceed 90-minutes and by mid-January it might take over two hours to get from Punta Gorda to Naples. So, now the last followup at three months will be done by early December. July thru October I can get from our house to I-75 (8-miles) in about 10-minutes because most of the drive is on 55 or 60 mph Hwy 41 (The Tamiami Trail). December thru April the five miles on Hwy 41 takes half an hour due to the two-cycle backups at each of the four controlled intersections.

Posts.Title: What A Relief! Decision Made so on to the cure

Posts.Content: CT scan w/ and /wo contrast came back clear with "unremarkable" lymph nodes and "unremarkable" seminal vesicles. No evidence of metastasis in abdomen and pelvis. Bone Scan (Tc-99m labeled MDP) "no definitive evidence of malignancy" Met, today August 17, with my medical urologist to review scan and discuss probability of radiation therapy post RALP, which he now puts at less than 10%. RALP surgeon had told me that only 15% of his patients (1,600 RALP total) with my characteristics ever require any radiotherapy. Those two numbers gave me the confidence to fully commit to a RALP procedure Thursday August 23. I can now relax and have a life other than searching for medical and research literature that would help me decide surgery or radiation. It is done and on we go to surgery and the definitive cure! I asked my medical urologist, who retired from doing open prostatectomies (retropubic), about having the surgery just 20-days after the biopsy. He said he used to wait six-weeks BUT he said my surgeon has so much experience (1,600 RALP in the last 15-years) that the surgeons judgement is far superior to his or mine. Now the really scary part of waiting for the surgery is Nothing to eat after 7 AM Wednesday but the surgery is scheduled (time is tenative and will not be confirmed until Tuesday evening) for late Thursday morning. How in the world can a fat guy go that long without eating?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Frenchy Good question, Pratoman. I've been wondering myself why they all of a sudden are testing me with the ultra test. The last score was 0.010. Before they were testing me with the regular PSA and I was less than 0.1 . So I still don't have a valid explanation of why the ultra sensitive test now. Your post maybe clarifies this for me in that they are looking for the next threshold, if it ever happens. I am not sure I would act on a score of something close to 0.05. I remember reading somewhere there is fluctuation from day in these scores. One does not see this if the test is simply resulting in less than 0.1 . But if an ultra test, it does tend to add to the stress level it the result begins to inch up a bit, or fluctuate a bit. Here is a copy of a post I made in another thread - it might explain why the interest in Ultrasensitive PSA tests. The 3-month Ultrasensitive number appears to provide a lot of prognostic information about Biochemical Recurrence: Walsh book (4th edition) page 326 "ULTRASENSITIVE PSA TESTS" references a study done by a Walsh colleague at Hopkins, Dr. Lori Sokoll (professor of pathology and assistant director of clinical chemistry): 750 men 3-months post RP with PSA <0.1 were given ULTRASENSITIVE PSA tests and then monitored for 10-years. 14% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA < 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years 78% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA > 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years There was no report about the clinical symptoms or actual PSA level at 10-years I found a source document for Dr. Sokoll (Journal of Urology Feb 2016), which discusses the same topic but has a little different conclusion than found in the Walsh book. I am not sure if this is the research Walsh was describing but pub date and number of subjects is very similar to what is in the book. Biochemical recurrence-free rates 11 years after surgery were 86.1% (95% CI 83.2–89.0) for prostate specific antigen less than 0.01 ng/ml and 48.9% (95% CI 37.5–60.3) for prostate specific antigen 0.01 ng/ml or greater (p <0.0001). That says to me: An Ultrasensitive PSA < 0.01 had an 86% chance of no biochemical recurrence compared to only about 50% chance of no recurrence if the Ultrasensitive PSA =>.01. My 6-week test is October 9 and 3-months is just after Thanksgiving so I am particularly interested in this topic!

Posts.Title: Some questions about PSA

Posts.Content: CT scan w/ and /wo contrast came back clear with "unremarkable" lymph nodes and "unremarkable" seminal vesicles. No evidence of metastasis in abdomen and pelvis. Bone Scan (Tc-99m labeled MDP) "no definitive evidence of malignancy" Met, today August 17, with my medical urologist to review scan and discuss probability of radiation therapy post RALP, which he now puts at less than 10%. RALP surgeon had told me that only 15% of his patients (1,600 RALP total) with my characteristics ever require any radiotherapy. Those two numbers gave me the confidence to fully commit to a RALP procedure Thursday August 23. I can now relax and have a life other than searching for medical and research literature that would help me decide surgery or radiation. It is done and on we go to surgery and the definitive cure! I asked my medical urologist, who retired from doing open prostatectomies (retropubic), about having the surgery just 20-days after the biopsy. He said he used to wait six-weeks BUT he said my surgeon has so much experience (1,600 RALP in the last 15-years) that the surgeons judgement is far superior to his or mine. Now the really scary part of waiting for the surgery is Nothing to eat after 7 AM Wednesday but the surgery is scheduled (time is tenative and will not be confirmed until Tuesday evening) for late Thursday morning. How in the world can a fat guy go that long without eating?

Posts.Content: I have been very impressed with Dr. Barry Blitz at Florida Urology Physicians. He has been my primary urologist/oncologist for my entire PCa adventure. When we were discussing the biopsy he said his firm had a relationship with Johns Hopkins and frequently used Epstein as a 2nd opinion. He asked me if I wanted him to send my information to JH for review. 7451 Gladiolus Drive Suite A Fort Myers, FL 33908 (239) 689-8800

Posts.Title: Medical Oncologist recommendation for Southwest Florida

Posts.Content: Thank you ALL for the words of encouragement and the sometimes necessary harsher words that forced me to first understand, and then accept my disease and diagnosis. I am quite certain that I would not have moved as quickly and with as much knowledge and understanding if ALL of you had not been here to guide me, encourage me, and when necessary push me along this inevitable path. I do hope my journey from denial in mid-May, to understanding in mid-July, to acceptance this week can help others who follow along. Going from the shock of "OMG - I have cancer" to "OMG I am going to be an impotent leaker" to "Oh - there is hope and a real possibility of several excellent long term outcomes" is painful and could only be accomplished with your help. So, now I hope my story, and all the others I read here, will help the next brother move along. A couple details about the surgery: - A Fleet Enema bowel prep is required at 8 PM the evening before the surgery - I was quite surprised that the RALP, as done by Dr. Ornstein & DaVinci, is a four-handed operation. He uses what his literature calls a "First Assistant" who handles two of the four Da Vinci arms and tools. The document I was given says the FA guides the non-cutting tools and manipulates all the robot settings and controls. The FA credentials ar RNFA, BSN, CNOR. Who Knew? - Clear liquid diet from 7 AM the day before the surgery, but this includes Crystal Lite (I drink a gallon a day), black coffee (another 1/2 gallon), and (I think) Beer - so that covers my three food groups! - I was surprised to see the pathology report will not be available for 5 to 7 business days after the surgery. He will call me with the results -I have a followup appointment scheduled 6-days after the surgery. His nurse said that almost all his patients my age and in good physical condition will have the catheter removed at that time and almost all have "pretty good" urninary control upon removal. I sure hope so! But, I must bring urinary pads or pull up diapers to that appointment. - Avoidance of coffee/caffeine and alcohol are two of the easiest ways to regain good urinary control early in the healing process. As I said I live on coffee during the day and the sun will not set if I don't have a beer to help it go down. - A big reason for scheduling the surgery ASAP was to get it done, and all the followup visits done before Thanksgiving when all the SnowBirds return to Naples, Ft Myers, Cape Coral here in SW Florida. The hospital is 61-miles from home and the surgeons primary office is 55-miles from home. We can make those trips in about 75 (or less) minutes June thru mid-November. By late December the time would exceed 90-minutes and by mid-January it might take over two hours to get from Punta Gorda to Naples. So, now the last followup at three months will be done by early December. July thru October I can get from our house to I-75 (8-miles) in about 10-minutes because most of the drive is on 55 or 60 mph Hwy 41 (The Tamiami Trail). December thru April the five miles on Hwy 41 takes half an hour due to the two-cycle backups at each of the four controlled intersections.

Posts.Title: What A Relief! Decision Made so on to the cure

Posts.Content: My closest friend of "only" 51-years and I have a relationship similar to what you describe. He and I have skied, climbed, run, bicycled, windsurfed together all over North America for over half a century. We both have needed bi-lateral knee replacements, due to injuries incurred while engaged in all those fun activities, for more than 20-years. Five years ago he finally had a knee replaced while I chose to wait and see the results of his surgery and replacement. He suffered horrible complications, required an additional surgery, and eventually a 2nd total knee replacement because the first one failed in just three years. He now has far less mobility, but also much less pain, than he did before the initial surgery. He was in such constant, debilitating pain that his loss of mobility and three surgeries were worth the problems he has suffered because he can now walk and sleep without living under the adverse influence of narcotic pain medication. As a result - I have continued to defer my bi-lateral knee replacement. He and I discuss the issue on a regular basis and he continues to push me to have my knee replacements done. I am fully cognizant of my choices, biases, and other reasons for deferring my knee replacements. His experience is just one of many data points in my decision matrix. Just as is the very positive result my father experienced when he had both knees replaced at age 76 and as is the somewhat negative results a third mutual 50-year friend had with his Canadian knee replacement. I am an adult and can take full responsibility for my choices and decisions. I respect his choices and felt he could make none other than get rid of the knee that was ruining his life. I greatly appreciate all the conversations he and I have had about our knees but in the end - it is my decision and only I can make that decision! I actively seek his advice and counsel but I know I am the only person that can make the right choice for my life.

AgeInfo.Phrase: both knees replaced at age 76 and as is the somewhat

Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: This is an enhanced copy of a post I made on June 29 in another thread about "do I or don't I biopsy" The changes in my PSA levels increased slowly over a period of time where my age was similar to where you are now. Age 57 PSA 2.0 Age 63 PSA 4.0 Age 65 PSA 4.5 Age 66 PSA 5.6 ... and I kept putting off the biopsy.... SLOW rate of increase, Levels "almost" normal for my age, my internist was not concerned, "normal" DRE, worry about potential side effects, head in the sand... SO - Here I am currently 70, soon to be 71, and waiting to see when my urologist will schedule my FIRST biopsy. I have been going thru the same "should I - shouldn't I" thought process for the last 14-years and have always chosen to wait. At this time my PSA is 10.2, having doubled in a bit over six-years (or maybe 8-years if you take the first occurence of a PSA 5+ in November 2010). My Free PSA percentage is now 8.4%, which combined with my PSA score indicates a high probability of some form of PCa being present. When my PSA went from 9.2 in mid-May this year to 10.2 in mid-June I knew my waiting time was over. However, my very experienced urologist (claims more than 3,000 biopsies in the last 20-years) does not seem to have any sense of urgency, other than to insist I get the biopsy done when he tells me to, but certainly not before early August or at least two months after he first saw me with a PSA score of 9.2 at age 70. NOW - facing a significant probability of having a significant PCa I am not unhappy I chose the course I did. BUT; way back in 2010 when my PSA increased to from 2.0 to 5.8 over a 6+ year period, I wish I had learned as much as I know now! I also now understand that a negative biopsy just means the PCa was not found by that particular biopsy and, depending on future PSA values and MRI images, I may be experiencing additional biopsies as the years go by. I now, understand deep in my heart, that is life with high PSA values and I can now accept the need for ongoing testing. IF I had understood biopsies, statistics, treatments, and side effects, then I would probably have elected to have the first biopsy in 2011 or 2012 when my PSA stabilized at 5.6 to 5.8. My current urologist has given me confidence that a TRUS/12-core biopsy is a very low risk/low side effect procedure and with MRI guidance can yield important information to help plan the rest of my life. I had a 3T mpMRI (with contrast) on June 28 which my urologist recommended for two reasons: 1) It helps clarify the timing for the biopsy by defining number, size, and location of possible lesions/tumors 2) He can use the MRI images to more accurately select the 12-core TRUS biopsy sample locations, once he decides when to do the biopsy My urologist also drew blood this week for a 4KScore test which will also help him decide when to do the biopsy. I'll get the MRI results/analysis and 4KScore on July 5 and may have an entirely different opinion of my decision to wait 14-years!

Posts.Title: 4K test useful for deciding not to get biopsy?

Posts.Content: PSA - May 2014 - 2.1, Oct. 2015 - 3.4, April 2016 - 4.0, Oct. 2016 - 2.5, April 2017 - 2.9, Oct. 2017 - 3.4, May 2018 - 3.5, Oct. 2018 - 4.0 Looking at your worst case PSA velocity (Oct 2016 to Oct 2018 with a 1.5 increase in 24-months) and calculating the absolute change in PSA over time - the doubling time is 3.3-years, which is relatively short or indicative of a growing PSA source. But ... if we do a PSA Velocity from Oct 2015 to Oct 2016 (3.4 to 4.0) we get a doubling time of 17-years, which is suggestive of a slow growing PSA source. And... a third analysis says the PSA has not changed in the 30-months between April 2016 and October 2018, which confirms the PSA doubling time of 17-years and the G6 in 5% of the tissue. Most research says that PSA can vary 20% from test to test with no change to the underlying source. When I calculate the slope of the trend line (PSA score on Y-axis and elapsed months on X-axis) using each PSA test value and the prior TWO values I see an annual change in absolute PSA score ranging from negative 1.1 to plus 1.1. FOUR consecutive values show an annual PSA increase ranging from -0.6 to +0.7 FIVE consecutive values show an annual PSA increase ranging from -0.2 to +0.7 With the sharp decrease in PSA between April 2016 and October 2016, with the PSA score not again reaching it's April 2016 value until October 18 (30-months), it is impossible to develop a reasonable trend line that extends back more than two-years. The 5-test trendline which incorporates the data from October 2016 to October 2018 shows a doubling time of 3.6 years and an annual increase of 0.7. Both of those numbers are on the higher, "less good", side of the equation and would indicate to me that I do not want to wait another six-months for a biopsy. The 4-test trendline which incorporates the data from October 2016 to May 2018 shows a doubling time of 3.8 years and an annual increase of 0.7, which (from a statistical POV) confirms the 5-test slope ( Oct 2016 thru Oct 2018 ) is a logical continuation of the 4-test slope. Is it not possible to get a biopsy done on a fairly short notice in your home town? Can you postpone your Florida travel a couple weeks?

Posts.Title: Update - TIme for a Biopsy ???

Posts.Content: This is an enhanced copy of a post I made on June 29 in another thread about "do I or don't I biopsy" The changes in my PSA levels increased slowly over a period of time where my age was similar to where you are now. Age 57 PSA 2.0 Age 63 PSA 4.0 Age 65 PSA 4.5 Age 66 PSA 5.6 ... and I kept putting off the biopsy.... SLOW rate of increase, Levels "almost" normal for my age, my internist was not concerned, "normal" DRE, worry about potential side effects, head in the sand... SO - Here I am currently 70, soon to be 71, and waiting to see when my urologist will schedule my FIRST biopsy. I have been going thru the same "should I - shouldn't I" thought process for the last 14-years and have always chosen to wait. At this time my PSA is 10.2, having doubled in a bit over six-years (or maybe 8-years if you take the first occurence of a PSA 5+ in November 2010). My Free PSA percentage is now 8.4%, which combined with my PSA score indicates a high probability of some form of PCa being present. When my PSA went from 9.2 in mid-May this year to 10.2 in mid-June I knew my waiting time was over. However, my very experienced urologist (claims more than 3,000 biopsies in the last 20-years) does not seem to have any sense of urgency, other than to insist I get the biopsy done when he tells me to, but certainly not before early August or at least two months after he first saw me with a PSA score of 9.2 at age 70. NOW - facing a significant probability of having a significant PCa I am not unhappy I chose the course I did. BUT; way back in 2010 when my PSA increased to from 2.0 to 5.8 over a 6+ year period, I wish I had learned as much as I know now! I also now understand that a negative biopsy just means the PCa was not found by that particular biopsy and, depending on future PSA values and MRI images, I may be experiencing additional biopsies as the years go by. I now, understand deep in my heart, that is life with high PSA values and I can now accept the need for ongoing testing. IF I had understood biopsies, statistics, treatments, and side effects, then I would probably have elected to have the first biopsy in 2011 or 2012 when my PSA stabilized at 5.6 to 5.8. My current urologist has given me confidence that a TRUS/12-core biopsy is a very low risk/low side effect procedure and with MRI guidance can yield important information to help plan the rest of my life. I had a 3T mpMRI (with contrast) on June 28 which my urologist recommended for two reasons: 1) It helps clarify the timing for the biopsy by defining number, size, and location of possible lesions/tumors 2) He can use the MRI images to more accurately select the 12-core TRUS biopsy sample locations, once he decides when to do the biopsy My urologist also drew blood this week for a 4KScore test which will also help him decide when to do the biopsy. I'll get the MRI results/analysis and 4KScore on July 5 and may have an entirely different opinion of my decision to wait 14-years!

Posts.Title: 4K test useful for deciding not to get biopsy?

Posts.Content: "When the MRI came I was called in and explained that the prostate looks inflamed and there are "some modifications in some cells" and he doesn't know what to say." Are you certain that is what you were told: "some modifications in some cells? In my limited knowledge, an MRI does not work at the cellular level. My understanding is the MRI senses changes in the spin of protons as they relax from the intense magnetic field. The timing of the spin change varies depending on tissue type. The contrast media allows the differential uptake (diffusion) of the fluid depending on the tissue type. The computer and the radiologist can then interpret the timing and pattern of spin changes to "estimate" tissue type. What kind of MRI? - 3TmpMRI - with or without contrast? - with or without endorectal coil? Was the MRI specific to the prostate or generalized to the entire area around the prostate? There should be a formal report about the MRI interpretation including a PIRADS number - did you get one? - prostate size? - were modified cells (tissue?) in one region or multiple regions? Can you share the report details? Here are two excellent references if you want to learn more about MRI function, limitations, and utility for prostate problem diagnosis: https://www.livescience.com/39074-what-is-an-mri.html https://pubs.rsna.org/doi/pdf/10.1148/rg.2016150234

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, EPE is an adverse finding/prognostic factor in a RP path report. I believe major ones reported are: I am not sure EPE is that important for prognosis post RALP & SRT. Memorial Sloan Kettering nomogram probability of progression free life 6-years AFTER SRT (probability of NO BCR): Using MY numbers assume SRT (72Gy) and NO ADT at 0.2 ng/ml at 18-months post RALP with a 12-month doubling time and pre-RALP PSA of 10.2 69% with NO EPE and 68% with EPE and SM+ 56% with NO EPE and 58% with EPE and SM- If we assume 0.1 ng/ml as starting point for SRT (72 Gy & NO ADT) and 6-month PSA doubling time with 0.2 reached at 12-months the 6-year probability of NO BCR (NO Progression) is: 60% with EPE and 61% with NO EPE and SM+ 47% with EPE and 48% with NO EPE and SM-

Posts.Title: Combined ADT + RT after Surgery

Posts.Content: "Why post SRT? I thought we were discussing adjuvant vs. salvage RT after RP with adverse findings, such as EPE." His surgery was July 2018 - more than 6-months ago so is the current RT - Adjuvant or SRT? There is little, if any, evidence of biochemical recurrence or disease progression (PSA 0.06; 0.07; 0.1; 0.08 ) so what would the adjuvant therapy be treating? "The stats you posted are far from good. Best practice is to offer ART to men who are high risk post RT." I guess I am missing something - what makes him a high risk? MSK stats (not mine) show that IF he receives NO ADT but does receive SRT (which would be a higher Gy load ?) there is almost no difference in the probability of disease progression for a man with or without EPE. Why would results be any different for adjuvant with or without ADT? We can find research studies on many sides of this issue: Early Salvage vs Adjuvant Radiotherapy for High-Risk Prostate Cancer Rahul Tendulkar, MD: At least three randomized trials have examined the role of immediate postprostatectomy radiotherapy in patients with high-risk pathologic features, yet the optimal management remains controversial.[4-6] Two of these trials (Southwest Oncology Group [SWOG] 8794 and European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer 22911) included patients with a detectable postoperative PSA level, and thus the immediate radiotherapy arms comprised a mix of adjuvant and salvage radiotherapy.[4,5] Likewise, the observation arms included some patients with untreated residual disease, which likely resulted in worse outcomes than would have been seen if these patients had been excluded from randomization. Only the German trial (ARO 96-02) tested adjuvant radiation vs observation in a cohort of patients with undetectable PSA levels (< 0.1 ng/mL), and unfortunately this trial had the smallest sample size.[6] Interestingly, among the patients randomized to observation across all three trials, about half (46% to 54%) remained free of biochemical recurrence at 5 years, suggesting that adjuvant radiotherapy would have been unnecessary in a large proportion of patients despite their high-risk pathologic features. In summary, serial PSA testing with initiation of early salvage radiotherapy is an attractive treatment paradigm and should be considered for most men after radical prostatectomy. Because of the ability of serum PSA to detect low-volume prostate cancer recurrences, clinicians can better select those patients who are most likely to benefit from treatment. Likewise, up to half of men with high-risk features may be spared from potentially unnecessary adjuvant therapy and its associated costs and side effects. Until genomic profiling is proven to provide more personalized outcomes assessments, patients should be counseled about both approaches, with joint decision making based on a careful assessment of the risks and benefits of each treatment option. A more recent metastudy (Contemporary role of postoperative radiotherapy for prostate cancer Alan Dal Pra,corresponding author Matthew C. Abramowitz, Radka Stoyanova, and Alan Pollack June 2018 states: Adverse pathological factors after RP, such as positive surgical margins (+SM), extracapsular extension (ECE), or seminal vesicle invasion (SVI) increase the likelihood of disease recurrence. Three randomized clinical trials (RCT) have addressed the potential benefits of adjuvant (ART) versus delayed RT after RP for these patents... Taken together, these RCTs provide level I evidence for improved biochemical control without clear proof of benefit in long-term freedom from metastasis or survival for adjuvant therapy." As more research is done and genomics because more precise to each individual - the ART -vs- SRT decision will become easier and the added decision about ADT will also become more clear.

Posts.Title: Should I have a biopsy or wait 6 months to repeat the MRI

Posts.Content: Shocking or perhaps Disturbing Results for my particular numbers! I sure hope I am mis-understanding or mis-interpreting the results. MY 10-year Overall Survival with: Radical Prostatectomy 74% Conservative Treatment (Active Surveillance) 71% NO PCa diagnosis 77% The data above says that I only gain a 3% increase in overall survival probability at age 81 by submitting to an RP. OR - 32 out of 33 cases similar to mine will receive NO benefit in 10-years by proceeding to treatment compared to AS. Does that mean that in 11 out of 12 cases ( [71-77]/77 = ~8%) similar to mine that COMPLETE IGNORANCE of my PSA, and thus no treatment, would lead to NO PCa death by age 81? I guess that is why PSA testing after age 72 is not recommended? MY 15-year Overall Survival with: Radical Prostatectomy 48% Conservative Treatment (Active Surveillance) 43% NO PCa diagnosis 54% Does that mean IF I knew I had PCa (3+4) and did NO treatment (AS) I would be only ~20% more likely ( [43-54]/54 )to die in 15-years than if I had NO PCa at all? Does that mean that in 9 out of 10 cases ( [43-48]/43 ) similar to mine that AS would lead to NO PCa death by age 86 IF I knew I had (3+4) PCa? I guess a more optimistic way to interpret the data is that RP benefits are only realized in the long term, which in my case exceeds 15-years. To me, this shows why it is so important to consider one's overall health and medical status when deciding on PCa treatment modalities and strategies. Life expectancy is so critical when making these long term decisions. I still expect to fumble around on this earth for another 20-years so RP still makes sense to me.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic The normogram risks are for PCa-related events, not all causes. Here is text from the nonomgram using my specific pre-RP numbers: 43 out of 100 men are alive at 15 years with conservative treatment. 48 out of 100 men treated (an extra 5) are alive because of radical treatment. Of the men who would not survive, 46 would die due to causes not related to prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: My wife and I walk 1.5 - 2.0 miles every evening along the Charlotte Harbor waterfront. The path takes us thru a Childrens playground, pickleball courts, tennis courts, fishing pier, past two waterfront restaurants, and then thru downtown Punta Gorda, which on a January evening with a beautiful sunset and 73° air temp is full of al fresco diners and drinkers. This evening I decided to take my walk wearing a pair of snug briefs lined with a light men's absorbent pad. Big MISTAKE! During the day while puttering about the house I wear a men's Depends pullup brief. For the last three days the pad in the Depends has barely been damp after 12 to 14-hours wearing. The one I took off just before going on the walk was only 1.2 oz heavier than a new dry pad and I had been wearing it for 15-hours. My personal problem with the Depends is that my butt and hips get very sweaty and wet when briskly walking for a half hour or more. I sweat easily and profusely and the non-breathable material in the Depends really makes my skin damp. SO - for tonight's walk I decided to wear my normal breathable cotton/nylon briefs with a men's light pad to absorb any minor leakage, something I have tried a couple times with good success. I wear the light pad inside my spandex bicycle shorts when I go on a two hour hard ride and the pad is hardly damp when I am done. So, I started our walk with no thought of a leakage problem. About 3/4-mile from the car in the midst of many walkers, strollers, skaters, and people admiring the sunset my wife exclaims - "your butt is wet." I look at my crotch and a damp stain is starting to appear at the base of the zipper in my light brown walking shorts. Normally I wear black shorts which do not easily show dampness but I was too confident this evening to worry about that. We walked about 100-yards to a secluded location where I could open my waist band and look down into my briefs. I was shocked by a steady stream of urine and nothing I could do stopped it! That has not happened for more than six-weeks and I have little idea why tonight. I adjusted the light pad to catch as much leakage as possible but within 5-minutes my shorts were darkly stained front and back. I tried my hardest to stop the leakage but as soon as I relaxed by kegel action the stream started again. I could feel a small stream running down my leg. Within 10-minutes the short's zipper was surrounded by dark stains. SO - the big question: Do we boldly walk back along the waterfront path, past the resturants and sunset observers and hope they are concentrating on the western sky? Or, slink back thru downtown on the side streets and hope we miss all the folks walking to the local pubs and resturants, after all this is the height of tourist season and it was a wonderful warm evening. We chose the side streets, which we walk three or four nights a week and were surprised to a dozen groups of evening walkers. At least none of them pointed and laughted! It was a long slow and embarassing 15-minute walk back to the car. Fortunately, we had an old towel in the trunk that I could place on our almost brand new leather drivers seat. Our car is a 1993 Saab 900S which I have spent a fortune on restoring, including new leather upholstery. By the time we arrived at home and I took a shower the leakage had stopped and I again had complete positive bladder control. I wonder what happened during that 35 to 40-minute walk that I lost all bladder control? The only unusual thing I did this afternoon was to drink 16-oz of strong coffee about 90-minutes before we walked. I drink twice that every morning and never have a leakage problem. But, something this evening was different!

Posts.Content: My urologist is on vacation for July so would appreciate any observations you can make. 3T mpMRI with Dotarem IV contrast (to provide Dynamic Contrast Enhancement - DCE) on June 28 found an 18 cc prostate My June 20 PSA level was 10.2 which gives me a PSA density of 0.57 ng/cc Prostate That seems to be a very high density number. I can't find much research about PSA density so can any one offer any observations? And... my prostate seems quite small at 18 cc. - Is that unusually small? - Does the small size have any significance in the long term prognosis if the my ambiguous PCa diagnosis continues to be uncertain?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Yes, EPE is an adverse finding/prognostic factor in a RP path report. I believe major ones reported are: I am not sure EPE is that important for prognosis post RALP & SRT. Memorial Sloan Kettering nomogram probability of progression free life 6-years AFTER SRT (probability of NO BCR): Using MY numbers assume SRT (72Gy) and NO ADT at 0.2 ng/ml at 18-months post RALP with a 12-month doubling time and pre-RALP PSA of 10.2 69% with NO EPE and 68% with EPE and SM+ 56% with NO EPE and 58% with EPE and SM- If we assume 0.1 ng/ml as starting point for SRT (72 Gy & NO ADT) and 6-month PSA doubling time with 0.2 reached at 12-months the 6-year probability of NO BCR (NO Progression) is: 60% with EPE and 61% with NO EPE and SM+ 47% with EPE and 48% with NO EPE and SM-

Posts.Title: Combined ADT + RT after Surgery

Posts.Content: "Why post SRT? I thought we were discussing adjuvant vs. salvage RT after RP with adverse findings, such as EPE." His surgery was July 2018 - more than 6-months ago so is the current RT - Adjuvant or SRT? There is little, if any, evidence of biochemical recurrence or disease progression (PSA 0.06; 0.07; 0.1; 0.08 ) so what would the adjuvant therapy be treating? "The stats you posted are far from good. Best practice is to offer ART to men who are high risk post RT." I guess I am missing something - what makes him a high risk? MSK stats (not mine) show that IF he receives NO ADT but does receive SRT (which would be a higher Gy load ?) there is almost no difference in the probability of disease progression for a man with or without EPE. Why would results be any different for adjuvant with or without ADT? We can find research studies on many sides of this issue: Early Salvage vs Adjuvant Radiotherapy for High-Risk Prostate Cancer Rahul Tendulkar, MD: At least three randomized trials have examined the role of immediate postprostatectomy radiotherapy in patients with high-risk pathologic features, yet the optimal management remains controversial.[4-6] Two of these trials (Southwest Oncology Group [SWOG] 8794 and European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer 22911) included patients with a detectable postoperative PSA level, and thus the immediate radiotherapy arms comprised a mix of adjuvant and salvage radiotherapy.[4,5] Likewise, the observation arms included some patients with untreated residual disease, which likely resulted in worse outcomes than would have been seen if these patients had been excluded from randomization. Only the German trial (ARO 96-02) tested adjuvant radiation vs observation in a cohort of patients with undetectable PSA levels (< 0.1 ng/mL), and unfortunately this trial had the smallest sample size.[6] Interestingly, among the patients randomized to observation across all three trials, about half (46% to 54%) remained free of biochemical recurrence at 5 years, suggesting that adjuvant radiotherapy would have been unnecessary in a large proportion of patients despite their high-risk pathologic features. In summary, serial PSA testing with initiation of early salvage radiotherapy is an attractive treatment paradigm and should be considered for most men after radical prostatectomy. Because of the ability of serum PSA to detect low-volume prostate cancer recurrences, clinicians can better select those patients who are most likely to benefit from treatment. Likewise, up to half of men with high-risk features may be spared from potentially unnecessary adjuvant therapy and its associated costs and side effects. Until genomic profiling is proven to provide more personalized outcomes assessments, patients should be counseled about both approaches, with joint decision making based on a careful assessment of the risks and benefits of each treatment option. A more recent metastudy (Contemporary role of postoperative radiotherapy for prostate cancer Alan Dal Pra,corresponding author Matthew C. Abramowitz, Radka Stoyanova, and Alan Pollack June 2018 states: Adverse pathological factors after RP, such as positive surgical margins (+SM), extracapsular extension (ECE), or seminal vesicle invasion (SVI) increase the likelihood of disease recurrence. Three randomized clinical trials (RCT) have addressed the potential benefits of adjuvant (ART) versus delayed RT after RP for these patents... Taken together, these RCTs provide level I evidence for improved biochemical control without clear proof of benefit in long-term freedom from metastasis or survival for adjuvant therapy." As more research is done and genomics because more precise to each individual - the ART -vs- SRT decision will become easier and the added decision about ADT will also become more clear.

Posts.Content: "When the MRI came I was called in and explained that the prostate looks inflamed and there are "some modifications in some cells" and he doesn't know what to say." Are you certain that is what you were told: "some modifications in some cells? In my limited knowledge, an MRI does not work at the cellular level. My understanding is the MRI senses changes in the spin of protons as they relax from the intense magnetic field. The timing of the spin change varies depending on tissue type. The contrast media allows the differential uptake (diffusion) of the fluid depending on the tissue type. The computer and the radiologist can then interpret the timing and pattern of spin changes to "estimate" tissue type. What kind of MRI? - 3TmpMRI - with or without contrast? - with or without endorectal coil? Was the MRI specific to the prostate or generalized to the entire area around the prostate? There should be a formal report about the MRI interpretation including a PIRADS number - did you get one? - prostate size? - were modified cells (tissue?) in one region or multiple regions? Can you share the report details? Here are two excellent references if you want to learn more about MRI function, limitations, and utility for prostate problem diagnosis: https://www.livescience.com/39074-what-is-an-mri.html https://pubs.rsna.org/doi/pdf/10.1148/rg.2016150234

A more recent metastudy (Contemporary role of postoperative radiotherapy for prostate cancer Alan Dal Pra,corresponding author Matthew C. Abramowitz, Radka Stoyanova, and Alan Pollack June 2018 states: Adverse pathological factors after RP, such as positive surgical margins (+SM), extracapsular extension (ECE), or seminal vesicle invasion (SVI) increase the likelihood of disease recurrence. Three randomized clinical trials (RCT) have addressed the potential benefits of adjuvant (ART) versus delayed RT after RP for these patents... Taken together, these RCTs provide level I evidence for improved biochemical control without clear proof of benefit in long-term freedom from metastasis or survival for adjuvant therapy." As more research is done and genomics because more precise to each individual - the ART -vs- SRT decision will become easier and the added decision about ADT will also become more clear.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the often confusing and confounding world of PSA measures, interpretations, and prognostication. You will find that your prostate related information, analysis, and interpretation develops slowly and frequently in less than straightforward fashion. I began the journey in mid-May 2018 and had no clear answer until August 9, 2018. Here is one study, published in 2013 that might give you some temporary mental relief until the urologist can do a more complete workup. You did not tell us your age, which is very important in the decision making processes, so the following study may not help. 268 men, aged 40-49, were randomly selected in 1990 and carefully followed for 16 or more years. Only 0.6% (ONE) of the 195 men with a PSA < 1.0 (in their initial 1990 exam) developed prostate cancer with a Gleason score of 6 by the time they all reached 55-years of age. None of those 195 men with PSA < 1.0 developed intermediate or higher risk prostate cancer. The article's summary says "If it is below 1.0 ng/mL, there is very little risk for developing a lethal CaP, and as many as 75% of men might be able to avoid additional PSA screening until 55 years."

Of the men who would not survive, 46 would die due to causes not related to prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Shocking or perhaps Disturbing Results for my particular numbers! I sure hope I am mis-understanding or mis-interpreting the results. MY 10-year Overall Survival with: Radical Prostatectomy 74% Conservative Treatment (Active Surveillance) 71% NO PCa diagnosis 77% The data above says that I only gain a 3% increase in overall survival probability at age 81 by submitting to an RP. OR - 32 out of 33 cases similar to mine will receive NO benefit in 10-years by proceeding to treatment compared to AS. Does that mean that in 11 out of 12 cases ( [71-77]/77 = ~8%) similar to mine that COMPLETE IGNORANCE of my PSA, and thus no treatment, would lead to NO PCa death by age 81? I guess that is why PSA testing after age 72 is not recommended? MY 15-year Overall Survival with: Radical Prostatectomy 48% Conservative Treatment (Active Surveillance) 43% NO PCa diagnosis 54% Does that mean IF I knew I had PCa (3+4) and did NO treatment (AS) I would be only ~20% more likely ( [43-54]/54 )to die in 15-years than if I had NO PCa at all? Does that mean that in 9 out of 10 cases ( [43-48]/43 ) similar to mine that AS would lead to NO PCa death by age 86 IF I knew I had (3+4) PCa? I guess a more optimistic way to interpret the data is that RP benefits are only realized in the long term, which in my case exceeds 15-years. To me, this shows why it is so important to consider one's overall health and medical status when deciding on PCa treatment modalities and strategies. Life expectancy is so critical when making these long term decisions. I still expect to fumble around on this earth for another 20-years so RP still makes sense to me.

Posts.Content: Journol of Urology Jan 2015 Extent of extraprostatic extension independently influences biochemical recurrence-free survival: evidence for further pT3 subclassification OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the impact of the extent of extraprostatic extension (EPE) on biochemical recurrence-free survival (BCRFS) after radical prostatectomy (RP). MATERIALS AND METHODS: We queried our RP database from 2004 to 2013. Extent of EPE on RP was divided into 3 groups: no EPE, focal EPE (F-EPE; a few extraprostatic cancer glands on 1-2 slides), and nonfocal EPE (NF-EPE). Multivariate Cox proportional hazard models determined the influence of EPE on BCRFS. RESULTS: A total of 10,750 men underwent RP during the study period. Of these, 7,843 men (73.0%) had no EPE, 1,258 (11.7%) men had F-EPE, and 1,649 men had (15.3%) NF-EPE. Overall BCRFS was worse in men with NF-EPE than those with F-EPE or no EPE. In a multivariate model, F-EPE and NF-EPE were both independently associated with worse BCRFS compared with no EPE (F-EPE: hazard ratio, 2.41; 95% confidence interval, 1.84-3.10; P <.0001; NF-EPE: hazard ratio, 3.57; 95% confidence interval, 2.89-4.40; P <.0001). When stratified by Gleason score in men without seminal vesicle invasion or lymph node metastases, there was no difference in BCRFS for Gleason score <6, 3 + 4 = 7, 4 + 3 = 7, and 8 for F-EPE vs no EPE; however, patients with Gleason score of 9-10 with F-EPE had worse BCRFS. Patients with NF-EPE had significantly worse BCRFS for Gleason score <6, 7, and 8 and a trend for worse BCRFS for Gleason score 9-10 compared with no EPE. I guess I will go to bed now - I found something to tell me that my Focal EPE has no more probability of BioChemical Failure, (requiring adjuvant or salvage radiation?), than if there were NO EPE. Now - If only I could find something as positive regarding positive margins. Like - mine are small (2mm<) and restricted to one slide only so they don't count. I suspect the only thing that matters is that first PSA test on October 9 but I can try to learn more as I wait.
