Posts.Content: Six Weeks since my RALP. I can easily control the urine stream much of the time. I get a full bladder signal and then piss out a normal healthy stream that I can stop and start at will. This full bladder & good control will last for eight or more hours. During that time I do leak or dribble a bit but do not have to change my maxi-Depends for six or eight hours. At other times I dribble continuously and can only stop the urine leakage with maximum effort, which if relaxed even a bit allows a burst of urine to escape. When my system is in that mode I fill a maxi-Depends in two or three hours and never retain any fluid in my bladder. The two phases are not related to caffeine or alcohol, as far as I can tell. This morning I had two strong cups of coffee and almost no leakage during the four hours after the coffee. Now, as I write this four hours after the last sip of coffee, the urine is flowing non-stop and I have almost zero control. Some nights I go eight hours with an almost dry pad and good full bladder emptying several times during the night with near perfect control. Other nights, e.g. last night, I soak through a pad in two hours or less and never get a full bladder. But, after changing the pad at 4 AM, I woke up at 9:30 AM with a full bladder, easy control, and an almost dry pad. I had one beer, at 7 PM, just before dinner. I am becoming quite frustrated because I feel like I have regained most of the bladder control, and then suddenly it disappears for half a day, only to reappear for no apparent reason. This good control / no control has not changed much in the last three weeks. The morning after the catheter was removed (six-days post RALP) I woke with a full bladder and good control, being able to stop and start the stream three times while emptying the bladder. But, it feels like I have made little progress since then. Additionally, stress incontinence has not improved a bit. Bending over to tie my shoes, getting up from a chair, or twisting in bed to reach a book on the night stand, all result in major leakage, no matter how much I try to tightened the external sphincter. That sphincter control is usually quite good while standing over the toilet but seems inadequate to deal with normal stress. Getting into and out of the car always leads to some, and often, major leakage. That is a real problem for every day living because I fill a maxi-Depends with two round trips into and out of the drivers seat. That makes it hard to go anywhere and do anything and is becoming a real QoL issue. Is this a normal course of events? The RALP surgeon told my wife, I can't remember the conversation but it was just four hours after the surgery, that he spared entirely one nerve, and felt he did very little damage to the other. He told my wife I should expect almost perfect bladder control after a few months. My first post-catheter removal appointment with the surgeon is next Tuesday so I will express my concerns then but I would appreciate any opinions from the "been there - done that" guys here. I am very careful to do 20x Kegels three times a day, every day without fail. Thanks!

AgeInfo.Phrase: I woke up at 9 30 AM with a full bladder

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kumquat we just spoke with is interested in doing the entire prostate and not just the side where we have discovered the tumors and cancer cells. Kumquat Did not know that was possible My understanding is that HIFU can only work on tumors in glands that are smaller than about 40cc or 60cc depending on who you talk with, or which articles you read. I thought that the sound waves could only penetrate a certain depth of tissue and would not work effectively beyond that depth, thus those high energy waves cannot reach all the way thru the gland. A prostate larger than 40cc must be reduced in size prior to HIFU. Is that cost covered by Medicare? My understanding of a TURP prostate size reduction is that most men find it quite unpleasant. Here is a quote from the Indian Jounal of Urology "A prostate volume >40 ml should be excluded from treatment, or two HIFU session should be considered. This is the major difficulty of HIFU, to reach the anterior parts of the prostate." The article was written in 2010 so maybe the newer technology has addressed that limitation. Please let us know what other interesting new information you gather in your future discussion. I am very interested in HIFU and will greatly appreciate any new data.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: Is cost any concern to you? I have been considering HIFU for my treatment and have spent a lot of time talking to Scionti Prostate Center in Sarasota, FLorida. They do make HIFU sound like an attractive option! I have Medicare and Florida Blue Shield NO Deductible Plan F supplemental insurance to pay what Medicare does not. I do not pay a penny to any medical provider, which accepts Medicare/CMS contracts or assignments. However, Scionti Billing was quite clear that MY out of pocket expense would be AT LEAST $7,000 and more likely $9,000. Their website said the OOP for a Medicare patient is in the $10,000- $12,000 range but the person I talked to, three times, said their experience is that the lesser range I quoted is the typical out of pocket expense. I did get the sense that many expenses that will not be covered by Medicare are unknowable at the time treatment begins and can be substantially greater than the $10,000 or $12,000 upper limit I quote above. There are now CMS Code C numbers to be used for billing CMS/Medicare or seeking reimbursement of my expenses but CMS/Medicare is clear that not all costs associated with HIFU will be covered. I tried but did not receive any answer to the question of "Do I pay all the expenses myself and seek reimbursement from Medicare or will you bill Medicare and then bill me the difference?" The answer I received indicated there were a lot of IFs associated with things unknown at the start of treatment but I should be prepared and able to pay up front $20,000 out of my own pocket with much, maybe half, of it being reimbursed to me by Medicare. But, other patients find that they pay only the $10,000 out of pocket because Medicare is billed directly. The financial ambiguity did not make me very comfortable! And... I have already had a 3T mpMRI to locate and classify my prostate tumor. The Scitonti RN told me that many MRIs they receive for review are not usable because they were not properly done and must be repeated at Scionti in order to develop the map Dr. Scionti uses to aim the UltraSound device. Usually, CMS/Medicare will not pay for a 2nd MRI. I have read a lot of technical/medical literature about HIFU and it does seem to hold great promise. But, there is limited long term data to confirm the 15 and 20-year survival rates and quality of life issues that are well analyzed with radiation and surgical procedures. My biopsy has been delayed due to an infected wound on my lower leg so I will continue to research this issue while I wait several more weeks to find out if I am a HIFU candidate. Financial issues may seem to be the least of concerns however: - My wife is not old enough for Medicare and pays $9,252 per year for Blue Shield of Florida Bronze high deductible insurance - She needs additional surgery to revisit a femur/hip repair that did not yield good results and this will cost us $7,000 this year - My Medicare and Florida Blue Plan F supplemental costs $4,750 per year - Our Dental insurance costs $1,000 per year - My wife needs $2,500 of dental work, over the annual max her insurance covers, to repair very old fillings and crowns that failed IF you are keeping track - that is more than $24,000 in medical insurance and expenses we have committed to for 2018. Another $10,000 for HIFU would be a sharp blow to our retirement budget! That amount of additional expense will make me think long and hard about the potential benefits of HIFU compared to other treatments that are 100%, (or so I understand at this point), paid for by Medicare and Blue Shield of Florida.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: After my MRI, Free PSA, and 4KScore convinced me that treatment was going to happen sooner rather than later I went on a frenzied search for information. I made it my full time job to talk to as many physicians, physicians assistants, and nurses as possible. I talked and talked and listened and listened - about procedures I would most likely never consider, theories that sounded crazy, and treatments that were outlandishly expensive. I sent e-mails, text messages, adn made phone calls. I wanted to hear from a wide variety of medical providers who could offer me a vast array of perspectives and ideas. I tried to get each of them to provide negative or adverse comments about all the others. I wanted each specialist to tell me why they and only they would be my savior. ALL of them were more than willing to play the game - they knew I was on a fishing expedition and willingly participated and spent a shocking amount of time educating me. I was so impressed at how willing each and every one was to talk and talk, and write answers to all my questions. Take your time and research a wide variety of options - some of the less likely ones may provide you with insight that could change your mind about what is best for you. Do not lock in on a particular clinic, doctor, or technique/procedure until you've explored the many possible paths you could follow from Dx thru primary treatment.

Posts.Title: Looking for surgeon and/or RT doc in Seattle area ...

Posts.Content: Walsh book (4th edition) page 326 "ULTRASENSITIVE PSA TESTS" references a study done by a Walsh colleague at Hopkins, Dr. Lori Sokoll (professor of pathology and assistant director of clinical chemistry): 750 men 3-months post RP with PSA <0.1 were given ULTRASENSITIVE PSA tests and then monitored for 10-years. 14% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA < 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years 78% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA > 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years There was no report about the clinical symptoms or actual PSA level at 10-years I found a source document for Dr. Sokoll (Journal of Urology Feb 2016), which discusses the same topic but has a little different conclusion than found in the Walsh book. I am not sure if this is the research Walsh was describing but pub date and number of subjects is very similar to what is in the book. Biochemical recurrence-free rates 11 years after surgery were 86.1% (95% CI 83.289.0) for prostate specific antigen less than 0.01 ng/ml and 48.9% (95% CI 37.560.3) for prostate specific antigen 0.01 ng/ml or greater (p <0.0001). That says to me: An Ultrasensitive PSA < 0.01 had an 86% chance of no biochemical recurrence compared to only about 50% chance of no recurrence if the Ultrasensitive PSA =>.01. Thanksgiving this year I will be at 3-months post RP and am hoping I see that PSA <0.1 report so I can then ask for an Ultrasensitive test to get even more peace of mind.

Posts.Title: 3 month post op Dr visit

Posts.Content: Have you studied the "Review of the Prognostic Value of BCR" thread? https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...c-Value-of-BCR It points at a very detailed analysis of 77 research papers about BioChemical Recurrence and the interpretation of rising PSA values. It also ends with some recommendations for how to think about future treatment decisions when faced with a rising PSA. In summary the article states: “Based on these analyses, in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment, the main prognostic factor for DM, PCSM, and OM was short PSA-DT." That is doubling time, or how long it takes the PSA score to double once it reaches a BCR level, which in RP surgery patients is typically 0.2ng/ml for two consecutive measures. The article discusses the determination of DT because it is such an important value. OM = Overall Mortality (death from any cause) PCSM = PCa Specific Mortality DM = Distant Metastasis (clinical evidence of distant metastasis or metastatic prostate disease) "3.4.2.6. Interval to biochemical failure. For patients undergoing RP as primary treatment, IBF was associated with DM in two out of six, PCSM in eight out of 11, and OM in one out of four studies, respectively." Research is pretty clear that and Interval Before Failure (time from surgery to BCR which is usually defined as 0.2 ng/ml) is the critical measure. If that interval is greater than 18-months the likelihood of a CLINICAL recurrence is small. "3.4.2.7. PSA-DT after radical treatment. There was a clear association between PSA-DT after primary therapy and oncological outcomes, being most pronounced in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment. All reported studies showed a significant correlation between shorter PSA-DT and DM, PCSM, and OM. The shorter the PSA-DT, the higher the risk of developing worse oncological outcomes." The study suggests there be a category of patients titled "EAU Low Risk of BCR" Interval to Biochemical Failuer > 18-months Gleason Score after surgery < 8 - OR- PSA-Doubling Time > 12-months Gleason Score after surgery <8 You do not provide enough detail to calculate DT exactly but it seems to be far greater than 12-months (.02 in late 2016) to 0.05 now. BCR has not been reached (0.05 << 0.2) so the IBF will be much greater than 34-months. That Gleason score is appearing much more important for prognosis. The study cites research done by Trock et. al.: "In contrast, in patients with PSA-DT >6 mo, sRT +/- ADT had no prognostic value with HRs for PCSM of 0.66 to 0.85." The HR refers to Hazard Ratio, which means in this case the number of men who died from PCa after they had a rising PSA and met the BCR level and received salvage radiation (with or without ADT) was 35% to 15% less than if they did not receive SRT +/- ADT. The meta-study authors felt there was no statistical difference in the probability of dying from PCa with or without SRT. Those patients need to consider the toxic side effects of salvage radiation therapy when considering future treatment. The "Implications for Clinical practise" section of the article says "As an example, if a PSA rise of >0.2 ng/ml is confirmed in a patient after primary RP, the pGS is 7, and if PSA kinetics are favorable (PSA-DT >12 mo, IBF >18 mo), patients should be informed that they have low-risk BCR and the potential toxicities of additional treatments should be discussed to allow the patient to make a well-informed decision." Your husband is young and it sounds like he has a long life ahead of him so consideration of his Quality of Life might be important IF his Gleason score was 7 or less.

Posts.Title: Update and question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kumquat we just spoke with is interested in doing the entire prostate and not just the side where we have discovered the tumors and cancer cells. Kumquat Did not know that was possible My understanding is that HIFU can only work on tumors in glands that are smaller than about 40cc or 60cc depending on who you talk with, or which articles you read. I thought that the sound waves could only penetrate a certain depth of tissue and would not work effectively beyond that depth, thus those high energy waves cannot reach all the way thru the gland. A prostate larger than 40cc must be reduced in size prior to HIFU. Is that cost covered by Medicare? My understanding of a TURP prostate size reduction is that most men find it quite unpleasant. Here is a quote from the Indian Jounal of Urology "A prostate volume >40 ml should be excluded from treatment, or two HIFU session should be considered. This is the major difficulty of HIFU, to reach the anterior parts of the prostate." The article was written in 2010 so maybe the newer technology has addressed that limitation. Please let us know what other interesting new information you gather in your future discussion. I am very interested in HIFU and will greatly appreciate any new data.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: His attitude does not sound OK to me. June and July this year I went thru the same exercise as you describe. My medical urologist/oncologist (he quit doing prostatectomeis when RALP demonstrated it's superiority in most cases) was eager for me to get a 2nd opinion from Johns Hopkins. He also automatically hooked me up with a Da Vinci surgeon who spent years doing basic research under Calafano, at National Cancer Institute, and UNC, into diagnostic procedures AND early robotic procedures. The robot guy now does 200 RALP a year. My medical urologist also put me in contact with a superb radiation oncologist who has similarly distinguished credentials. My medical guy said he prefers surgery but the patient needs to explore all appropriate options and discuss those options with the experts. He automatically forward ALL my tests and images to the robot guy, the radiation guy, and my internist who is serving as my un-biased advisor because she prefers a more holistic approach but recognizes the need for aggressive treatment in my case. I am not a expert but your biopsy numbers and blood work need to be reviewed by someone who is not a cutter and is not a radiotherapy advocate. From my very limited perspective it seems you have many choices other than RALP.

Financial issues may seem to be the least of concerns however: - My wife is not old enough for Medicare and pays $9,252 per year for Blue Shield of Florida Bronze high deductible insurance - She needs additional surgery to revisit a femur/hip repair that did not yield good results and this will cost us $7,000 this year - My Medicare and Florida Blue Plan F supplemental costs $4,750 per year - Our Dental insurance costs $1,000 per year - My wife needs $2,500 of dental work, over the annual max her insurance covers, to repair very old fillings and crowns that failed IF you are keeping track - that is more than $24,000 in medical insurance and expenses we have committed to for 2018. Another $10,000 for HIFU would be a sharp blow to our retirement budget! That amount of additional expense will make me think long and hard about the potential benefits of HIFU compared to other treatments that are 100%, (or so I understand at this point), paid for by Medicare and Blue Shield of Florida.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: Is cost any concern to you? I have been considering HIFU for my treatment and have spent a lot of time talking to Scionti Prostate Center in Sarasota, FLorida. They do make HIFU sound like an attractive option! I have Medicare and Florida Blue Shield NO Deductible Plan F supplemental insurance to pay what Medicare does not. I do not pay a penny to any medical provider, which accepts Medicare/CMS contracts or assignments. However, Scionti Billing was quite clear that MY out of pocket expense would be AT LEAST $7,000 and more likely $9,000. Their website said the OOP for a Medicare patient is in the $10,000- $12,000 range but the person I talked to, three times, said their experience is that the lesser range I quoted is the typical out of pocket expense. I did get the sense that many expenses that will not be covered by Medicare are unknowable at the time treatment begins and can be substantially greater than the $10,000 or $12,000 upper limit I quote above. There are now CMS Code C numbers to be used for billing CMS/Medicare or seeking reimbursement of my expenses but CMS/Medicare is clear that not all costs associated with HIFU will be covered. I tried but did not receive any answer to the question of "Do I pay all the expenses myself and seek reimbursement from Medicare or will you bill Medicare and then bill me the difference?" The answer I received indicated there were a lot of IFs associated with things unknown at the start of treatment but I should be prepared and able to pay up front $20,000 out of my own pocket with much, maybe half, of it being reimbursed to me by Medicare. But, other patients find that they pay only the $10,000 out of pocket because Medicare is billed directly. The financial ambiguity did not make me very comfortable! And... I have already had a 3T mpMRI to locate and classify my prostate tumor. The Scitonti RN told me that many MRIs they receive for review are not usable because they were not properly done and must be repeated at Scionti in order to develop the map Dr. Scionti uses to aim the UltraSound device. Usually, CMS/Medicare will not pay for a 2nd MRI. I have read a lot of technical/medical literature about HIFU and it does seem to hold great promise. But, there is limited long term data to confirm the 15 and 20-year survival rates and quality of life issues that are well analyzed with radiation and surgical procedures. My biopsy has been delayed due to an infected wound on my lower leg so I will continue to research this issue while I wait several more weeks to find out if I am a HIFU candidate. Financial issues may seem to be the least of concerns however: - My wife is not old enough for Medicare and pays $9,252 per year for Blue Shield of Florida Bronze high deductible insurance - She needs additional surgery to revisit a femur/hip repair that did not yield good results and this will cost us $7,000 this year - My Medicare and Florida Blue Plan F supplemental costs $4,750 per year - Our Dental insurance costs $1,000 per year - My wife needs $2,500 of dental work, over the annual max her insurance covers, to repair very old fillings and crowns that failed IF you are keeping track - that is more than $24,000 in medical insurance and expenses we have committed to for 2018. Another $10,000 for HIFU would be a sharp blow to our retirement budget! That amount of additional expense will make me think long and hard about the potential benefits of HIFU compared to other treatments that are 100%, (or so I understand at this point), paid for by Medicare and Blue Shield of Florida.

Posts.Title: HIFU? My husband is 71, has PSA 5.5, Gleason 4+3, T2b. Any advice?

Posts.Content: Have you studied the "Review of the Prognostic Value of BCR" thread? https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...c-Value-of-BCR It points at a very detailed analysis of 77 research papers about BioChemical Recurrence and the interpretation of rising PSA values. It also ends with some recommendations for how to think about future treatment decisions when faced with a rising PSA. In summary the article states: “Based on these analyses, in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment, the main prognostic factor for DM, PCSM, and OM was short PSA-DT." That is doubling time, or how long it takes the PSA score to double once it reaches a BCR level, which in RP surgery patients is typically 0.2ng/ml for two consecutive measures. The article discusses the determination of DT because it is such an important value. OM = Overall Mortality (death from any cause) PCSM = PCa Specific Mortality DM = Distant Metastasis (clinical evidence of distant metastasis or metastatic prostate disease) "3.4.2.6. Interval to biochemical failure. For patients undergoing RP as primary treatment, IBF was associated with DM in two out of six, PCSM in eight out of 11, and OM in one out of four studies, respectively." Research is pretty clear that and Interval Before Failure (time from surgery to BCR which is usually defined as 0.2 ng/ml) is the critical measure. If that interval is greater than 18-months the likelihood of a CLINICAL recurrence is small. "3.4.2.7. PSA-DT after radical treatment. There was a clear association between PSA-DT after primary therapy and oncological outcomes, being most pronounced in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment. All reported studies showed a significant correlation between shorter PSA-DT and DM, PCSM, and OM. The shorter the PSA-DT, the higher the risk of developing worse oncological outcomes." The study suggests there be a category of patients titled "EAU Low Risk of BCR" Interval to Biochemical Failuer > 18-months Gleason Score after surgery < 8 - OR- PSA-Doubling Time > 12-months Gleason Score after surgery <8 You do not provide enough detail to calculate DT exactly but it seems to be far greater than 12-months (.02 in late 2016) to 0.05 now. BCR has not been reached (0.05 << 0.2) so the IBF will be much greater than 34-months. That Gleason score is appearing much more important for prognosis. The study cites research done by Trock et. al.: "In contrast, in patients with PSA-DT >6 mo, sRT +/- ADT had no prognostic value with HRs for PCSM of 0.66 to 0.85." The HR refers to Hazard Ratio, which means in this case the number of men who died from PCa after they had a rising PSA and met the BCR level and received salvage radiation (with or without ADT) was 35% to 15% less than if they did not receive SRT +/- ADT. The meta-study authors felt there was no statistical difference in the probability of dying from PCa with or without SRT. Those patients need to consider the toxic side effects of salvage radiation therapy when considering future treatment. The "Implications for Clinical practise" section of the article says "As an example, if a PSA rise of >0.2 ng/ml is confirmed in a patient after primary RP, the pGS is 7, and if PSA kinetics are favorable (PSA-DT >12 mo, IBF >18 mo), patients should be informed that they have low-risk BCR and the potential toxicities of additional treatments should be discussed to allow the patient to make a well-informed decision." Your husband is young and it sounds like he has a long life ahead of him so consideration of his Quality of Life might be important IF his Gleason score was 7 or less.

Posts.Title: Update and question

Posts.Content: Walsh book (4th edition) page 326 "ULTRASENSITIVE PSA TESTS" references a study done by a Walsh colleague at Hopkins, Dr. Lori Sokoll (professor of pathology and assistant director of clinical chemistry): 750 men 3-months post RP with PSA <0.1 were given ULTRASENSITIVE PSA tests and then monitored for 10-years. 14% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA < 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years 78% of men with ULTRASENSITIVE PSA > 0.03 had an elevated PSA at the end of 10-years There was no report about the clinical symptoms or actual PSA level at 10-years I found a source document for Dr. Sokoll (Journal of Urology Feb 2016), which discusses the same topic but has a little different conclusion than found in the Walsh book. I am not sure if this is the research Walsh was describing but pub date and number of subjects is very similar to what is in the book. Biochemical recurrence-free rates 11 years after surgery were 86.1% (95% CI 83.289.0) for prostate specific antigen less than 0.01 ng/ml and 48.9% (95% CI 37.560.3) for prostate specific antigen 0.01 ng/ml or greater (p <0.0001). That says to me: An Ultrasensitive PSA < 0.01 had an 86% chance of no biochemical recurrence compared to only about 50% chance of no recurrence if the Ultrasensitive PSA =>.01. Thanksgiving this year I will be at 3-months post RP and am hoping I see that PSA <0.1 report so I can then ask for an Ultrasensitive test to get even more peace of mind.

Posts.Title: 3 month post op Dr visit

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kumquat we just spoke with is interested in doing the entire prostate and not just the side where we have discovered the tumors and cancer cells. Kumquat Did not know that was possible My understanding is that HIFU can only work on tumors in glands that are smaller than about 40cc or 60cc depending on who you talk with, or which articles you read. I thought that the sound waves could only penetrate a certain depth of tissue and would not work effectively beyond that depth, thus those high energy waves cannot reach all the way thru the gland. A prostate larger than 40cc must be reduced in size prior to HIFU. Is that cost covered by Medicare? My understanding of a TURP prostate size reduction is that most men find it quite unpleasant. Here is a quote from the Indian Jounal of Urology "A prostate volume >40 ml should be excluded from treatment, or two HIFU session should be considered. This is the major difficulty of HIFU, to reach the anterior parts of the prostate." The article was written in 2010 so maybe the newer technology has addressed that limitation. Please let us know what other interesting new information you gather in your future discussion. I am very interested in HIFU and will greatly appreciate any new data.

Posts.Title: The Stumbling journey continues on to unknown destinations

Posts.Content: His attitude does not sound OK to me. June and July this year I went thru the same exercise as you describe. My medical urologist/oncologist (he quit doing prostatectomeis when RALP demonstrated it's superiority in most cases) was eager for me to get a 2nd opinion from Johns Hopkins. He also automatically hooked me up with a Da Vinci surgeon who spent years doing basic research under Calafano, at National Cancer Institute, and UNC, into diagnostic procedures AND early robotic procedures. The robot guy now does 200 RALP a year. My medical urologist also put me in contact with a superb radiation oncologist who has similarly distinguished credentials. My medical guy said he prefers surgery but the patient needs to explore all appropriate options and discuss those options with the experts. He automatically forward ALL my tests and images to the robot guy, the radiation guy, and my internist who is serving as my un-biased advisor because she prefers a more holistic approach but recognizes the need for aggressive treatment in my case. I am not a expert but your biopsy numbers and blood work need to be reviewed by someone who is not a cutter and is not a radiotherapy advocate. From my very limited perspective it seems you have many choices other than RALP.

Posts.Title: The Stumbling journey continues on to unknown destinations

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think your doc is wisely prudent. OTS, stay optimistic that all is prostate-contained and either treatment path will permanently rid you of you unwanted intruder! I am actually quite relieved that the doc was so committed to treatment and so unequivocal in his analysis. I can now stop wondering and thinking this or that and can concentrate on treatment. I am a man of action and when committed to a path I seldom "what if" my choice. My doc was a board certified surgeon for five years prior to becoming a board certified urologist. But - he does not do any prostatectomy work at this point in his busy practice. He wants to concentrate on the non-oncology side of surgery and the diagnostic side of prostate cancer. He recommended a robotic surgeon whose practice involves many robotic prostatectomies each week. His total robotic prostatatecomy count is in the several thousand range. At this point I am strongly leaning to RALP because few surgeons in SW Florida are doing open prostatectomies. And, the latest quality of life, post prostatectomy, shows fewer adverse side effects in the areas that concern me, i.e bowel and bladder involvement. I can deal with ED and minor urinary incontinence but bowel or bladder problems would drive me crazy. The ability to get a 100% cure with a RP is appealing as is the ongoing PSA monitoring to verify I too get to be a member of the PSA Zero club - look out - here I come! (at least once more before the RP?) I have an appointment with the Robot operator on Monday afternoon to get a feel for him, his practice, and his prognosis.

Posts.Title: I really knew little about my pathology report and understood even less

Posts.Content: My MO, whose practice includes a major radiation treatment facility, talked to me about radiation during our mid-January appointment when I had a 0.018 PSA. His take, at that time, was NO radiation and no consideration of radiation until my PSA exceeded 0.1 for two tests over 3-months. We'll find out what he now thinks Wednesday mid-Day, April 10. He does not even want a µPSA test - he says the > 0.1 level will provide us plenty of time to make an appropriate decision IF the PSA rises.

Posts.Content: My career, beginning with NASA in 1969, was exploitation of new and over the horizon computer technology. I see my situation as a race between imaging and radiation technology and whatever little PCa badboys might have escaped my prostate. Technology has always come thru for me and I sure hope that remains the case for the next 20-years!

Posts.Title: The Stumbling journey continues on to unknown destinations

Posts.Content: T1c/Grade II / medical urologist says "unfavorable intermediate but doesn't matter because of high PSA density" surgeon urologist says "favorable intermediate" radiation oncologist says "intermediate intermediate but it doesn't matter because it is intermediate with high PSA density" The RP -or- EBRT+LDR Brachy -or- LDR Brachy monotherapy all seem to depend on the probability of Exta Capsular Extension (ECE) My radiation oncologist recommends 3 to 6 months ADT, 37 to 44 EBRT treatments, and LDR-Brachytherapy He also wants a 2nd opinion read on the biopsy and recommended Hopkins. I was pushing for ONLY LDR-BT. My .55ng/ml/ml PSA density and a 100% 1.4cm 3+4 and 60% 2.0cm 3+4 specimen are worrisome, as they were to my medical urologist, who gave me a 50% proabability of ECE, and my RALP surgeon who things the chance of ECE is less than 35%. Thus, the need for EBRT. Radiation doc, thinks the ADT could also be helpful due to the 35% probability of extra-capsular extension . Is there anything a 2nd opinion can due to resolve the ECE probability? My 3T mpMRI report clearly states the "capsule is intact" and "No extracapsular disease." Specificity of the MRI reading for ECE exceeds 75% in most studies, which says to me there is less than a 1 in 4 chance of ECE. That probability seems to be critical in the decision making path. All the recent literature indicates that ADT is indicated when there is a significant risk of ECE. A 2016 talk by Dr Juanita Crook clearly states the decision about LDR-BT as a monotherapy in a G7 (3+4) patient rests on ECE probabilities. AND... if I have more than a 1 in 3 chance of ECE THEN - a RALP surgery would almost certainly be followed by EBRT or at least ADT so why bother with the RALP? How does one resolve this Extracapsular Extension/Disease question?

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic OTS, with regard to ECE prediction: (If any Abstracts look promising, you may want to look into getting the Full Text.) Thanks so much for the fantastic assistance! I'd seen a couple of those articles but not most of them. I guess the big question is what is my Tumor Contact Length? I will try to get the radiologist to reexamine my mpMRI to give me some more information. The "map" provided with the biopsy report shows the 100% (3+4) specimen to be 14mm and located next to the capsule and the 20mm specimen in the Lateral Apex to be 60% (3+4) and next to the capsule. I wonder if radiologist can use that info to estimate TCL? An issue raised by the radiation oncologist about those specimens is the distinct possibility the needle penetrated the capsule a bit and includes some periprostatic tissue. That seems unlikely to me and also seemed to be a bit of "salesman" talk also known as FUD when I was doing support for MegaMillion dollar software sales (Fear-Uncertainty-Doubt make the potential client scared enough they believe you are their savior) SO MUCH to think about! But, at least it is fun and interesting to deal with all this technical stuff and once again bury myself in analyzing research and statistical validity. Your assistance is so appreciated. I am shortly off to get the CT scan (pelvis & abdomen) with contrast and whole body bone scan. Hopefully they will not change my status and will allow me to continue this fantastic decision making process.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I'll let others comment on the stats. If you do opt for a RP, remember that you are not looking and interviewing for Dr. Average Stats. There are excellent, highly experienced surgeons with excellent urinary outcomes as well as some Just-Starting-Out-Haven't-Quite-Got-the-Hang-of-It ones. Yes that is an important observation and surgeon experience was not a controlled or analyzed variable in the JAMA QOL study. Here are two biggish names Patel (2011) reports on 1,111 RALP patients with an average 12-month continence rate of 96%. Shikanov (2010) reports on 1,436 RALP patients with an average 12-month continence rate of 69%. How does one verify the data / success rates / side effect percentages provided by my particular surgeon? My urologist, board certified surgeon and urologist, no longer does prostatectomies. He referred me to D. Ornstein in Bonita Springs, FL. Ornsteins website says he began doing RALP procedures in 2003 and has done thousands since then. So, I can assume the proper experience. How do I verify the results? My urologist says fewer than 4% of Ornstein RALP patients experience urinary incontinence at 24-months. They both work for the 21st Century Oncology which has many practices in many states. Trust but Verify - HOW?

Posts.Content: One hour discussion with my urologist regarding my blood tests and pathology report (August 3 TRUS 12-core biopsy with guidance from prior 3T mpMRI image). Bottom Line - Staging / Grading / MRI imaging mean very little when deciding the next steps to take in my PCa journey. Doctor confirmed: 18 cc prostate size calculated by TRUS PSA (blood taken during biopsy) has risen from 9.2 (May 19) to 10.2 (June 20) to 10.4 August 3 Every sample in left lobe was Gleason 6 or 7 A 1.4 cm sample was 100% (3+4) A 2.0 cm sample was 60% (3+4) His beginning summary was "You have a a very high level of PSA for such a small gland and small tumor identified on the MRI. Your PSA density is way to high and you have several cores that were a very high percentage Gleason 7." He confirmed the staging was T1c (I double checked that and he explained there was no tumor felt by DRE and it was equivocal\ in the MRI thus the T1c) He confirmed I was Grade II He confirmed I was unfavorable intermediate risk BUT - he felt none of that mattered because of the PSA density (~.56 ng/ml) and the 100% involvement in the left lobe. I asked him about a 2nd opinion and he said he had an easy process to transmit everything to Epstein at JH but was 100% certain there would be no change. Then the SHOCKER for me - "Even if the path is down graded to Gleason 6 (3+3) for every positive sample - you will still have a very high PSA density and total involvement of the left lobe - thus immediate treatment is required." He is a bit concerned about cancerous cells having already leaked (invaded) from the left lobe into the pelvic area (~5% probability) and/or into the systemic blood stream (~3% probability) Whole body CAT Scan with contrast and Whole Body Bone Scan on Wednesday August 15. If nothing detected on either scan I get to choose from surgery (prostatectomy) or radiation to begin prior to September 14. The date was selected because new data says to complete the surgery or start the radiation within 6-weeks of the biopsy. PCa with my characteristics is probably becoming more aggressive and the data shows a 1 point Gleason upgrade within several months of a biopsy with results similar to mine. He left treatment choice up to me and my wife. Similar survival rates at 15-years but significant advantage at 20-years for surgical patients.

Posts.Title: I really knew little about my pathology report and understood even less

Posts.Content: I need help understanding the urinary incontinence statistics I find in many places. They are quite inconsistent and in some cases hugely different. My baseline is a 2017 JAMA study looking at Quality of Life (QOL) for 1,141 men who underwent AS, RP, Internal, and External radiation during 2011 to 2013. This is an important study because it uses a nationally recognized and standarized method to determine QOL. All patients were extensively interviewed at pre-treatment/post Dx, 3-months, 12-months, and 24-months post treatment or post Dx for AS. Each patient had a Baseline (pre-treatment/post Dx) QOL analysis. I will focus on just urinary incontinence because that is the side effects that most concerns me at this point as I plan for RALP but still consider radiation. QOL responses are broken into three categories Normal (full urinary control with no dysfunction), intermediate (one distressful symptom, e.g. occasional leakage but minor impact on QOL), and poor ( at least one very distressful symptom with major QOL impact). I will focus on the NORMAL baseline group because that is where I currently live. No leakage, no holding problems, no emptying problems, almost no night time symptoms. The 314 AS participants grouped themselves as follows when asked about their CURRENT urinary incontinence at 24-months post Dx: 73% Normal 20% Intermediate 7% Poor (at least one major dysfunction adversely affecting The 469 RP participants grouped themselves as follows when asked about their CURRENT urinary incontinence at 24-months post RP: 34% Normal 50% Intermediate 16% Poor (at least one major dysfunction adversely affecting QOL) Please note - the participants shown above self reported NORMAL QOL (no symptoms) at their pre-treatment baseline. Those numbers seem to say that 27% of AS men and 66% of RP men have at least some urinary incontinence and 16% of RP patients report major urinary dysfunction at 24-months post treatment. I CANNOT reconcile those numbers with the following types of numbers I find reported at many prostate cancer education and treatment sites: Less than 10% of RP patients require pads 3-years post surgery (PCF) More than 90% of men who undergo surgery at MSK return to normal urinary function, usually within a few months. (MSK) Only 7% of men had urinary incontinence 18-months after RP (article in Urology) No Control or frequent leakage at 24-months post RP 9.6% (NEJM 2013) Personally bothered by leakage or dripping 24-months post RP 10.6% (NEJM 2013) Most of the literature reports 5% to 10% urinary incontinence post RP for ALL patients which is ~40% below the number for the QOL RP patients who had NO urinary sypmtoms prior to RP. How do the popular literature and other medical studies report post-RP urninary incontinence percentages that are LOWER than the pre-RP incontinence numbers? What am I misunderstanding here? The major QOL study found that 2 of 3 RP patients who had normal urinary function prior to surgery had at least one distressful symptom post RP yet everyone else reports only 1 out of 10 men have an incontinence problem. An AUA paper published in 2016 concludes: Surgeon overestimate continence Patients report higher incontinence and are bothered by the rate of incontinence

Posts.Content: D&B At 4-weeks post surgery I too was impatient and tried sitting on my mountain bike. I was uncomfortably aware of the saddle and felt a bit of pressure in my lower abdomen. That one bike sitting convinced me to wait a couple more weeks. At six weeks I could feel a somewhat uncomfortable sensation when I sat down too firmly on a hard surface. But, at seven weeks I was surprised to find I could sit on the WTB Silverado saddle with no discomfort. I had dug out an older, wider, softer saddle my wife used a long time ago Just in Case but did not need to use it. I was most worried about urine leakage and bladder control as the weeks went by and my control did not improve as quickly as my physical well being. I am most pleased that the "not minor" leakage is not going to be a problem during the months it takes me to regain full bladder control. My surgeon stressed that 98% of his patients who have had similar amount of tissue removal and nerve damage as did I will eventually regain almost full control. He did say that stress leakage might be a long term problem but I will learn to exert more positive and thoughtful/willful muscle control. He reminded me that the old autonomic sphincter control is not enough for men like me. Good luck with the recovery and please do not rush things for a short term gain and potentially long term adverse consequences.

Posts.Title: Post RALP bicycle riding and Leakage - turns out to be no big deal

Posts.Content: I am a life time cyclist and measure most days by the quality and duration of my bicycle adventure. Being off the bike for 7-weeks after my surgery has been a trial. I am happy to report that just 49-days after my surgery I was back on the bicycle and riding as if the surgery never happened. I hope other serious bicyclist will find the thread in the future and take comfort in my experiences, all of which have been positive. My comments get a little "bike geeky" and cover some of the details bicyclist who do a hundred miles a week worry about. 48-Days after the surgery I was given permission to return to "all normal activities." I specifically asked the surgeon about strenuous street bicycle riding with a hard narrow saddle and dropped handlebars. He cautioned me "not to be stupid - but if it does not hurt then it is OK to do it. Just ease into it and give your body a couple weeks to get used to the effort again." I have ridden five times since then and feel no pain, discomfort, or any other sensation that indicates the surgery or missing parts have any adverse impact on my ability to ride or the comfort of riding. Three rides were on a 26" wheel front suspension and very stiff Specialized aluminum mountain bike and two were on a stiff 700c Specialized carbon fiber road burner. I use the same saddle on all my bicycles and it is on the "hard narrow" side of things. My cardio-vascular conditioning fell way off during the 7-weeks of only walking and light exercise after the surgery. I have eased back into the riding but have done two rides with an average heart rate over 130 and max at 165. I have tried spinning at max, which for me is about 108 RPM. I have pushed a big gear for several minutes at 160 bpm heart rate. AND... have felt no indication of any soreness, loss of strength, or pain, stiffness, or soreness in my abdomen and groin. As I said - except for the poor cardio condition - I feel like the surgery never happened and my shorts feel just as normal as before I discovered Prostate Cancer. Most of the time I can control my bladder until it almost fills and then semi-gracefully find my way to the toilet and release the flow with a modicum of control. However, I do "leak" a lot due to stress such as laughing, coughing, standing up, bending over, sneezing... and many other little things. I dribble out less than an ounce per hour to a little more than two ounces per hour but many nights go almost all night with no leakage. I was very concerned about the leakage and how it would impact my longer and more intense bike riding. Turns out to be a non-issue and the leakage is hardly noticeable while riding. I am a traditionalist on the bike and wear Lycra bike shorts (tights) or baggy mountain bike shorts. I tried using Depends Men's shields in the baggy shorts but they were not comfortable and did not stay in place. I completed all the rides with men's Depends max absorption briefs under either the tights or the baggy shorts. Once I put them on and start riding - everything automatically adjusts and I hardly think about the briefs being there. I am riding in Florida where it is 90-degrees or so each day and the humidity is over 55% so I SWEAT - A Lot! I weight my Depends briefs after each ride and find they gain about 4-ounces an hour while riding. I know I sweat out about 12 or so ounces per hour and the entire brief is soaking wet, as are my shorts so I suspect that my urine leakage is more like 2 or 3-ounces per hour. I am only aware of the Depends briefs when I try hard to think about them. I find no indication of chafe or other adverse skin effects after even two hours non-stop on the bike. This is a key point because I was very worried that wearing bulky briefs under Lycra shorts with a synthetic chamois would surely cause chafing and irritation as I spin at 85 - 95 RPM continually. As far as I can tell the briefs are not a problem! I can feel a little "warm dribble" occurring during certain riding conditions: - standing up to sprint causes a little dribble as I spring off the saddle and make the first surge - riding over speed bumps knocks loose a dribble or two (even if out of the saddle) - sudden change in pedal load such as moving to the big chain ring - bouncing on the saddle when spinning at high RPM and getting out of synch with the pedals After about 7-hours of riding I am now confident that the RALP surgery will turn out to be a total non-issue for my future bicycle riding. EVEN IF my bladder control never improves! I expect to regain full bladder control in the next six-months but I am relieved to know even if my leakage problem continues by bicycle riding will hardly be impacted. Being able to issue this report has really freed my mind of many concerns because bicycle riding has always been a huge part of my wife and I's life and I now know it can continue to be.

Posts.Title: Post RALP bicycle riding and Leakage - turns out to be no big deal

Posts.Content: T1c/Grade II / medical urologist says "unfavorable intermediate but doesn't matter because of high PSA density" surgeon urologist says "favorable intermediate" radiation oncologist says "intermediate intermediate but it doesn't matter because it is intermediate with high PSA density" The RP -or- EBRT+LDR Brachy -or- LDR Brachy monotherapy all seem to depend on the probability of Exta Capsular Extension (ECE) My radiation oncologist recommends 3 to 6 months ADT, 37 to 44 EBRT treatments, and LDR-Brachytherapy He also wants a 2nd opinion read on the biopsy and recommended Hopkins. I was pushing for ONLY LDR-BT. My .55ng/ml/ml PSA density and a 100% 1.4cm 3+4 and 60% 2.0cm 3+4 specimen are worrisome, as they were to my medical urologist, who gave me a 50% proabability of ECE, and my RALP surgeon who things the chance of ECE is less than 35%. Thus, the need for EBRT. Radiation doc, thinks the ADT could also be helpful due to the 35% probability of extra-capsular extension . Is there anything a 2nd opinion can due to resolve the ECE probability? My 3T mpMRI report clearly states the "capsule is intact" and "No extracapsular disease." Specificity of the MRI reading for ECE exceeds 75% in most studies, which says to me there is less than a 1 in 4 chance of ECE. That probability seems to be critical in the decision making path. All the recent literature indicates that ADT is indicated when there is a significant risk of ECE. A 2016 talk by Dr Juanita Crook clearly states the decision about LDR-BT as a monotherapy in a G7 (3+4) patient rests on ECE probabilities. AND... if I have more than a 1 in 3 chance of ECE THEN - a RALP surgery would almost certainly be followed by EBRT or at least ADT so why bother with the RALP? How does one resolve this Extracapsular Extension/Disease question?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Just based on the volume, type, and time in the oven, I'd assume ECE. Whether it has metastizised or not is the big question. The serious question, imo, is surgery and radiation or radiation. You want to use the hormone therapy if offered. I agree completely - so I keep asking myself "why bother with the surgery IF the radiation is a certainty?" Might as well just go straight to glow in the dark and become a post-menopausal female

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I'll let others comment on the stats. If you do opt for a RP, remember that you are not looking and interviewing for Dr. Average Stats. There are excellent, highly experienced surgeons with excellent urinary outcomes as well as some Just-Starting-Out-Haven't-Quite-Got-the-Hang-of-It ones. Yes that is an important observation and surgeon experience was not a controlled or analyzed variable in the JAMA QOL study. Here are two biggish names Patel (2011) reports on 1,111 RALP patients with an average 12-month continence rate of 96%. Shikanov (2010) reports on 1,436 RALP patients with an average 12-month continence rate of 69%. How does one verify the data / success rates / side effect percentages provided by my particular surgeon? My urologist, board certified surgeon and urologist, no longer does prostatectomies. He referred me to D. Ornstein in Bonita Springs, FL. Ornsteins website says he began doing RALP procedures in 2003 and has done thousands since then. So, I can assume the proper experience. How do I verify the results? My urologist says fewer than 4% of Ornstein RALP patients experience urinary incontinence at 24-months. They both work for the 21st Century Oncology which has many practices in many states. Trust but Verify - HOW?

Posts.Title: New QOL study has much higher RP incontinence percentages than I find elsewhere

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic OTS, with regard to ECE prediction: (If any Abstracts look promising, you may want to look into getting the Full Text.) Thanks so much for the fantastic assistance! I'd seen a couple of those articles but not most of them. I guess the big question is what is my Tumor Contact Length? I will try to get the radiologist to reexamine my mpMRI to give me some more information. The "map" provided with the biopsy report shows the 100% (3+4) specimen to be 14mm and located next to the capsule and the 20mm specimen in the Lateral Apex to be 60% (3+4) and next to the capsule. I wonder if radiologist can use that info to estimate TCL? An issue raised by the radiation oncologist about those specimens is the distinct possibility the needle penetrated the capsule a bit and includes some periprostatic tissue. That seems unlikely to me and also seemed to be a bit of "salesman" talk also known as FUD when I was doing support for MegaMillion dollar software sales (Fear-Uncertainty-Doubt make the potential client scared enough they believe you are their savior) SO MUCH to think about! But, at least it is fun and interesting to deal with all this technical stuff and once again bury myself in analyzing research and statistical validity. Your assistance is so appreciated. I am shortly off to get the CT scan (pelvis & abdomen) with contrast and whole body bone scan. Hopefully they will not change my status and will allow me to continue this fantastic decision making process.

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: The pains you describe sound very similar to what I experienced post-RALP. First it was dull pain in upper left quadrant, which was scary due to cardiac concerns. It then moved closer to my left shoulder and became more intense and felt very much like my dislocated shoulder/broken clavicle pains. A day or so later it moved to my right quadrant in the mid-rib area and felt like my previous broken rib episode. I saw my surgeon on day 6 post-RALP and discussed the pains with him. Apparently there are multiple theories about the pain: - referred pain due to gas pressure on nerves in the diaphragm area - actual pain in the area it is felt due to gas pressure in the shoulder or rib area - actual pain in the abdomen area that the brain mis-interprets as being from upper chest or ribs due to all the trauma in the lower abodomen His recommendation (he has done over 1,600 RALPs and another 1,000 other robotic urogenital procedures) was WALK - WALK - WALK! He was correct - I started walking 1/4 mile day five, 1/2 mile day seven, 1/2 mile twice on day 10.... and the pain moved around more, diminished, returned and by day 15 was just a distant memory. BUT - then my biggest incision for the "gas port" in my lower right abdomen started really aching as I stretched and walked. Again - surgeon says "I moved a lot of stuff, I cut a lot of stuff, I traumatized a lot of stuff in your abodomen, especially where we cut access holes - it will take a couple months before all the aches and pains are gone." And it was! At 3-months post RALP I was back to hard bicycle riding, long walks, and sailing my big boat. Patience and a reasonable expectation of various pains, aches, discomfort will get you thru the recovery.

Posts.Title: Transient pain under rib cage and shoulder day 5&6 post RALP

Posts.Content: I am currently 9-days post RALP done by surgeon with 1,600 prior cases experience. He said he thinks he did no damage to any nerves. I am not quite understanding my incontinence behavior and would like someone with experience to explain what I am experiencing. - Dry all night - Can start/stop/hold urine stream on demand with little effort - Dry sitting or walking if I am not stressing abdomen or pelvis and I make conscious effort to stop urine stream - ANY little stress, (laughing, coughing, farting, bending over too far) causes serious dribbling that I can stop with some effort - Standing up from chair causes major leakage that I might or might not be able to stop depending on bladder fullness Standing in shower, relaxed and upright, my penis dribbles at a steady rate. I can easily stop the dribble by flexing the appropriate muscles and I can keep the stream shut off with a continued conscious effort. But, as soon as I relax my mind/sphincter (?) the dribble returns. My understanding of all the above is that I have a good nerve path from brain to sphincter but the brain is not sending a steady "pinch that thing off" signal to the external sphincter unless my mind wills it to do so. Will that autonomic/no conscious effort signal return eventually? Is progress dependent on my muscles, nerves, brain learning a new skill similar to learning to throw a curve? I have been conscientious doing my Mayo and UCLA kegels and feel I have excellent control of the urine stream with an overt effort. What do I need to do to regain that same control with no conscious thought? I am not impatient and am fine with not getting full control back for months. I do want to confirm there is not something else I can be doing to make faster progress. thanks for any advice

Posts.Title: Question for you DRY guys post RP

Posts.Content: I have many questions about the interpretation of post-RP PSA values and what prognostic information those PSA tests provide. In the following I summarize some of the information and literature I have found useful. Anything in italics is a direct quote from the article I am summarizing or paraphrasing. Here is a Literature Review titled: Biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy: what does it mean? January-February 2018 International Brazilian Journal of Urology This is a concise but complete summarization of all the literature and research about BioChemicalRecurrence (BCR) conducted from the mid-1990 thru summer 2017. Much of what I summarize below is taken from this article. I highly recommend the IBJU article to all post-primary treatment PCa patients. The article discusses many of the issues involved with interpreting PSA scores after primary treatment. For example, something very important for me: "Positive surgical margins (PSM) PSM alone is not associated with higher risk of PCa mortality, although it increases men’s risk of BCR in 2 to 4-fold and need for secondary therapy" ************** Single Best Study: Natural history of progression after PSA elevation following radical prostatectomy. JAMA. 1999 "An excellent report of natural history of BCR was given by Johns Hopkins’s researchers. They performed a retrospective review of almost two thousand men that underwent RP for localized PCa who had not received adjuvant hormonal treatment before documentation of metastasis. Patients with good response to radiotherapy after BCR were also excluded. After a mean follow-up of 5.3 years, BCR (PSA =0.2ng/mL) was observed in 15% of patients at a median time of 2.3 years and 34% of them developed metastatic disease. The median actuarial time to clinically evident metastasis after PSA elevation was 8 years and it was dependent on GS 8-10, PSA-DT <10 months and time to BCR after RP. The likelyhood of metastatic disease was 37% in 5 years among those men who had presented BCR. Forty four percent of patients with metastatic disease died due to PCa. Actuarial median time to death after development of metastasis was 5 years. Death time was only influenced by time to metastatic disease after RP" ************ SHOULD WE ADDRESS BIOCHEMICAL RECURRENCE OF PROSTATE CANCER AS SOON AS POSSIBLE? IN FAVOUR European Oncology & Haematology, 2018; "Approximately 15–40% of men will develop recurrent disease following an attempt at curative therapy for prostate cancer. Some of them will develop metastases after a median time of 8–10 years. The predictors of metastasis are Gleason score of 8–10, pathological stage T3b-4, nodal invasion and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) doubling time. One can anticipate that about 10% of patients with recurrent PSA will develop systemic progression and that 5% will die from prostate cancer more than 10 years after radical prostatectomy and more than 6 years after the biochemical recurrence." ************ Biochemical (prostate specific antigen) recurrence probability following radical prostatectomy for clinically localized prostate cancer. J Urol. 2003 Han and colleagues evaluated 2.091 men submited to RP without adjuvant radiotherapy for a median follow-up of 5.9 years. Recurrence (PSA =0.2ng/mL) was noted in 17% of patients. Overall actuarial 5, 10 and 15 year BCR rates were 16%, 28% and 39%, respectively. Same years rates for metastatic disease were 4%, 11% and 19% and for PCa specific mortality 1%, 4% and 11%, respectively The last sentence above seems to say that if left untreated, BCR leads to metastatic disease symptoms in about 1/5 of the occurrences of BCR within 15-years, and about half (1/10 of RP patients) of those with symptoms die from PCA/metastatic disease within 15-years. ************ Long-term risk of clinical progression after biochemical recurrence following radical prostatectomy: the impact of time from surgery to recurrence. Eur Urol. 2011 Ten-year rate of PCa systemic progression ranges from 10% to 19% for patients who experienced BCR >6 years or <1.2 year after RP, respectively. ************ Comparative effectiveness of radical prostatectomy and curative radiotherapy in localized prostate cancer: long-term follow-up J of Radiation Research 14 Nov 2016. 248 RP and 182 EBRT patients were followed for at least 10-years. The number with NO Biochemical Recurrence (PSA > 0.2 twice) was as follows. 48-months 78% RP & 88% EBRT 96-months 72% RP & 80% EBRT (percentages did not change much after 8-years) ************ 10-Year Outcomes After Monitoring, Surgery or Radiotherapy for Localized Prostate Cancer N Engl J Med 2016; 375:1415–24 1,095 PCa G6 or G7 patients treated with either RP or RT monitored for 10-years 92 suffered "disease progression", which was undefined. I interpret that to mean almost 92% of the men receiving a single primary treatment did not have clinical disease symptoms after 10-years. ************ Do Ultrasensitive Prostate Specific Antigen Measurements Have a Role in Predicting Long-Term Biochemical Recurrence-Free Survival in Men after Radical Prostatectomy? J of Urology Feb 2016 754 men wiht PSA < 0.1 ng/ml post-RP. Eleven years after RP 86% of men with PSA nadir < 0.01 had no BCR but 49% of men with PSA nadir >0.01 experienced BCR. 93% of the men who had NO BCR had a PSA nadir <0.01. Amling and colleagues analyzed the use of various PSA cut point definitions for determining biochemical progression after RP in 2001. They evaluated the percentage of patients with a continued PSA increase after each cut point to define the most appropriate PSA level to determine disease progression. Progression of PSA rates were 49%, 62% and 72% after reaching PSA levels of 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4ng/mL, respectively. I guess that means that half the men with a post-surgery PSA <0.2 do not continue to experience an increase in their PSA score.

Posts.Content: You can read my PSA history in my signature I am having a hard time getting the 1st biopsy scheduled - I posted two rants about that problem here... but the important thing is that==> My urologist just sent me an e-mailing saying that even with my dire PSA, free PSA, 4KScore, MRI results it will be no problem if my biopsy is postponed for another month while my open ankle wound heals. He called while I was writing this and reassured me that even with those scary (to me) numbers there is no rush to biopsy let alone treatment. "things move slowly in the PCa world" was his parting words based on 22-years of practice after a 4-year resident program.

Posts.Title: elevated PSA at age 52

Posts.Content: Your situation sounds very similar to mine at age 57 and after Age 57 PSA 2.0 - my long time, (and non-confrontational), internist said "no big deal but we'll keep and eye on it" Age 63 PSA 4.0 - my internist said the same thing again Age 63 PSA 5.8 - I told myself that the increase was a fluke and the value would decrease again Age 65 PSA 4.5 - my internist was a little more concerned but the 2012 guidelines seemed to indicate PSA testing should be avoided or ignored because I had no familial PCa occurrences and no symptoms of any kind Age 67 PSA 5.6 - I told myself this is a repeat of what happend four years earlier so I ignored it Age 68 - Age 70 - Too busy sailing and bicycling full time to think about PSA and PCa Age 70 PSA 9.2 - my NEW (loud outspoken New Yorker) internist was very concerned and forced me to see a urologist Age 71 PSA 10.2 - my urologist says "get the biopsy now!" I will have said biopsy next week and let you know then IF my choice to ignore the ever increasing PSA value was a wise choice. At this time I am wishing, now that I understand a biopsy is no big deal!, I had had a biopsy at age 66 or earlier. This forum has been a wealth of information and has guided me to a world of important PCa diagnosis and treatment information on the web. If I had known that information at age 63 I would have had the first biopsy at that time. I now believe, contrary to back then, that a biopsy has few objective risks and many potential benefits.

Posts.Content: I am 71 and had a robotic assisted radical prostatectomy done in late August this year. The recovery was 100% non-eventful. I was up walking in 8-hours, home from the hospital in 36-hours, and walking miles around the neighborhood in 3-days. Seven weeks after the surgery the robot man told me I could resume all normal activities including sailing my 40' boat and riding my very stiff carbon fiber bicycle with a small hard saddle. It is now 10+ weeks since the surgery and I feel as if it never happened. I spent the last three days digging up the irrigation/sprinkler system in our yard and other than being a little tired and sore in the evening, I don't feel any effects from the surgery. At least for me - surgery in my early '70s was not problem. The wild fluctuations in the PSA score are quite unusual. Is EVERY PSA test done at the same lab using the same equipment? If not - then comparing those numbers is less than useful. My PSA fluctuated quite a bit (+ and - 25% of so) over a period of 4-years but never like your husband's. When I had PSA scores in the 4 to 5 range at ages 63 to 66 I dismissed them as not important and thus delayed my treatment by a couple years. That delay will probably lead to the eventual need to have radiation therapy at some point in the next five-years.

Posts.Content: The authors state: “Owing to the heterogeneity of the studied populations and measurement of prognostic factors, we did not report on a pooled HR for the different prognostic factors. Rather, the meta-analysis is an exploratory analysis to attempt more complete insight into the most strongly associated prognostic factors.” I summarized the various individual findings about prognostic indicators just for my personal knowledge but figured that many other men here probably are in the same situation as me: SM+, EPE+, non-Zero PSA, waiting for that all important 3-month Post RP PSA score. In the following summaries you will find capitalized initials: DM = Distant Metastasis PCSM = Prostate Cancer Specific Mortality (patient died from PCa) OM = Overall Mortality (patient died regardless of cause) HR = Hazard Ratio (factor showing number of BCR patients experiencing effect (DM or PCSM) due to a factor or treatment compared to patients with NO factor or treatment) For example, A HR of 1.0 for the DM effect for Positive Surgical Margins means the percentage of patients with a particular factor (e.g. SM+) experiencing an effect( e.g. DM) is not different than a patient without that factor (e.g. SM-). An HR of 2.0 for DM in SM+ patients would mean that twice the percentage of SM+ patients experience DM as do SM- patients. HR is the key indicator in this study. RP = Radical Prostatectomy (used as primary treatment) RT = Radiotherapy (Radiation of any kind used as primary treatment) IBF = Interval to BCR following initial treatment ((definition of BCR varies study to study) PSA-DT = PSA Doubling Time pGS = Pathological Gleason Score MY SUMMARY OF THE SUMMARY is stated by the authors (IMHO): “Based on these analyses, in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment, the main prognostic factor for DM, PCSM, and OM was short PSA-DT. For patients who underwent primary RT, clearly the strongest prognostic factor for DM, PCSM, and OM was a short IBF.” The following are ALL quotes from the article UNLESS I label it My Comment. What I consider Good News is in a different font Here are what I consider the important summary quotes from the section titled: “3.4.2 Prognostic factors for oncological outcomes in patients who develop BCR.” 3.4.2.1 AGE For PCa-specific outcomes (DM and PCSM) and irrespective of the primary PCa treatment (RP or RT), age is not an unfavorable factor with HRs ranging from 0.98 to 1.02 for the development of DM and 0.96 to 1.05 for PCSM, with only two studies showing a small, but statistically significant unfavorable effect of increasing age 3.4.2.2. Initial PSA. Initial serum PSA (iPSA) levels prior to primary treatment were not uniformly found as a prognostic factor for any of the investigated outcomes. 3.4.2.3. Gleason score. For patients undergoing primary RP, a higher GS identified on prostatectomy histology report (pGS) is a strong prognostic factor for oncological outcomes in most studies. My Comments about G Score: RP men were 1.2 to 14.4 more likely to have DM and 1.4 to 10.8 times more likely to die from PCa depending on the G Score. RT men’s factors were 1.7 to 3.7 for DM, 2.1 to 14.8 for PCSM. And very disturbingly, to me at least, RT men were 1.8 to 17.9 times more likely to die from any cause, depending on the Gleason Score. The increasingly large HR correlates well with ever higher Gleason Scores. For example, RP men with BCR & G7 (3+4 and 4+3) are between ~5 and ~11 times more likely to have DM than men with BCR & G6 pathology. 3.4.2.4. T category. Increasing T category at prostatectomy histology report (pT category) is not clearly associated with any of the oncological outcomes for patients undergoing RP. For RT, four out of six, three out of seven, and two out of six studies showing a significant correlation between cT category and DM, PCSM, and OM, respectively. 3.4.2.5. Positive surgical margin. For patients who underwent RP, two out of eight studies showed an inverse relationship with DM (ie, “a protective effect”) and none of the eight studies investigating PCSM as an outcome showed a significant correlation 3.4.2.6. Interval to biochemical failure. For patients undergoing RP as primary treatment, IBF was associated with DM in two out of six, PCSM in eight out of 11, and OM in one out of four studies, respectively. For patients undergoing RT as primary treatment, IBF had a clear association with oncological outcomes, with five out of five studies, five out of seven studies, and five out of six studies showing a strong association with DM, PCSM, and OM, respectively. Although studies repeatedly reported this association, the effect size was less interpretable due to the use of different thresholds. However, it is clear that the shorter the IBF, the higher the risk of developing DM, PCSM, and OM after both RP and RT. 3.4.2.7. PSA-DT after radical treatment. There was a clear association between PSA-DT after primary therapy and oncological outcomes, being most pronounced in patients who underwent RP as primary treatment. All reported studies showed a significant correlation between shorter PSA-DT and DM, PCSM, and OM. The shorter the PSA-DT, the higher the risk of developing worse oncological outcomes. Similarly, for patients who underwent RT, the limited number of studies consistently showed that PSA-DT was a risk factor for DM. 3.4.2.8. Salvage RT. Four studies included salvage RT (sRT) as a covariable in their MVAs, of which three studies showed a significant impact on survival outcome. These data suggest that a PSA cutoff of 0.4 mg/l that keeps increasing is probably indeed a good definition for BCR and that initiating sRT based on this definition is probably desirable. Eleven studies investigated only patients who received sRT. For these patients, pGS remained a strong predictor for DM and to a lesser extent for PCSM. In two out of four and four out of five studies investigating IBF in their MVA for DM and PCSM as outcomes, respectively, this was significant. PSA-DT was only investigated by one study and showed a significant effect [33]. Closely related were the PSA levels before initiation of sRT, which showed to be a significant predictor for DM and PCSM, More about SRT from the Clinical Implications Section: In this study, in patients with PSA-DT <6 mo, sRT with or without ADT resulted in a reduction of PCSM with HRs of 0.14 to 0.24. In contrast, in patients with PSA-DT>6 mo, sRT with or without ADT had no prognostic value with HRs of 0.66 to 0.85. My Comment: Section 3.4.2.8 is not easily summarized but for me the conclusion is that early SRT (within 2-years of BCR) significantly diminished the possibility of DM and PCSM when PSA-DT < 6-months. When the PSA-DT > 6-months the benefit of SRT is less easily distinguished or quantified. The addition of ADT does not seem to change the outcome. The authors discuss 15-studies involving SRT but it is hard to generalize any result other than early SRT is good if the PSA-DT is less than 6-months. 3.4.2.9. Salvage ADT. A limited number of studies report on the prognostic effect of salvage ADT (sADT) after RP or RT. No conclusions can be drawn from the RT patients outcomes after ADT because of the contradictory results and the lack of Hazard Ratios being reported. My Comment: The PCSM (patient died from PCa) HR’s for RP followed by ADT vary from .83 (patients who received ADT did a little bit better) to 1.09 (patients who did not receive ADT did marginally better). ALL studies found that RP patients who received ADT did far worse when looking at OM (overall mortality), with the HR being 0.55, which says an ADT patient is almost twice as likely to die as one who does not get ADT.

Posts.Title: Fluctuating PSA

Posts.Content: But the authors do say: Although we acknowledge that a prognostic study design is not the appropriate study design to investigate the therapeutic effect of a certain treatment, it shows that not all patients with BCR are equal in outcome and therefore should not receive the same treatment. As an example, if a PSA rise of >0.2 ng/ml is confirmed in a patient after primary RP, the pGS is <=7, and if PSA kinetics are favorable (PSA-DT >12 mo, IBF >18 mo), patients should be informed that they have low-risk BCR and the potential toxicities of additional treatments should be discussed to allow the patient to make a well-informed decision. Which, to me at least, implies the patient should be carefully notified of the tradeoff between Low Risk of future clinical symptoms of PCa and the known toxicities of SRT. If the authors did not want the patient to consider delay or non-treatment, then why would they want the patient and treatment team to discuss the topic?

Posts.Title: Nineteen Week Good News

Posts.Content: My surgeon (1,600+ RALPS) said he did not do frozen sections. Prior to surgery he told me: "I take as much tissue as possible consistent with saving nerves and blood supply. The pre-surgery Gleason score, PSA, biopsy findings, MRI findings tell me the likelihood there is malignant tissue outside the prostate tissue and I excise tissue based on that information. Frozen sections don't really provide any more useful information." In my case I ended up with a 2mm G6 focal positive margin at the apex. The surgeon did not want to dig any deeper there in the hope of saving some function. Post surgery he told me the tissue did not appear dangerous and he felt my quality of life outweighed the very small likelihood that positive margin would lead to future PCa extensions. However, (isn't there always?), during his post surgery pathology review appointment with me he also said "Due to the positive surgical margin I suspect there will be radiotherapy in your future." Only time will tell which of his assessments was correct.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Sailor, in the Subforum, Thread (C) , #9 has two studies specifically on indeterminate or equivocal PIRAD 3 lesions with statistics and suggested follow-up. (There is a link to the full text of the first paper if you want more detail than is in the Abstract.) Djin - thanks for the great reference. I had not yet gotten around to looking at the sub forum. What a wealth of information! London & Melbourne Study - 196 biopsies on men with PI-RADS 3 - 70% found to have some cancer on biopsy - 27% Gleason (3 + 4) - 2% Gleason (4 + 3) - 2% Gleason 8 Doesn't seem encouraging...BUT... (my favorite word in Statistics) ~ 9% of Men with NO lesion on MRI had Gleason (3 + 4) on biopsy (so how did they get a PIRADS 3 score?) ~37% of Men with 1 lesion on MRI had Gleason (3 + 4) on biopsy ~56% of Men with 2 or lesions on MRI had Gleason (3 + 4) on biopsy So - it appears a biopsy is in my future!
