Posts.Content: 11:20 PM Comfortable end to long day! Went for 15-minute walk at 9:15 PM ( 11-hours from start of RALP). Used a walker but only ‘cause nurse did not trust me at first. Very little pain, more like hard tugging feeling, while sitting and then standing. Walking was easy with no pain from incisions and big dull ache above pubic bone. I was able stroll along at about 75% of normal hot weather in Florida/don’t work up sweat speed. BUT - after 10-minutes started feeling serious, then scary pain in Left shoulder...by the time I retuned to room it an eye-watering 9 of 10 stabbing and burning. RN checked pulse and BP - all OK. Laid down and pain slowly diminished. RN says “most likely residual CO2 that moved around and is not uncommon.” Now, two hours later, all gone. I feel great with little to whine about. Urine, lots and lots urine because I am on third saline bag and drunk another 40-oz water, is almost a normal yellow with just a touch of stylish, “girly?” Pink. RN says that is great but unusual. Sure hope tomorrow goes as well so I can go home. No swollen belly from CO2. RFNA (robot guy) talked with me for 1/2 hour before surgery - just chatting about technology. They were using, new this week, a CO2 machine, which monitors CO2 pressure in pelvis area and automatically adjusts it. It also sucks OUT vapors and fumes from cauterisation to provide very clear srgical field. And, it sucks out almost all the CO2 after work is done. Supposed to almost eliminate gas pains and post op swelling. Seems to have worked for, almost.

Posts.Title: Live from Room 427

Posts.Content: My urologist is on vacation for July so would appreciate any observations you can make. 3T mpMRI with Dotarem IV contrast (to provide Dynamic Contrast Enhancement - DCE) on June 28. Following are quotes from the printed report I received today. Findings: 18cc prostate Subtle area of T2 signal hypointensity and mild restricted diffusion at apical posterolateral PZ measuring 1.0 x 0.6 x 0.7 cm Remainder of gland is unremarkable Capsule intact Impression: 18cc volume with an Equivocal 1.0 x 0.6 x 0.7 cm left posterolateral PZ and apical lesion. No exttracapsular disease PI-RADS 3 INDETERMINATE I've spent a lot of time the last week learning about MRI physics, techniques, and interpretation and think I understand it fairly well, for a novice layperson. I've gone thru the American College of Radiology (ACR) PI-RADs presentation ( https://www.acr.org/-/media/ACR/File.../PIRADS-V2.pdf ) and have studied the PI-RADS Version 2: A Pictorial PDF published by the Genitourology Imaging publication. Update1 My Understanding of the report - I have a quite small and unremarkable prostate ( 18cc ) - only one area of possible concern measuring 0.42 cc located in peripheral zone - the area of possible concern produced a low intensity T2 signal that was not so obvious ( "subtle" ) - the DCE contrast fluid did not flow into the area of concern as easily or in as much volume as adjacent area, during the same sampling interval, but the diminution ( "restricted" ) of diffusion was limited ( "mild" ) - the 0.47 cc lesion can not be clearly characterized ( "equivocal" ) Due to the presence of a lesion of "equivocal" characteristics and limited diffusion (DCE) a P-RADS 3 score is given " PI-RADS 3 = the presence of clinically significant cancer is equivocal" is the definition found in the ACR presentation IF there had been extensive DCE diffusion in the lesion the score would have been a PI-RADS 4. I am inclined to see this report as good news. - relatively small lesion ( < 0.5cc) - subtle hypointensity - mild restricted diffusion - no clear indication of malignancy Will my urologist, who seems to be quite conservative (tries not to) about ordering a biopsy, order one for me when I see him late in July? Maybe the 4KScore results will now play a larger part in the biopsy decision. OR - am I just being too optimistic in my interpretation of a PI-RADS 3 score and trying to see only the plus side?

Posts.Content: RALP began 10:15 AM -wife met me recovery at 12:15 PM. Moved to private room 1:O0 PM. Very little discomfort as of 7:30 PM with NO pain meds so far. The only serious pain is a heavy ache in right side when I laugh! How bad can it be when laughter is my big complaint? Right side is where they put a larger hole just above the liver to extract the prostate. About 3PM I experienced some heavy pain that was about a nine out of 10 for 20 to 30 minutes. It turned out to be a blood clot in the catheter that was preventing urine from flowing and the bladder had filled up. I have many bits of plumbing coming and going from arms, hands, belly, and other personal items. The RN used one of those special ports and plumbing loops to flush the blood clot and within 10 minutes all of the pain was gone. The hospital staff wanted me on a liquid diet this evening but my surgeon came in at 4 PM to check on me and said I could have A full dinner. So I was able to eat a wonderful hospital prepared chicken breast, mashed potatoes, green beings, and cooked carrots. The only annoying part of the process so far has been my extreme dry mouth. Since 1 PM I have drunk over a gallon of freshwater and had two IV bags run through me but my mouth still feels like it is full of desert sand. I just ate 4 ounces of very nice cold vanilla ice cream and that seems to have cured much of the dry mouth. I am not allowed ice cream at home per my wife/nutritionist but she had sympathy for me here and let me have a treat! I’m lying here in bed very comfortable and in far less pain than after a normal hard afternoon on the bicycle. The nursing staff is overly busy but says they will take me for my first walk sometime later this evening. I’m looking forward to the walk because I feel so good I want to get up and do something. You guys who are wondering about radical prostatectomy, mine was robot assisted, should not worry about any of the immediate surgery or post immediate post surgery issues if my situation is typical. I sure hope I am not jinxing my short term recovery by talking about my incredible lack of problems and pain but I did want to share this with those of you who are concerned about RALP procedure. The surgeon was very optimistic - he said he completely spared the right-hand nerve bundle and felt he did not do too much damage to the left hand nerve bundle and did no damage at all to the necessary arteries and veins.

Posts.Title: Live from Room 427

Posts.Content: Does seem that a biopsy is necessary! Journal of Urological Oncology March 2016: 288 mpMRIs (?T) July 2010 - April 2014 followed by 14-core Transperineal biopsy with TRUS PI‐RADS v2 score of 3 and PSA density of ≥0.30 ng/mL/mL, was associated with the highest clinically significant prostate cancer detection rates (76–97%) on the first biopsy. Of the patients in this group with negative biopsy results, 22% were subsequently diagnosed as prostate cancer. The median patient age, PSA level, prostate volume and PSA density were 69 years, 7.5 ng/mL, 28.7 mL, and 0.26 ng/mL/mL, respectively. The biopsy results were benign, clinically insignificant, and clinically significant prostate cancer in 129 (45%), 18 (6%) and 141 (49%) patients, respectively. My PSA is 30% higher than average and PSA Density almost twice their average. Maybe I can grow a bigger prostate in the short term to get that PSAD down?

Posts.Title: MRI Ambiguity or ??

Posts.Content: My wife had an appointment today with our PCP / Internist, which I attended. After the doc wrote the Rx for my wife she turned to me and said - "Your PSA could not have been better." She then checked her computer and handed me a slip of paper with 0.021 written on it. My 6-week follow up appointment with my surgeon is next Tuesday, Oct 9 but my PCP was copied on the PSA lab results from my blood draw yesterday and she knew I would be anxiously waiting for the results. I asked her to confirm the 0.021 and she looked again at the lab report to confirm them. She did say "you could not hope for better results at 6-weeks!" I AM concerned because I had to call my surgeon on Monday morning to ask them to fax the PSA test request to my local lab. At that time I asked the surgeons front desk person if it would be µPSA test and she replied "Yes - it will be a standard PSA test." I am not sure how my local lab could have sent the blood to Lab Corp or Quest mid-day Tuesday (blood draw was 11 AM Tuesday) and the results be back to my PCP by 2 PM Wednesday. UPDATE: Just talked to my surgeon's PA who confirmed it was a 3-digit µPSA test with a 0.021 result.

Posts.Title: Seems to be Very Encouraging News about future PCa treatment - no surgery/no radiatio

Posts.Content: RALP Surgery scheduled for tomorrow (August 23) at 10:00 AM if I believe the surgeons nurse or 10:30 AM if I believe the surgery scheduling nurse at the hospital. I need to check-in at 8:45 (hospital statement) or 8:00 AM (surgeon statement). Why trying to determine the schedule the surgeon nurse casually mentioned: "Oh - we have not received the EKG, Chest X-Ray, blood work clearance from your GP. If we don't receive that information within 2-hours (90-minutes as of this writing) the surgery will be cancelled. I've talked to your GP's nurse three times and each time she says she will send the information immediately. " I immediately called my GP but am not allowed to talk to doctor or nurse. Left message with front desk who said someone will call me back. My GP's nurse just called and says my RALP surgeon has never talked to them and has never requested a medical clearance. She is not sure she can get the FAX sent this afternoon. She is now calling the RALP office. And, now I find that the RALP "First Assistant" (RNFA) will not accept assignment from Medicare. But, I am supposed to get a form from my RALP surgeon guaranteeing the RNFA will only bill me $250, of which Medicare and Blue Shield Supplemental will pay NOTHING! And, being new to SW Florida we did not know that Ft Myers has a morning rush hour and I need to plan an EXTRA hour on the freeway so our normally 75-minute drive may take up to 2.5 hours. I hate to get up in the morning but I guess we need to plan on leaving the house before 6 AM. Pre-surgery jitters are not diminished by this stuff!

Posts.Title: Great Yearly Follow Up Results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Is there a study that defines the overtreatment concern? Do we really know? A partial answer (copied from a post I made elsewhere): A 2013 study, published in Molecular and Clinical Oncology, followed 200 RP patients for a median of 52-months to monitor their µPSA values and post surgery progression toward biochemical recurrence (BCR), which was defined as two consecutive PSA tests with a value > 0.2 ng/ml. 94% of the patients (183) with a PSA nadir of < 0.008 had not experienced BCR at a median followup time of 52-months. Sixtysix (66) of those patients who reached a nadir of <0.008 subsequently progressed to have a PSA > 0.008 4+ year followup. Thirtythree (33) of those 66 patients never exceeded a PSA value of 0.05 in the 52-month followup. That means almost 52% of the patients whose PSA value rose above the 0.008 nadir never exceeded 0.05, which is only 1/4 of the definition of BCR. The author's characterized those 33-patients as having a PSA transition pattern of "peaking out." Their pathology characteristics are not real great. 46% of them were T3 or greater, 30% were G8 or greater, and 21% had positive surgical margins. That says to me that we can start with a very low PSA value post surgery and show some significant increase in the PSA values while not coming close to BCR (PSA > 0.2 twice) in over 4-years. I have read some other studies looking at progression toward BCR but have not yet found them. Your question is always in the forefront of my PCa thoughts!

Posts.Title: Simple a Simple Act and it brings Such Joy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 So I have seen a local Uro and a Cleveland Clinic Uro. The local Uro knows I have been to CC and who I have seen at CC when I arrive today for a some urinary issues and a consultation. He does a very good job explaining things lasting about an hour. I ask hm what he believed the odds of cure with surgery. The value given was 2x what I expected him to say based on my research. To some extent I believe I was getting a sales job. What are your experiances? My Medical Oncologist/Urologist with 25+years experience and over 1,000 prostatectomies under his hands, before he quit doing surgery, refused to cite any "CURE" numbers. Every time I or my wife asked he insisted there is no CURE - there are just increasingly less frequent PSA tests after a prostatectomy and an increasing probability I will die from something other than PCa as I get older and time goes by after the surgery. He explained that many of his long time surgery patients do eventually experience biochemical recurrence but it is of little concern as they age. He reminded me that the median time from the 2nd occurrence of a 0.2 PSA test, post surgery, to the onset of metastatic disease symptoms is over eight years and the median time to death is another five years. Have you plugged your numbers into the Memorial Sloan Kettering (MSK) nomogram for pre-radicial prostatecotmy patients? I assumed you were 65-years old and had a T1c clinical stage given your biopsy results. That nomogram gives you a 99% chance of NOT dying from PCa in 10-years and 98% in 15-years. It also calculates a 50% chance of NO biochemical recurrence (MSK BCR is 0.05 ng/ml or greater) in 5-years and only a 34% chance of NO recurrence in 10-years. Please consider that many oncologists will not recommend Salvage Radiation Therapy (SRT) until you have two consecutive PSA >0.2 tests. If your PSA gets to 0.05 MSK considers it BCR, BUT, if your PSA increases at .02 per year you'd have 7 more years until SRT might be necessary. So - what do you consider to be a definition of CURE relative to your situation? How do those numbers compare to what the clinic or your doctor reported? The MKS nomogram also provides the odds of the cancer: - being organ confined - extra capsular extension - lymph node involvement - seminal vesicle invasion

Posts.Title: Prognosis, do you believe your doctor?

Posts.Content: During my 2nd discussion with my urologist about "what to do if PSA keeps increasing but we find NO PCa on the biopsy" he clearly stated: "I've many patients who are LEAKERS - they have abnormally high PSA values and we never find any lesion, tumor, or non-normal cells in their biopsies. Some men just secrete larger than normal amounts of PSA into their blood stream. We don't know why that happens nor do we know what it means. But, I'm comfortable with just conservatively monitoring their status. I've never had a single one suddenly develop an aggressive PCa and I've never had one who suffered any negative consequences of just tracking the PSA and doing a biopsy every couple years.." OTH - he did order a 3T mpMRI and 4KScore for me to help determine IF I need a biopsy. He is a strong advocate of using the 3T MRI images, annotated by the radiologist, to guide the sample needles when doing a TRUS 12-core biopsy. He claims to find more than 90% of the PCa lesions with those guided biopsies. He is 52-years old and has been a board certified urologist for 22-year. He claims many thousands of biopsies and "never a lost soul due to suddenly aggressive PCa he missed by taking a conservative, non-invasive path when appropriate." I asked several more questions about leakers with high PSA counts and how to live with the uncertainty. He again stressed "trust me - I've seen a lot of men with and without PCa and we'll make sure you are well cared for"

Posts.Title: My Uro Wants Another 3T MRI

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 ... Personally see about zero chance of negative margins. Staging for last Urologist was T2B. .... Q. Am I too pesimistic on hopes of negative margins? I too obsessed over surgical margins and have read everything I can find about them. And, have played endlessly with nomograms which incorporate surgical margins as they predict biochemical failure, disease progression, and life expectancy. As with almost every thing else I have learned about PCa since my initial PSA=9.2 in May 2018 - the more I learn the less I know. Current research about the interpretation of surgical margins and their prognostic value after an RP is confusing and inconsistent. For Example (the following use my specific pathology reports and assume 12-months post RP progression from 0.02 ng/ML to 0.2 ngl/ml PSA). the Memorial Sloan Kettering (MKS) nomograms: - Death due to PCa post RP with NO additional therapy gives the SAME probability of death due to PCa at 5 - 10 - 15 years (4% - 13% - 20%) when I tell it there were surgical margins and then tell it there were NO surgical margins. https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/pros...cal_recurrence - Probability of NO additional PCa progression for 6-years following a PSA = 0.2 a year (12-months) following RP is 71% when there are surgical margins present and only 61% when NO surgical margins were present https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/pros...iation_therapy - Probability of NO future Biochemical Recurrence in 2 - 5 - 7 - 10 years is 88% - 69% - 61% - 52% with surgical margins and extraprostatic extension - Probability of NO future Biochemical Recurrence in 2 - 5 - 7 - 10 years is 94% - 85% - 80% - 74% with NO surgical margins and extraprostatic extension and just to show how much those BCR free progression numbers depend on other factors - here they are for SM+ EPE- and SM- EPE- - Probability of NO future Biochemical Recurrence in 2 - 5 - 7 - 10 years is 90% - 79% - 73% - 65% with surgical margins and NO extraprostatic extension - Probability of NO future Biochemical Recurrence in 2 - 5 - 7 - 10 years is 96% - 91% - 87% - 83% with NO surgical margins and NO extraprostatic extension AND Of course - the probability of DEATH from PCa within 15-years varies from 1% to 2% with changes to Surgical Margin and Extraprostatic Extensions. https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/prostate/post_op A recent research project concerning the prognostic value of biochemical recurrence said the following about surgical margins: "Positive surgical margin. For patients who underwent RP, two out of eight studies showed an inverse relationship with DM (ie, “a protective effect”) and none of the eight studies investigating PCSM as an outcome showed a significant correlation" All the details are in the thread: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...c-Value-of-BCR I have now decided that the only thing I can do for the next ten or so years is monitor my PSA and prepare a mental plan for dealing with an increasing PSA value - IF it were to occur. Trying to read tea leaves, or surgical pathology reports does not help me prepare for the 50% probability I will experience biochemical recurrence in the next 15-years so I am trying to learn to live PSA test to PSA test. One last thought- the more I learn post RP and the more I talk with my medical oncologist - the more importance genomics / genetic testing is coming to play in my thinking and decision making process. PSA dynamics describes what is currently happening and genetics gives me the most possible information about where that PSA change may ( will ?? ) take me in the subsequent years.

Posts.Title: Post RALP Path Report - Not as clear, or more "positive" than I wanted

Posts.Content: I am now a Biopsy Evangelist singing the praise of the life saving diagnostic tool! Here is a practical example showing how much fairly serious cancerous tissue can be missed with a 3T mpMRI. June 28 3TmpMRI with Dotarem contrast. The images were read by a very experienced radiologist who has done thousands of MRI studies for my urologist: "There is a subtle area of T2 signal hypointensity and mild restricted diffusion at the apical left posterolateral peripheral zone measuring 1.0 x 0.6 x 0.7 cm. REMAINDER OF THE GLAND IS UNREMARKABLE. Capsule is intact." Capitalization is mine for emphasis. That meant, IMHO, that only 0.42cc of my 18cc prostate contained cancerous tissue. The August 3 TRUS 12-Core biopsy found that ALL 6-cores (Every one!) from the left lobe contained Gleason 6 or Gleason 7 cells. A 1.4cm core was 100% Gleason 7, a 2.0 cm core ws 60% Gleason 7, and a 1.8 cm core was 20% Gleason 7. The ENTIRE tumor identified by the MRI was only 1cm long and ~0.6cm in the other dimensions. Yet two of the Gleason 7 samples had far more than 1cm of cancerous tissue! The 100% and 60% Gleason 7 cores were from the tumor identified by the MRI but the other 20% Gleason 7 core was from an area the MRI displayed as not abnormal. ALL Gleason 6 cores (3 total) were from areas in the prostate that the radiologist noted as "unremarkable." I am very happy that my urologist did a Free PSA and 4KScore blood test in order to give me more evidence to convince myself that a biopsy was necessary. I had read studies, and the urologist warned me before the MRI, that some big percentage ( more than 50% ?) of low and intermediate grade tumors can be missed in a 3T mpMRI. The significance of that warning was not apparent last month when it seemed I had only a "tiny" 0.3cm area of concern. Now, I can more fully appreciate the problem of missed low and intermediate grade tissue. Two months ago I was a biopsy sceptic, my many forum comments from May and June now embarass me, but am now a proud supporter of the Another approach to biopsies: Git 'er done Stupid!

Posts.Title: 3T mpMRI missed ALL 3 of my Gleason 6 and One of my Gleason 7 hot spots

Posts.Content: I hope my providing the following summary is OK - it is exciting for me to read about these wonderful new ideas that will stop the growth of PCa without surgery or radiation. Thanks to Todd1963 and the great article about his treatments that led me to start exploring this new and ongoing research. Summarized in MedicalXpress (https://medicalxpress.com/news/2019-...te-cancer.html) Quotes are from Professor Fahri Saatcioglu at University of Oslo's Department of Biosciences who heads the research team publishing in Nature Communications. "We think that what we found is really exciting. We have shown that a new small molecule drug called MKC8866 has very good effect on the growth of prostate cancer cells both in cell culture and in animal experiments, and we are already planning clinical trials with humans. We expect these trials to be carried out in Scandinavia and Western Europe," "Now we have used MKC8866, which was developed for other purposes, and shown that it inhibits the signal pathway and oncoprotein activation. Thus, it also inhibits the growth of prostate cancer tumors both in vitro—cell culture—and in vivo—in mouse prostate cancer models,..." This progress is a result of basic and translational research that has been going on for about 10 years," Translation research is a type of medical research that aims to translate knowledge from basic research into practical application in patient treatment. "There is a lot of effort by many people internationally over many years that is behind these findings. I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the students, employees and partners who have participated in various parts of this and the organizations that have supported us financially. If we succeed in the clinical trials, and I think we have good chances, we can have a new medicine developed in about five or six years," A little more background: "All cells in the body can experience different forms of stress from time to time, and the cancer cells are under extra stress because they have to grow fast while having trouble getting enough oxygen and nutrients. Therefore, the cancer cells "hijack" the normal cells' stress response mechanisms and use these for their own benefit to survive. We have found a way to block this 'hijacking' and thus the cancer cells can no longer cope. So they die," Detailed in Nature Communications (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-08152-3) ABSTRACT Activation of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress/the unfolded protein response (UPR) has been linked to cancer, but the molecular mechanisms are poorly understood and there is a paucity of reagents to translate this for cancer therapy. Here, we report that an IRE1α RNase-specific inhibitor, MKC8866, strongly inhibits prostate cancer (PCa) tumor growth as monotherapy in multiple preclinical models in mice and shows synergistic antitumor effects with current PCa drugs. Interestingly, global transcriptomic analysis reveal that IRE1α-XBP1s pathway activity is required for c-MYC signaling, one of the most highly activated oncogenic pathways in PCa. XBP1s is necessary for optimal c-MYC mRNA and protein expression, establishing, for the first time, a direct link between UPR and oncogene activation. In addition, an XBP1-specific gene expression signature is strongly associated with PCa prognosis. Our data establish IRE1α-XBP1s signaling as a central pathway in PCa and indicate that its targeting may offer novel treatment strategies. Critically, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis of MKC8866-treated or XBP1 knockdown PCa cells revealed that IRE1α-XBP1s is essential for c-MYC signaling, a central oncogenic regulatory pathway in PCa12,13. These results establish IRE1α-XBP1s signaling as a potential target for alternative treatment strategies for PCa.

Posts.Title: Still cannot get the biopsy scheduled

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Have you absolutely ruled out surgery as an option ? Is there some reason surgery is not an option for you ? RALP is currently my chosen treatment. I meet with the RALP operator tomorrow afternoon (Monday Aug 13). I got the order to proceed to immediate treatment on Friday afternoon (Aug 10). My wife, my urologist, and I spent an hour discussing my PCa and treatment options. At that time I verbally committed to RALP - get the bad stuff out, get the PSA to 0, and don't look back. I am still holding to that commitment. But, I have been frantically studying the many measures of survival and side effects for external and internal radiation just to make sure I carefully and objectively consider all the options. Some of those options would take me out of town - thus this question. The more I study the more it seems that external radiation (various forms) and RALP are pretty much equal in the various measures of survival out to 15 or so years. The side effects seem to break down as follows: RALP - Side effects begin at treatment, are well known, and will probably not change in the future RT - Few immediate side effects, are less clearly established, and will probably increase over time.

Posts.Title: Logistics & Planning for 9-weeks treatment far from home

Posts.Content: EXACTLY My experience: "Once it's out, expect it to take 3 to 6 months to recover "full" urinary continence. I say "full" because there will always be a bit of stress leakage when you stress your abdomens doing something. Measure progress week by week, not day by day as some days will be better than others. The first thing to come back is staying dry overnight. The next thing is staying dry while doing normal daily activities. The last thing to improve is leakage doing things that compress or stress the abdomen." In 3-days (Dec 23) I will be 4-months post-RALP. My Depends now stay almost bone dry 11 PM to 11AM. But, as soon as I start doing any activity requiring bending or pressing on my abdomen - I dribble or leak a bit. Hard work, e.g. yesterday afternoon replacing five landscape light bulbs that required bending and digging, will cause me to leak a ounce or two per hour. Another funny one is dishwashing or teethbrushing. If I lean forward against the counter and let it press into my abdomen - leaky/leaky. Don't let the bad/leaky hours or days disturb you as you progress. Four or five weeks ago - After I started being bone (not yet!) dry all night I thought my pad wearing days were over. I then went thru several afternoons reversion to leaking several ounces per hour followed by 12 or more hours of no dribbles. That was very frustrating but I now understand that the periods of extreme leakage become less and less frequent. For me at this point - it has been five-days since I leaked more than an ounce an hour, and that occurred while working under/over the car while installing new driving lights. I am a numbers guy so six-weeks post RALP I bought a nice digital scale that can accurately measure 0.1 fl oz up to 32-fl oz (by weight). I have weighed every pad and Depends since them and plot the ounces/hour number over time. I also plot the trend line. It is reassuring to a geeky statistician to see the trend line headed downward and the 90-percentile line (90% of previous 20 pads) trending downward at even a steeper rate. And, those 2-ounce per hour peak leaks are becoming less and less evident. I expect to be almost completely continent, except for sever bending, pressing and lifting before the Super Bowl and am pretty sure I will be almost completely dry under all conditions by Easter.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Good luck OTS! Keep in mind that the above guidelines to NOT apply to you today! At time of surgery, your PSA was likely > 4x normal. With a 1/2 Life of approx 3 days, your PSA level might not yet be < 0.03ng/ml. If not today, may your 3 month post RP PSA be < 0.03ng/ml! MF My surgeon said he does not do a µPSA at 6-weeks. He will decide later about the µPSA at 3-months. 10.2 PSA at time of surgery 0.5^9*10.2=~0.02 9 (half lifes) x 3-days (half life of PSA) is about 27 or so days. Today was 40-days so I am really hoping to see <0.1 when I get the results Friday or Monday. My appointment with the surgeon is Oct 9. I read and read about the Zero Club but did not really understand the significance of membership until about 3-weeks after the RALP and I began to appreciate how much my short term future depends on that <0.1. Now I do so hope I qualify for at least a short term membership!

Posts.Content: My CT scan says "Mild prostatomegaly with no evidence of metastasis ..." "Dr Daniel J Bell ◉ and Dr Henry Knipe ◉ ◈ et al. Prostatomegaly is a term used to generally describe enlargement of the prostate gland from whatever cause. Usually the prostate is considered enlarged on imaging when it measures beyond 30 cc (30 grams) in size. " Yet the MRI and TRUS biopsy stated I had an 18cc prostate and my urologist (with 26-years experience) initially noted "a quite small and soft prostate" after the very intense DRE. HOW can there be two such different measurements of the prostate size? One of the key reasons I was promptly moved to surgery was the PSA density of .58 ng/ml/ml but the CT scan would cut that value almost in half. The CT scan report does not change anything but I am curious about the different estimates of size.

Posts.Content: Djiin Tonic - MY thoughts exactly. What you so elegantly (?) stated is exactly what I had in mind as I asked the questions. I will review the studies you mentioned. Standard Errors, Standard Deviations, Repeatability, Confounding...etc were my professional life for many years and I do appreciate your concerns. My subjective impression is the MO wants to prepare me mentally/psychologically for the future need to make some decisions and he is trying to make me think now, while I have time and little pressure, about choices in the future. During our detailed discussion I felt like he was not totally committed to the need for SRT but wanted me to know it might be a hard choice in the future. Additionally, his attitude / experience with SRT seemed to me to be "minimal side effects and minimal long term consequences" so WHY NOT do SRT at some point just to be sure of a cure? He did say "you chose surgery and the side effects. You are young (??) and healthy so why wouldn't you want to take the next step of SRT to ensure a positive and life long good outcome?" I did not feel any pressure from him to choose now. He did stress that things move slowly at this stage and waiting to begin SRT is a perfectly reasonable choice. SO - just to continue my "It is a life time journey with many twists and turns" - it appears to be more twisted now than before. But, I've accepted the uncertainty and can happily wait 3 - 6 - 12 months to see what I next need to do.

Posts.Content: My RALP was August 23, 2018 with first PSA test Oct 3 showing 0.021. Next test scheduled for January 19, 2019 which will be five months post surgery and will again be a 3-digit µPSA test done by Lab Corp. The info above is per my surgeon who has done more than 1,600 RALPs in the last 15-years. His card says Urologist/Oncologist and his practice is part of 21st Century Oncology corporation. My medical urologist/oncologist wants me to have an µPSA test in early December because he wants that 3-month number, which is becoming the standard for prognostic information. The medical onocologist, (who has done thousands of open prostatectomies since 1996 but quit doing surgery when RALP became so popular) is my original diagnostician and will become my go to guy for any additional PCa diagnosis and treatment. His practice is also part of the 21st Century Oncology corporation. SO - both doc's have the same intent to use a µPSA (3-digit) test but different ideas about intervals. Their primary concern is my positive surgical margin and extra prostatetic extension. They both expect BCR within 4-years.

Posts.Title: Two Quick Questions regarding PSA test

Posts.Content: Fourth post-RALP appointment with Medical Oncologist 30-weeks after surgery PSA prior to RALP 10.2 up from 9.2 3-months earlier RALP August 23, 2018 Focal EPE and Focal SM+ G7 (3+4) Lab Corp µPSA 0.021 at 6-weeks 0.018 at 18-weeks 0.022 at 30-weeks Surgeon at 10-days post-RALP told me radiation therapy would be "required within 6-months" due to EPE and SM+ Surgeon at 6-weeks postponed SRT until PSA shows a consistent rise but to "expect it within 6-months" MO at 18-weeks said there was "no need to consider SRT until PSA shows consistent rise over 3-months" MO at 30-weeks (April 10, 2019) "plan on SRT before end of 2019" Details that led MO to plan for SRT within a year: EPE (even if it is FOCAL and G6) SM+ (even if it is 2mm FOCAL G6) µPSA increase from 0.018 to 0.022 in 3-months There is no reason the PSA should increase IF ALL the PCa cells were removed. But, the confusing factor is "psuedo-PSA" or "PSA-analogue" produced by cells in the urethra. At the 0.00x PSA level it is possible to detect the analogue version of the PSA. However, there is NO reason the amount of analogue will increase over time. The 0.004 INCREASE in my µPSA is indicative of some remaining PCa tissue. We will wait 3-months and get another µPSA test. I asked about the 6-week 0.021 PSA value and the fact that the 30-week value (0.022) has just returned to the 6-week value. The MO answer was that PSA has a 6-week half-life and the 0.021 could have been remaining from prior to the RALP. The 18-week decrease to 0.018 would indicate that at least some of the 0.021 was "old" PSA. The 30-week rise/increase should not occur if all the PCa was removed. I asked about standard error of measurement for µPSA and he told me Lab Corp does not provide that information. And, it doesn't really matter because he cares about the TREND rather than the absolute value. I tried to pin him down to numbers and he refused to play. He ordered another 3-month µPSA test. If the July 2019 test shows any increase above 0.022 it almost certainly means I will experience SRT in the not distant future. But, as to actual initiation of SRT - there is no rush so if the July test shows a small increase (0.005 or less?) he would probably wait another 3-months. But, his experience is that, even at the µPSA levels, three consecutive increases, even in the third digit (0.00X) inevitably leads to BCR and the need for SRT- "You have no remaining non-cancerous tissue, which can increase the amount of PSA over time so any consistent increase in the PSA level, no matter how small, must be from PCa tissue that was missed during the surgery" He wants to wait until at least 10-months post-RALP because a 71-year old needs 9-months healing time to recover from the RALP. He does not want to irradiate tissue that is still healing because it leads to strictures and fibrous growth. The longer I wait post surgery - the fewer SRT side effects I will experience. Whatever level of continence (almost 100% dry except when playing pickleball - my opponents "piss me off") and sexual function (semi-firm) will be retained if the SRT begins after 10-months post-RALP. He says the Radiation Oncologist will make all the decisions about type of SRT and imaging prior to radiation. But, his experience, (the MO and RO work for the same national practice 21st Century Oncology), is that no high tech imaging will be done if we start SRT at PSA <0.05 because none of it can detect metastasizes at such a low level. The MO did also say that SRT technology is progressing at a very rapid pace and the longer I can wait the better the results and fewer the side effects. Asked him about ADT or any other hormone or chemical treatment prior to or with the SRT and he was quite definite - NO- NONE! My G7 (3+4) and small focal EPE & SM are not indicative of the need for anything in addition to SRT. The radiation therapy will almost certainly be a near cure or provide me enough time to die from anything other than PCa. Bottom Line for me is that SRT is inevitable but I want to delay it as long as possible.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maldonado57 Has anyone tried the 4K Score blood test as an alternative to having a prostate biopsy? YES and it quickly CONFIRMED the need for a biopsy! You can see my path from not knowing how to spell prostate in mid-May 2018 to a RALP in late August. My medical urologist/oncologist insisted I have the 4KScore test done in mid-June after my PSA went from 9.2 May 18 to 10.2 June 18. He knew the 4KScore results would be the last test I needed to convince me that a biopsy was needed NOW! 4KScore showed a 34% (1 in 3) chance of clinically significant cancer and sure enough the August 3 biopsy found 3 of 12 samples at G6 and 3 at G7 (3+4). PLEASE NOTE: As late as July 20 I was still resisting the idea of a biopsy for all the typical but wrong reasons. The 3T mpMRI gave me hope the biopsy would not be needed but the 4KScore and the PSA Density (.57 ng/ml/ml) was enough to push me into the biopsy room. And...the RALP pathology report confirmed that the surgery was necessary and should have been done several years earlier.

Posts.Title: 4K Score Blood Test

Posts.Content: I can identify with your anguish and understand the overwhelming sense of "what happened and what do I do now?" After years of watching my PSA move around and choosing each time to "wait for more information" - this spring my PSA jumped to 9.2 and then 10.2 the next month. I've had more tests and a 3T mpMRI to confirm the presence of a quite small "equivocal" tumor in my prostate. My biopsy will be on Friday August 3. When I started posting here in late May, in much the same mental state you seem to be, I found the forum to be very informative and helped me gain some degree of relaxation and peace of mind. You will hear from a lot of very knowledgeable men who have a lot of important experience. My urologist, 26-years in practice with a state of the art diagnostic and treatment facility, urged me to remember that nothing moves rapidly in the world of prostate cancer. He cautioned me to take my time and learn as much as I could. He is also adamant, very outspoken, that many, a high percentage, of men with prostate cancer are over treated. He has been treating prostate cancers for several decades and he is convinced that his fellow practitioners are far to eager to cut and irradiate. He is a both a board certified surgeon (one fellowship) and a board certified urologist (different fellowship), but he is apparently opposed to surgery except in dire circumstances. He wants to do my biopsy 'cause my 4KScore, which he recommended, says I have a 34% chance of a significant cancer despite his knowing the tumor is very small. Then, he wants to get genetic tests on the tumor samples, IF (Big IF!), the pathologist sees any undifferentiated cells. Then (IF a Gleason 7 or more), he wants to take OUR time to discuss the treatment options. He stressed we have plenty of time to make an informed decision that is specific to my health, life expectancy, and my wife's wishes. At all three appointments I've had since early June he has reassured me that "I've never lost a patient to prostate cancer by waiting, being thoughtful, and being conservative while trying to minimize the impact of treatment" SO - I would not rush off to that surgeon just yet

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed and overwhelmed

Posts.Content: There are many statistics about PCa progression after biochemical recurrence (BCR). But, let's just use the simple ones found in the Johns Hopkins research paper about the Natural History of BCR after prostatectomy and with no additional hormonal therapy. At 5.3 years post surgery 15% of men had BCR (PSA > 0.2ng/ml) The median (half the times were less and half were more) time to BCR was 2.3 years Eventually 1/3 of those men developed metastatic disease (About 1 in 20 of the original study group of prostatectomy patients) The Median time to metastatic disease symptoms was 8-years About half (actually 44%) of men with metastatic disease died from the disease (About 1 in 40 of the original study group of prostatectomy patients) The Median time to metastatic disease death was 5-years AFTER development of symptoms (About 13-years after initial PSA > 0.2) As others have mentioned - your life expectancy and Quality of Life is critical in the SRT / ADT / HT Yes or No? decision making process. All the the life expectancy calculators I've used give me at least another 20-years and I expect them to be good years. My father and I went for a 3-mile hike in the Everglades on his 89th birthday and he felt great doing it. SO - for me it seems I should do everything possible to fight the renewed growth of PCa IF I experience BCR. The recent post describing two brother's current SRT and HT therapy with few side effects has been very encouraging for me. They make it sound like SRT & HT can be experienced with a minimal degree of suffering and long term effects. Yet another reason to plan on additional treatment if BCR does occur. Several surviving partners of men who died from Metatstatic Prostatic Cancer disease have posted threads here describing the last two years of their partners journey to death. It sounds like a horrible way to die and is also very hard on the surviving family. I've promised my wife, 8-years younger than me and from a family where all the women live to be older than 95, I will outlive her. Thus I have a strong incentive to submit to whatever additional treatment I need to delay or deny PCa return. I've written several more detailed threads about BCR and prognosis, which summarize much of the research I've found. Here is one link: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-RP-prognosis

AgeInfo.Phrase: the disease  About 1 in 40 of the original study group

Posts.Content: Saved by the e-mail! Hospital nurse who schedules surgery called to say she would have to cancel the surgery due to lack of paperwork for medical clearance. I asked for her FAX number and another 10-minutes to call my GP and have the stuff faxed directly to the hospital. She gave me her FAX number and then said "Oh - wait - here is an e-mail from your surgeon" That e-mail did contain all the necessary clearances. But, they have now moved the check-in up to 7:45 AM and she said to plan on a 3-hour drive at that time of morning. That makes no sense because if we leave home at 5:30 AM we will be thru all the bottlenecks by 6:30 AM. The first 20-miles of the drive is on wide open I-75 (85 mph) in the wilderness of SE Charlotte County where there is no on/off ramp for 14-miles. A nearby suites hotel will give us a good rate but my wife has decided we should leave at 5:30 AM and make the best of it. The scheduling nurse did say that if I called her at 7:45 AM and said "I am on I-75 10-miles north of the hospital she would allow me until 8:15 AM." I am pre-registered and they have all the insurance, emergency contact, etc so getting there 90-minutes before surgery could work. And so on and so on...

I called her at 7 45 AM and said  I am

Posts.Title: Why can't it be easy?

Posts.Content: One more update to help those considering RALP understand the short term effects / life after RALP. RALP 10:15 AM - 12:15 PM Thursday and it is now noon Saturday. I left the hospital at 4 PM Friday and drove myself 61-miles home. I know that is not recommended but I had had no pain medications and felt like I had a clear head. I had taken three longish walks in the 12-hours prior to leaving. And, we were experiencing a monumental tropical downpour and lightning storm. My wife has only driven our new car one time previously and really hates to drive on the freeway in rush hour traffic, let alone in blinding rain. And, she was totally freaked out because two lightning bolts had hit trees in the parking lot while she was trying to find the car. The main point is that driving a nice new automatic auto with a catheter and bag is no big deal. Fatigue, and overwhelming desire to just lie down and stay still is the main way to describe my current situation. I went to bed last night at midnight and did not move again, literally not a muscle, until I convinced myself to get up at 10 AM. This morning I struggled to the kitchen and made two cups of very strong Starbucks Sumatra. It is only five steps from the coffee pot to the recliner in front of the 72" TV but, once I settled in the chair with the first cup, it was just way too hard to stand up again and get the 2nd cup. No pain, little discomfort but WAY TOO much effort was required to lift my self out of that nice electric recliner! After 20-minutes contemplation I was able to standup and get that 2nd cup and a couple peanut M&Ms. I was a bit over optimistic about the lack of gas pains and the benefit of the robots new de-gassing device. I have experienced several unpleasant gas episodes where my stomach becomes hugely swollen but walking and making loud rude noises resolves the issue. A couple of times, sitting on the toilet, I wished I had a seat belt fastened because I thought I was going to experience toilet seat liftoff! The surgeon told me he believes the sharp shoulder pains, I've now experienced it several times in both shoulders, is a "referred pain." They are pretty sure the gas in the abdomen pushes up on the diaphragm which irradiates nerves and the brain interprets that nerve signal to be shoulder pain. It is disconcerting at first but quickly diminishes, especially after passing gas. The only consistent discomfort I have experienced is in the big incision in my right side near my ribs. It really pulls and is quite uncomfortable when I try to cough. Learning to deal with the catheter and bag is an experience. The small bag the nurse strapped to my leg at discharge is hard to deal with, especially in a recliner. I hooked up the big "overnight" bag last evening before going to bed. It has a 48" tube and a carrying handle. I find it much easier to just carry that bag as I walk and then lay in on the floor when I sit down. The main problem with the smaller leg bag was the velcro straps the nurse used were ineffective and the bag kept dropping down my leg. That meant the tube in my penis kept getting tugged and caused leakage and a bit of pain. I've now got the long tube strapped to the thigh with that reusable elastic double sided sticky tape you get after they draw blood. Holds everything very secure and is comfortable. I was concerned about living with a catheter and bag but, as others told me, it is no big deal and convenient to not have to get up to pee every so often. Draining either bag is simple and quick. I have absolutely no appetite and have to work hard to eat stuff like yogurt, chopped fruit, and banana. I am sitting at my computer desk, banging away on the keyboard and feel almost normal, except for the fatigue.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I never said stupid. No you didn't but I did and it needed to be said. I now see the 2012 NO Screening recommendation as an invitation for men like me, (know it all techno-nerds), to ignore marginally bad PSA results and to convince themselves the biopsy is needless, invasive, and counter productive to a good life. My Internist in 2012 and 2013 did not press the subject and try to convince me that a 5.6 PSA at age 63 needed further investigation. She made me aware of the No Screen advice and I used that NO Screening advice to allow myself to do NO more screening for FIVE years, which resulted in a 9.2 then 10.2 PSA result.

Posts.Title: 3T mpMRI missed ALL 3 of my Gleason 6 and One of my Gleason 7 hot spots

Posts.Content: Here is an interesting factoid that might help with decision making: In patients with localized prostate cancer, the 5-year survival approximates 100%; however, in patients in whom distant metastases have occurred, the 5-year survival drops to 31%. Like most other solid malignancies, prostate cancer can metastasize to distant organs such as the liver, lungs and brain, but it has an unusually high propensity for metastasizing to the bone. In one autopsy study, approximately 80% of the men who had died from prostate cancer possessed bone metastases. Most current treatments for individuals with bone metastases have only palliative effects, with little effect on long-term survival International Journal of Cancer June 2012

Posts.Content: RALP began 10:15 AM -wife met me recovery at 12:15 PM. Moved to private room 1:O0 PM. Very little discomfort as of 7:30 PM with NO pain meds so far. The only serious pain is a heavy ache in right side when I laugh! How bad can it be when laughter is my big complaint? Right side is where they put a larger hole just above the liver to extract the prostate. About 3PM I experienced some heavy pain that was about a nine out of 10 for 20 to 30 minutes. It turned out to be a blood clot in the catheter that was preventing urine from flowing and the bladder had filled up. I have many bits of plumbing coming and going from arms, hands, belly, and other personal items. The RN used one of those special ports and plumbing loops to flush the blood clot and within 10 minutes all of the pain was gone. The hospital staff wanted me on a liquid diet this evening but my surgeon came in at 4 PM to check on me and said I could have A full dinner. So I was able to eat a wonderful hospital prepared chicken breast, mashed potatoes, green beings, and cooked carrots. The only annoying part of the process so far has been my extreme dry mouth. Since 1 PM I have drunk over a gallon of freshwater and had two IV bags run through me but my mouth still feels like it is full of desert sand. I just ate 4 ounces of very nice cold vanilla ice cream and that seems to have cured much of the dry mouth. I am not allowed ice cream at home per my wife/nutritionist but she had sympathy for me here and let me have a treat! I’m lying here in bed very comfortable and in far less pain than after a normal hard afternoon on the bicycle. The nursing staff is overly busy but says they will take me for my first walk sometime later this evening. I’m looking forward to the walk because I feel so good I want to get up and do something. You guys who are wondering about radical prostatectomy, mine was robot assisted, should not worry about any of the immediate surgery or post immediate post surgery issues if my situation is typical. I sure hope I am not jinxing my short term recovery by talking about my incredible lack of problems and pain but I did want to share this with those of you who are concerned about RALP procedure. The surgeon was very optimistic - he said he completely spared the right-hand nerve bundle and felt he did not do too much damage to the left hand nerve bundle and did no damage at all to the necessary arteries and veins.

Posts.Title: Too Good to be True? PSA = 0.021 ??

Posts.Content: My wife and I live in a small village in SW Florida about 3-hours from Miami or Orlando, 2.5 hours from Tampa, and 5-hours from Jacksonville. Those appear to be the nearest facilities where I could receive one of the several newer and more advanced forms of radiation therapy that might be appropriate for my current PCa situation (T1c, Grade II, unfavorable intermediate). My current understanding, briefly mentioned by my urologist, is any of those treatments would involve eight or more weeks of daily (5-days a week) appointments lasting one or two hours (check in, positioning, treatment, check out...etc). The centers offering treatment are too distant to drive to on a daily basis so how does one manage their living arrangements during two or more months of such treatment? Do we rent a small efficiency apartment and move our lives there Monday thru Friday and drive home on the weekends? Do the treatment centers have some type of living facility for patients? It does appear that some of the radiation therapy might be available in either Ft Myers (an hour drive if the snowbirds are still in the North) or Naples (90 minute drive until after Thanksgiving). Is it practical to plan on 3-hours a day driving back and forth and a couple hours a day at the treatment facility? My wife likes to drive and would not mind doing so but five hours a day / 5-days a week for at least two months. Is that doable as side effects of the treatment progress? I would be very interested in any thoughts you survivors can offer. Our financial situation does allow us to take the most comfortable option but I am not sure how you move your life to another city for two months of daily medical procedures. Does that really work? A close boating friend of ours in San Diego lived in Yuma, AZ which is about 2.5 hours from San Diego or Phoenix (90 mph thru the desert!) where she could receive her radiation therapy for an aggressive throat and nasal cancer. They chose to move their lives to their boat in San Diego, just across the dock from us. I remember them spending about half their time for three months attending to appointments for checkups, treatment, other minor procedures, and yet more treatments. So, that is the basis/background for my question. From what I witnessed, and participated in as driver and support person, it would not be practical to do all the necessary things if those facilities are located more than an hour from the living location.

Posts.Title: Here is the news, tell me what you think

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate OTS, Thanks for all the thoughtful research, and the confounding conclusion that "the more I learn, the less I know". I, and I'm sure many others have that same dilemma. I want to confirm your statement that: "- Probability of NO additional PCa progression for 6-years following a PSA = 0.2 a year (12-months) following RP is 71% when there are surgical margins present and only 61% when NO surgical margins were present." Is that what you intended to write; or, I am I misinterpreting it? It seems to say that the probability of PCa progression is LESS if there are positive surgical margins at RP, than if there weren't any. Doesn't sound right to me. Indeed! That is confusing and counter-intuitive to me as well. I have tried the MKS nomograms many times and come up with the same result. I think the research I cited: "Positive surgical margin. For patients who underwent RP, two out of eight studies showed an inverse relationship with DM (ie, a protective effect) and none of the eight studies investigating PCSM as an outcome showed a significant correlation" is addressing the issue you raise. All I can think of at this time is that a slight rise (0.02 to 0.2) in PSA when SM+ is evident could be caused by some small amount of PCa tissue at the margin. But, if the margin is negative (SM-) then there must be some "unknown" of "hidden" PCa tissue that was not noted in the surgical pathology report and therefore leads to a less optimistic prognosis. As I said - I do a lot of reading in this area and have not found a satisfactory explanation for the result you question. My understanding of nomograms (but not the MKS ones in particular) is based on decades of professional research in the use of big data and multivariate statistics to develop predictive models for large system behavior. I can conceptualize how the MKS charts were developed and my thinking is that men with SM- develop future BCR at a higher rate independent of the other variables used in the regression equation (EPE, LNI, SVI, PSA pre/post RP, PSA-DT...).

Posts.Title: Margins?

Posts.Content: Biopsy scheduler called me back to explain in more detail the problems they are having: - the open wound on my ankle, noted by my internist, is of concern even though the internist ordered many tests for systemic infection and they were all normal and noted as such on the medical clearance form - my internist noted that EKG showed signs of LVH (Left ventricular hypertrophy ) but does not consider it a problem. I had explained to the internist that a cardiologist in 2014 did an intense 2-month study of my LVH and declared it benign and not important. But, she did not include that in the medical clearance because I did not give her the report - my internist did note that my EKG was otherwise excellent - the chest X-ray was to confirm/deny the LVH - I can have the biopsy done on Monday IF I do it without the Propofol - Or I can wait for the urologist/nurse anesthesiologist review the chest X-ray and EKG on Monday the 30th and have the biopsy later in the week I (being a wimp with a lot of positive Propofol experience) chose later in the week! We'll see on Monday if I can really get the biopsy scheduled Urologist e-mailed and called to tell me that the biopsy could be delayed a month with no concern because there is no indication that whatever my little tumor is - is aggressive or fast growing. He was busy and did not want to talk - why is my PSA density over 0.55 mg/ml? - is the PSA going from 9.2 May 18 to 10.2 June 20 important? I guess I will find out sometime after August 8

Posts.Content: Adenocarcinoma Gleason 7 ( 3 + 4 ) Grade Group 2 pT3a pNo 20% of gland involved bilaterally EPE: Present, Focal Left Posterior Apex Margins: Involved by invasive carcinoma 2mm Unifocal Gleason 3 Positive Margin: Left Posterior Apex 2mm Alll other margins: No invasion Perinuereal Invasion: Present 4 Lymph nodes examined - No involvement Seminanal Vesicle Invasion: Not identified Curiosity is that the path report identifies a 30cc prostate (ellipsoid) and 38cc prostate (bullet) with a weight of 35 grams. The DRE characterized my prostate as "small" and the MRI and TRUS calculated it to be 18cc. The surgeon looked at the report for a couple minutes and said: "well, looks like you might need radiation therapy but let's wait 6-weeks for a PSA test." Memorial Sloan Kettering nomogram gives me a 31% chance of BCR within 5-years, 48% chance of BCR within 10-years with NO radiation but a 98% cancer specific survival rate at 15-years with NO radiation. My whole attitude has changed dramatically since the RALP. The worry about side effects and the future no longer concern me. It is like "I've been through the worst now, so a little radiation is no big deal and a 98% survival rate at age 86 is a big deal."

Posts.Title: Post RALP Path Report - Not as clear, or more "positive" than I wanted

Posts.Content: Standing over the toilet STOPPING & STARTING my urine stream! I almost burst into tears because it was 5:30 AM, my bladder was full, my diapers dry, and I again had control! 6-days Post RP and 18-hours after having the catheter removed. Catheter out at 2 PM day 5 post RP and I leaked and dribbled all afternoon and evening. I soaked thru a pair of Depends Maxi pants in about three hours. I had no control and no feeling, no connection to penis or bladder. I was so distressed and emotionally distraught as I stood in the shower at 11 PM watching that steady drip, drip, drip from my penis. It continued no matter how I worked the muscles. There was just no connection at all between my mind, let alone brain, and the external sphincter. I put on dry Depends at midnight and put a double layer of waterproof cover on the matteress and a doubled beach towel on top of that. I then tried to go to sleep while thinking about the future of dribbling and leaking but ended up reading Walsh on Adjuvanct and Salvage radiation for several hours. Eventually I fell into a restless sleep but not before noting my Depends were still dry, which was enough to make me smile. About first light I woke with a strange sensation - "Jeez do I have to pee!" I carefully climbed out of bed and took the 10-steps to the toilet, dropped the Depends to find them almost totally dry,and from there it was as if a miracle had occurred. There was mind-brain-sphichter connection and I could turn the stream on and off at will. I could completely stop the stream for a few seconds then it would slowly start again. I'd let it build to full flow and clamp it off. What FUN! I suddenly remembered what it was like to be a very young boy who ran around the woods and pastures peeing on stuff (the electric fence I tried was not so much fun). Maybe the future was not going to be so grim. I write this 9-hours later knowing that I have very little control yet of the urine flow when coughing, bending, or standing too suddenly. And, I am getting a very faint "bladder full" signal. I have to remind myself to empty the bladder every couple hours. But, when doing that I can do three or four clamp off and restart exercises. Each time I visit the toilet I can clamp longer and stronger. I know everyone tells us to be patient with the incontinence issue but I had no idea how upsetting it would be for me, after only a few hours of NO control. I was devasted and assumed the nerves to the external sphincter had been damaged because of the amount of EPE at the left apex. Now that I know there is a clear signal path I can concentrate on strengthening the sphincter and learning to exert more careful control as I move around. My wife tells me the surgeon talked to me about incontinence after taking out the catheter. He clearly stated he had spared almost all the nerves and I should quickly regain continence but it might be a week or a month. I remember none of that conversation! Trust your surgeon - patience - and, I guess, listen to your wife.

Posts.Title: Simple a Simple Act and it brings Such Joy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 So I have seen a local Uro and a Cleveland Clinic Uro. The local Uro knows I have been to CC and who I have seen at CC when I arrive today for a some urinary issues and a consultation. He does a very good job explaining things lasting about an hour. I ask hm what he believed the odds of cure with surgery. The value given was 2x what I expected him to say based on my research. To some extent I believe I was getting a sales job. What are your experiances? My Medical Oncologist/Urologist with 25+years experience and over 1,000 prostatectomies under his hands, before he quit doing surgery, refused to cite any "CURE" numbers. Every time I or my wife asked he insisted there is no CURE - there are just increasingly less frequent PSA tests after a prostatectomy and an increasing probability I will die from something other than PCa as I get older and time goes by after the surgery. He explained that many of his long time surgery patients do eventually experience biochemical recurrence but it is of little concern as they age. He reminded me that the median time from the 2nd occurrence of a 0.2 PSA test, post surgery, to the onset of metastatic disease symptoms is over eight years and the median time to death is another five years. Have you plugged your numbers into the Memorial Sloan Kettering (MSK) nomogram for pre-radicial prostatecotmy patients? I assumed you were 65-years old and had a T1c clinical stage given your biopsy results. That nomogram gives you a 99% chance of NOT dying from PCa in 10-years and 98% in 15-years. It also calculates a 50% chance of NO biochemical recurrence (MSK BCR is 0.05 ng/ml or greater) in 5-years and only a 34% chance of NO recurrence in 10-years. Please consider that many oncologists will not recommend Salvage Radiation Therapy (SRT) until you have two consecutive PSA >0.2 tests. If your PSA gets to 0.05 MSK considers it BCR, BUT, if your PSA increases at .02 per year you'd have 7 more years until SRT might be necessary. So - what do you consider to be a definition of CURE relative to your situation? How do those numbers compare to what the clinic or your doctor reported? The MKS nomogram also provides the odds of the cancer: - being organ confined - extra capsular extension - lymph node involvement - seminal vesicle invasion

Posts.Title: Prognosis, do you believe your doctor?

Posts.Content: He said he wanted a CT scan of my abdomen and pelvis with and without contrast plus delays. CT scan requires you to lie still inside a large open ring that is approximately 2' deep. I am pretty claustrophobic but a 0.5mg Ativan (Lorazepam) tablet 90-minutes before the scan makes it easy for me. The contrast is injected through a small port they put in your arm prior to you going into the scanner. I was in and out of the imaging place in less than 90-minutes. The scan is to look for tissue outside the prostate that might be acting abnormally. The contrast fluid is taken up/absorbed more readily by abnormal, malignant?, cells so a greater intensity return on the image shows where abnormal tissue "might" be located. I will be having this CT scan next week and have alot of questions regarding possible outcomes. What should I expect from the CT scan? My scan was done 4-weeks AFTER the 2nd PSA test confirmed a number > 10 and three weeks AFTER a 3T mpMRI, which found a prostate tumor and was rated PIRADS 3 (not normal but of an indeterminate nature). You can see from my signature the MRI missed a whole lot of stuff. I received the CT scan results 4-days after the scan, (I had go to the imaging facility and make an in-person request for the report) and met with my urologist/oncologist a week after the scan. It was done the same day as a whole body bone scan. Both the CT and bone scan showed no abnormal tissue activity outside the prostate. The "clear" findings allowed my doctors and I to take a little more time to decide what to do. It also reassured me that a prostatectomy would have a high probability of removing ALL PCa tissue. If the scans had found abnormal tissue activity outside the prostate - then the surgical intervention might not have resulted in removal of the nasty tissue. Does this high PSA likely statistically mean cancer? There are many excellent websites explaining the possible causes of high PSA. Just start googling "high psa" or "how to interpret PSA". I chose to ignore my PSA (4.0 at age 63, 5.8 age 65) until it hit 9.2 at age 70. I wish I had learned more about the meaning of a PSA > 5.0 several years ago. ASK all the questions you want - some of us here enjoy writing and it is therapeutic on both the asking and answering side. What questions should I be asking? The "sticky" section of this forum, at the top of the page, has many threads about questions to ask.

Posts.Content: I had a nice talk with the scheduler Friday evening and it sounds like they can get me in for the "relaxed" biopsy by Wednesday or Thursday at the latest so I will keep my wimp credentials intact and go with the drugs. My annoyance is more with the paper work problems and the fact that my urologist did not explain to me that the Propofol route would require such a detailed medical clearance. I've had four propofol procedures in the last 4.5 years and not a single one of them required any kind of medical clearance so I made an assumption ( I know - bad idea!) that this one would be the same. I mean... really how different is a colonoscopy, with emphasis on the upper reaches of the lower colon, done under poropofol than a quick and easy TRUS biopsy? Well - now I know! The good news is that the biopsy scheduler told me "this is not prostate season in SW Florida because all the snow birds have gone north so our facilities and staff have open and flexible schedules." Wednesday or Thursday

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Good luck OTS! Keep in mind that the above guidelines to NOT apply to you today! At time of surgery, your PSA was likely > 4x normal. With a 1/2 Life of approx 3 days, your PSA level might not yet be < 0.03ng/ml. If not today, may your 3 month post RP PSA be < 0.03ng/ml! MF My surgeon said he does not do a µPSA at 6-weeks. He will decide later about the µPSA at 3-months. 10.2 PSA at time of surgery 0.5^9*10.2=~0.02 9 (half lifes) x 3-days (half life of PSA) is about 27 or so days. Today was 40-days so I am really hoping to see <0.1 when I get the results Friday or Monday. My appointment with the surgeon is Oct 9. I read and read about the Zero Club but did not really understand the significance of membership until about 3-weeks after the RALP and I began to appreciate how much my short term future depends on that <0.1. Now I do so hope I qualify for at least a short term membership!

Posts.Title: 9 month follow up

Posts.Content: I did not know how to spell Prostate in mid-May this year. Now, I know way more than I ever wanted to know. But, have learned I really know way less than I think I know about PCa. I understand the shock of getting that high a number and then being rushed down the path of more and more tests, each a little more intrusive. The only thing I can offer at this point is: - be prepared for frustration as you learn more about your condition you will learn there is so much more to learn - be prepared to wait, and wait, and wait some more as tests are analyzed and next steps are pondered - be prepared for a lot of seemingly contradictory information - postpone decisions as long as possible as you learn more and more - accept the roller coaster of emotions you will experience in the next few month - try to find someone, or several someone's for emotional support. Talking out your concerns, frustrations, confusions helps, even if the other person can do nothing for you - find a doctor you connect with. I do not like my oncologist but I would have none other. He is no nonsense, no BS, will not accept it from me and gives me honest and straightforward answers based on 25-years and thousands of men like us - ask question, ask more questions, then ask the really dumb questions because they are the important ones Finally - believe what the men here on this site tell you. They turned my negative thoughts around and probably saved my life. There is a wealth of knowledge and experience here. The brothers have gone thru every imaginable permutation of BPH, PCa, Incontinence, ED, fear, worry, frustration and can help you understand and cope. Be honest when writing and don't expect to be treated with kid-gloves. This is a tough love forum that will help you in ways you can not yet appreciate.

I will be having this CT scan next week and have alot of questions regarding possible outcomes. What should I expect from the CT scan? My scan was done 4-weeks AFTER the 2nd PSA test confirmed a number > 10 and three weeks AFTER a 3T mpMRI, which found a prostate tumor and was rated PIRADS 3 (not normal but of an indeterminate nature). You can see from my signature the MRI missed a whole lot of stuff. I received the CT scan results 4-days after the scan, (I had go to the imaging facility and make an in-person request for the report) and met with my urologist/oncologist a week after the scan. It was done the same day as a whole body bone scan. Both the CT and bone scan showed no abnormal tissue activity outside the prostate. The "clear" findings allowed my doctors and I to take a little more time to decide what to do. It also reassured me that a prostatectomy would have a high probability of removing ALL PCa tissue. If the scans had found abnormal tissue activity outside the prostate - then the surgical intervention might not have resulted in removal of the nasty tissue. Does this high PSA likely statistically mean cancer? There are many excellent websites explaining the possible causes of high PSA. Just start googling "high psa" or "how to interpret PSA". I chose to ignore my PSA (4.0 at age 63, 5.8 age 65) until it hit 9.2 at age 70. I wish I had learned more about the meaning of a PSA > 5.0 several years ago. ASK all the questions you want - some of us here enjoy writing and it is therapeutic on both the asking and answering side. What questions should I be asking? The "sticky" section of this forum, at the top of the page, has many threads about questions to ask.

Posts.Title: Newbie with alot of questions and concerns

Posts.Content: I did not know how to spell Prostate in mid-May this year. Now, I know way more than I ever wanted to know. But, have learned I really know way less than I think I know about PCa. I understand the shock of getting that high a number and then being rushed down the path of more and more tests, each a little more intrusive. The only thing I can offer at this point is: - be prepared for frustration as you learn more about your condition you will learn there is so much more to learn - be prepared to wait, and wait, and wait some more as tests are analyzed and next steps are pondered - be prepared for a lot of seemingly contradictory information - postpone decisions as long as possible as you learn more and more - accept the roller coaster of emotions you will experience in the next few month - try to find someone, or several someone's for emotional support. Talking out your concerns, frustrations, confusions helps, even if the other person can do nothing for you - find a doctor you connect with. I do not like my oncologist but I would have none other. He is no nonsense, no BS, will not accept it from me and gives me honest and straightforward answers based on 25-years and thousands of men like us - ask question, ask more questions, then ask the really dumb questions because they are the important ones Finally - believe what the men here on this site tell you. They turned my negative thoughts around and probably saved my life. There is a wealth of knowledge and experience here. The brothers have gone thru every imaginable permutation of BPH, PCa, Incontinence, ED, fear, worry, frustration and can help you understand and cope. Be honest when writing and don't expect to be treated with kid-gloves. This is a tough love forum that will help you in ways you can not yet appreciate.

Posts.Title: Newbie with alot of questions and concerns

Posts.Content: EXACTLY My experience: "Once it's out, expect it to take 3 to 6 months to recover "full" urinary continence. I say "full" because there will always be a bit of stress leakage when you stress your abdomens doing something. Measure progress week by week, not day by day as some days will be better than others. The first thing to come back is staying dry overnight. The next thing is staying dry while doing normal daily activities. The last thing to improve is leakage doing things that compress or stress the abdomen." In 3-days (Dec 23) I will be 4-months post-RALP. My Depends now stay almost bone dry 11 PM to 11AM. But, as soon as I start doing any activity requiring bending or pressing on my abdomen - I dribble or leak a bit. Hard work, e.g. yesterday afternoon replacing five landscape light bulbs that required bending and digging, will cause me to leak a ounce or two per hour. Another funny one is dishwashing or teethbrushing. If I lean forward against the counter and let it press into my abdomen - leaky/leaky. Don't let the bad/leaky hours or days disturb you as you progress. Four or five weeks ago - After I started being bone (not yet!) dry all night I thought my pad wearing days were over. I then went thru several afternoons reversion to leaking several ounces per hour followed by 12 or more hours of no dribbles. That was very frustrating but I now understand that the periods of extreme leakage become less and less frequent. For me at this point - it has been five-days since I leaked more than an ounce an hour, and that occurred while working under/over the car while installing new driving lights. I am a numbers guy so six-weeks post RALP I bought a nice digital scale that can accurately measure 0.1 fl oz up to 32-fl oz (by weight). I have weighed every pad and Depends since them and plot the ounces/hour number over time. I also plot the trend line. It is reassuring to a geeky statistician to see the trend line headed downward and the 90-percentile line (90% of previous 20 pads) trending downward at even a steeper rate. And, those 2-ounce per hour peak leaks are becoming less and less evident. I expect to be almost completely continent, except for sever bending, pressing and lifting before the Super Bowl and am pretty sure I will be almost completely dry under all conditions by Easter.

Posts.Title: 2nd day postop

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi OTS! The 3 month post RP PSA is pretty much the Universal Standard. It is the PSA value against which all future PSA values will be compared. I am assuming that your 2018 Healthcare Deductibles have been met and you have reached your Out of Pocket limits. If so, getting a uPSA after Thanksgiving will provide the key 3 month data point and will be free. Most importantly, it should be < 0.021 and will be able to confirm that your PSA is on a downward trajectory. Then move your Jan PSA back about 5 weeks to the end of Feb and "Voila!" you are on a Every 3 Months Program. Even if you have to pay an out of pocket fee, it should only be about $13. LabCorp can provide an estimate up front. Good luck! MF Several years ago I chose to go with a Blue Shield (at that time California and now Florida) ZERO Deductible Plan F Medicare Supplemental. I pay $212 a month for the Plan F and never have a single out of pocket expense. My knees and my heart required fairly constant attention thus I know I will always exceed my deductibles and other numbers. And that was years before I became a PCa participant. I decided the easiest way to manage all my medical expenses was to commit to the $2,544 annual payment and be assured I never receive a single bill from any medical professional. AND... my medical insurance and expenses pale compared to my wife's. She is 9-years younger than me (I married her when she was 18 but led me to believe she was 20) and still has to pay for a private individual policy. She has broken a proximal humerus, and thigh/hip during the last four years. Those repairs have required five major surgeries, each with extensive hospital stays. And, she has a fatal blood chemistry deficiency that requires a maintenance drug at $135/month. She has been on that for 10-years now and will be on it the rest of her life. All I can say is "Hope she gets old soon and can sign up for Medicare!" Her insurance premiums are $9,600 / year with OOP max of $6,900 ($6,400 deductible).
