Posts.Title: 9 month follow up

Posts.Content: I started several threads about my biopsy results and discussion today (Friday Aug 10) with my urologist. Due to my very high PSA density and very low gland size he is pushing me to immediate treatment just as your cousin is experiencing. . A key part about my treatment choices was my life expectancy, current health, and how I wanted to live my remaining years. Your cousin seems to have a number of comorbidities that do not suggest a long life expectancy. Nor does it seem his quality of life will be as high as one would want. Is he carefully considering the potential benefits, e.g. additional years of life, compared to the decreased quality of that life? The red text seemed to indicate he was aware of the trade off. I have had several Afib episodes and my father suffered dozens of Afib events requiring cardio-conversion in the last five years of his 90-year life. I do know that the blood thinner regimen puts a real strain on every other medical decision. My father experienced total remission from a very rare and typically fatal lymphoma at about age 80 and had no problem with the nasty 2-years of treatment required to get there. But at age 88 with a worsening Afib situation he chose not to take any additional invasive steps to manage the Afib. He felt the potential negative side effects were not worth whatever gain he might enjoy. Two years later he died of a non-medical condition unrelated to either his lymphoma or his heart. His choice not to treat broke my mother's and sister's heart but I totally understood his reasoning. He and I went for a long hike through a SW Florida swamp just a month before his death and he was very happy with the choices he had made. I am 71 and other than my PCa am quite healthy. Every life expectancy test I use gives me another 17 to 23 years so I am willing to take drastic steps today (RALP ASAP) to ensure PCa will not interfere with that 17+ year life. Is your cousin really in a life space (medically / physically) that drastic PCa treatment with all it's side effects will have a net benefit in what ever years he has left? I know you have thought through this stuff many times - has he or have you really talked him through it?

Posts.Title: My Cousin has Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Djiin Tonic - MY thoughts exactly. What you so elegantly (?) stated is exactly what I had in mind as I asked the questions. I will review the studies you mentioned. Standard Errors, Standard Deviations, Repeatability, Confounding...etc were my professional life for many years and I do appreciate your concerns. My subjective impression is the MO wants to prepare me mentally/psychologically for the future need to make some decisions and he is trying to make me think now, while I have time and little pressure, about choices in the future. During our detailed discussion I felt like he was not totally committed to the need for SRT but wanted me to know it might be a hard choice in the future. Additionally, his attitude / experience with SRT seemed to me to be "minimal side effects and minimal long term consequences" so WHY NOT do SRT at some point just to be sure of a cure? He did say "you chose surgery and the side effects. You are young (??) and healthy so why wouldn't you want to take the next step of SRT to ensure a positive and life long good outcome?" I did not feel any pressure from him to choose now. He did stress that things move slowly at this stage and waiting to begin SRT is a perfectly reasonable choice. SO - just to continue my "It is a life time journey with many twists and turns" - it appears to be more twisted now than before. But, I've accepted the uncertainty and can happily wait 3 - 6 - 12 months to see what I next need to do.

Posts.Title: 9 month follow up

Posts.Content: Fourth post-RALP appointment with Medical Oncologist 30-weeks after surgery PSA prior to RALP 10.2 up from 9.2 3-months earlier RALP August 23, 2018 Focal EPE and Focal SM+ G7 (3+4) Lab Corp µPSA 0.021 at 6-weeks 0.018 at 18-weeks 0.022 at 30-weeks Surgeon at 10-days post-RALP told me radiation therapy would be "required within 6-months" due to EPE and SM+ Surgeon at 6-weeks postponed SRT until PSA shows a consistent rise but to "expect it within 6-months" MO at 18-weeks said there was "no need to consider SRT until PSA shows consistent rise over 3-months" MO at 30-weeks (April 10, 2019) "plan on SRT before end of 2019" Details that led MO to plan for SRT within a year: EPE (even if it is FOCAL and G6) SM+ (even if it is 2mm FOCAL G6) µPSA increase from 0.018 to 0.022 in 3-months There is no reason the PSA should increase IF ALL the PCa cells were removed. But, the confusing factor is "psuedo-PSA" or "PSA-analogue" produced by cells in the urethra. At the 0.00x PSA level it is possible to detect the analogue version of the PSA. However, there is NO reason the amount of analogue will increase over time. The 0.004 INCREASE in my µPSA is indicative of some remaining PCa tissue. We will wait 3-months and get another µPSA test. I asked about the 6-week 0.021 PSA value and the fact that the 30-week value (0.022) has just returned to the 6-week value. The MO answer was that PSA has a 6-week half-life and the 0.021 could have been remaining from prior to the RALP. The 18-week decrease to 0.018 would indicate that at least some of the 0.021 was "old" PSA. The 30-week rise/increase should not occur if all the PCa was removed. I asked about standard error of measurement for µPSA and he told me Lab Corp does not provide that information. And, it doesn't really matter because he cares about the TREND rather than the absolute value. I tried to pin him down to numbers and he refused to play. He ordered another 3-month µPSA test. If the July 2019 test shows any increase above 0.022 it almost certainly means I will experience SRT in the not distant future. But, as to actual initiation of SRT - there is no rush so if the July test shows a small increase (0.005 or less?) he would probably wait another 3-months. But, his experience is that, even at the µPSA levels, three consecutive increases, even in the third digit (0.00X) inevitably leads to BCR and the need for SRT- "You have no remaining non-cancerous tissue, which can increase the amount of PSA over time so any consistent increase in the PSA level, no matter how small, must be from PCa tissue that was missed during the surgery" He wants to wait until at least 10-months post-RALP because a 71-year old needs 9-months healing time to recover from the RALP. He does not want to irradiate tissue that is still healing because it leads to strictures and fibrous growth. The longer I wait post surgery - the fewer SRT side effects I will experience. Whatever level of continence (almost 100% dry except when playing pickleball - my opponents "piss me off") and sexual function (semi-firm) will be retained if the SRT begins after 10-months post-RALP. He says the Radiation Oncologist will make all the decisions about type of SRT and imaging prior to radiation. But, his experience, (the MO and RO work for the same national practice 21st Century Oncology), is that no high tech imaging will be done if we start SRT at PSA <0.05 because none of it can detect metastasizes at such a low level. The MO did also say that SRT technology is progressing at a very rapid pace and the longer I can wait the better the results and fewer the side effects. Asked him about ADT or any other hormone or chemical treatment prior to or with the SRT and he was quite definite - NO- NONE! My G7 (3+4) and small focal EPE & SM are not indicative of the need for anything in addition to SRT. The radiation therapy will almost certainly be a near cure or provide me enough time to die from anything other than PCa. Bottom Line for me is that SRT is inevitable but I want to delay it as long as possible.

months post RALP because a 71 year old needs 9 months

Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: I can identify with your anguish and understand the overwhelming sense of "what happened and what do I do now?" After years of watching my PSA move around and choosing each time to "wait for more information" - this spring my PSA jumped to 9.2 and then 10.2 the next month. I've had more tests and a 3T mpMRI to confirm the presence of a quite small "equivocal" tumor in my prostate. My biopsy will be on Friday August 3. When I started posting here in late May, in much the same mental state you seem to be, I found the forum to be very informative and helped me gain some degree of relaxation and peace of mind. You will hear from a lot of very knowledgeable men who have a lot of important experience. My urologist, 26-years in practice with a state of the art diagnostic and treatment facility, urged me to remember that nothing moves rapidly in the world of prostate cancer. He cautioned me to take my time and learn as much as I could. He is also adamant, very outspoken, that many, a high percentage, of men with prostate cancer are over treated. He has been treating prostate cancers for several decades and he is convinced that his fellow practitioners are far to eager to cut and irradiate. He is a both a board certified surgeon (one fellowship) and a board certified urologist (different fellowship), but he is apparently opposed to surgery except in dire circumstances. He wants to do my biopsy 'cause my 4KScore, which he recommended, says I have a 34% chance of a significant cancer despite his knowing the tumor is very small. Then, he wants to get genetic tests on the tumor samples, IF (Big IF!), the pathologist sees any undifferentiated cells. Then (IF a Gleason 7 or more), he wants to take OUR time to discuss the treatment options. He stressed we have plenty of time to make an informed decision that is specific to my health, life expectancy, and my wife's wishes. At all three appointments I've had since early June he has reassured me that "I've never lost a patient to prostate cancer by waiting, being thoughtful, and being conservative while trying to minimize the impact of treatment" SO - I would not rush off to that surgeon just yet

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed and overwhelmed

Posts.Content: Walsh book - 4th edition page 326-327 "What is the advantage of the ultrasensitive test? If your pathology report suggests that not all the cancer has been removed....then this information can be helpful." JH Research done by Dr. Lori Sokoll, professor of pathology and associate director of clinical chemistry at JH studied 750 men with PSA<0.1 3-months post surgery. Those with µPSA <0.03 had only 14% chance of an elevated PSA in 10-years. Those with µPSA>0.03 had 78% chance of an elevated PSA within a decade. The research DID NOT quantify the percentage of those 750 men who actually experienced BCR (PSA >0.2 for three consecutive tests) nor did it specify how many men needed additional therapy after their surgery. So men with SM+, SVI+, LNI+ and a µPSA >0.03 at 3-months need to have more frequent µPSA screening than those with a lower µPSA. I interpret the above as saying the µPSA <0.03 provides some reasonable peace of mind for at least a decade. And, if the score is higher it tells me that I will probably have to deal with BCR at some distant point. I find very different information in the Sokoll paper published in J of Urology Feb 2016! The Feb 2016 paper does not seem to say that a µPSA<0.03 is the assurance of a biochemical recurrence free survival that the Walsh book states. 754 men with standard PSA<0.1 17% (131) experienced BCR at a median time of 4-years. 69% of men with BCR had a µPSA <0.01 83% (623) had no BCR at a median time of 11-years. 93% of the BCR free men had a µPSA < 0.01 BCR free rates 11 years after surgery were 86% for prostate specific antigen less than 0.01 ng/ml and 48.9% for prostate specific antigen 0.01 ng/ml or greater. Kaplan-Meier estimates for mean BCR-free survival were 15.2 years for µPSA<0.01 ng/ml and 10.0 years for µPSA>0.01 ng/ml or greater. Conclusions (paraphrased from article) µPSA<0.01 ng/ml stratified biochemical recurrence-free survival and was a significant independent predictor of biochemical recurrence, as were pathological features. PSA concentrations in men without pathological evidence of prostate cancer suggest that a higher prostate specific antigen concentration (0.03 ng/ml) in the ultrasensitive range may be needed to define the detection threshold. The Kang et. al paper in J of Urology May 2015 offers a different perspective on µPSA and it's usefulness for determining future treatment. 247 hi risk patients (EPE+ or SM+ after surgery) and studied 1991 -2013. Sensitivity analysis identified uPSA ≥0.03 as the optimal threshold identifying recurrence. First post-op uPSA ≥0.03, Gleason grade, T-stage, iPSA (initial PSA), and margin status predicted BCR (PSA>0.2 for successive tests). First post-op uPSA ≥0.03 conferred the highest risk (Hazard Ratio =8.5 which means BCR is 8.5 times more likely to occur with a PSA>0.03) and discerned cBCR with greater sensitivity than undetectable first conventional PSA (70% vs. 46%). Any post-op PSA ≥0.03 captured all failures missed by first post-op value (100% sensitivity) with accuracy (96% specificity which means 96% of men with PSA<0.03 do not suffer BCR). Defining failure at uPSA ≥0.03 yielded a median lead-time advantage of 18 months (mean 24 months) over the conventional PSA ≥0.2 definition.

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Here is an interesting factoid that might help with decision making: In patients with localized prostate cancer, the 5-year survival approximates 100%; however, in patients in whom distant metastases have occurred, the 5-year survival drops to 31%. Like most other solid malignancies, prostate cancer can metastasize to distant organs such as the liver, lungs and brain, but it has an unusually high propensity for metastasizing to the bone. In one autopsy study, approximately 80% of the men who had died from prostate cancer possessed bone metastases. Most current treatments for individuals with bone metastases have only palliative effects, with little effect on long-term survival International Journal of Cancer June 2012

Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: I can identify with your anguish and understand the overwhelming sense of "what happened and what do I do now?" After years of watching my PSA move around and choosing each time to "wait for more information" - this spring my PSA jumped to 9.2 and then 10.2 the next month. I've had more tests and a 3T mpMRI to confirm the presence of a quite small "equivocal" tumor in my prostate. My biopsy will be on Friday August 3. When I started posting here in late May, in much the same mental state you seem to be, I found the forum to be very informative and helped me gain some degree of relaxation and peace of mind. You will hear from a lot of very knowledgeable men who have a lot of important experience. My urologist, 26-years in practice with a state of the art diagnostic and treatment facility, urged me to remember that nothing moves rapidly in the world of prostate cancer. He cautioned me to take my time and learn as much as I could. He is also adamant, very outspoken, that many, a high percentage, of men with prostate cancer are over treated. He has been treating prostate cancers for several decades and he is convinced that his fellow practitioners are far to eager to cut and irradiate. He is a both a board certified surgeon (one fellowship) and a board certified urologist (different fellowship), but he is apparently opposed to surgery except in dire circumstances. He wants to do my biopsy 'cause my 4KScore, which he recommended, says I have a 34% chance of a significant cancer despite his knowing the tumor is very small. Then, he wants to get genetic tests on the tumor samples, IF (Big IF!), the pathologist sees any undifferentiated cells. Then (IF a Gleason 7 or more), he wants to take OUR time to discuss the treatment options. He stressed we have plenty of time to make an informed decision that is specific to my health, life expectancy, and my wife's wishes. At all three appointments I've had since early June he has reassured me that "I've never lost a patient to prostate cancer by waiting, being thoughtful, and being conservative while trying to minimize the impact of treatment" SO - I would not rush off to that surgeon just yet

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed and overwhelmed

Posts.Content: There are many statistics about PCa progression after biochemical recurrence (BCR). But, let's just use the simple ones found in the Johns Hopkins research paper about the Natural History of BCR after prostatectomy and with no additional hormonal therapy. At 5.3 years post surgery 15% of men had BCR (PSA > 0.2ng/ml) The median (half the times were less and half were more) time to BCR was 2.3 years Eventually 1/3 of those men developed metastatic disease (About 1 in 20 of the original study group of prostatectomy patients) The Median time to metastatic disease symptoms was 8-years About half (actually 44%) of men with metastatic disease died from the disease (About 1 in 40 of the original study group of prostatectomy patients) The Median time to metastatic disease death was 5-years AFTER development of symptoms (About 13-years after initial PSA > 0.2) As others have mentioned - your life expectancy and Quality of Life is critical in the SRT / ADT / HT Yes or No? decision making process. All the the life expectancy calculators I've used give me at least another 20-years and I expect them to be good years. My father and I went for a 3-mile hike in the Everglades on his 89th birthday and he felt great doing it. SO - for me it seems I should do everything possible to fight the renewed growth of PCa IF I experience BCR. The recent post describing two brother's current SRT and HT therapy with few side effects has been very encouraging for me. They make it sound like SRT & HT can be experienced with a minimal degree of suffering and long term effects. Yet another reason to plan on additional treatment if BCR does occur. Several surviving partners of men who died from Metatstatic Prostatic Cancer disease have posted threads here describing the last two years of their partners journey to death. It sounds like a horrible way to die and is also very hard on the surviving family. I've promised my wife, 8-years younger than me and from a family where all the women live to be older than 95, I will outlive her. Thus I have a strong incentive to submit to whatever additional treatment I need to delay or deny PCa return. I've written several more detailed threads about BCR and prognosis, which summarize much of the research I've found. Here is one link: https://www.cancerforums.net/threads...t-RP-prognosis

AgeInfo.Phrase: the disease  About 1 in 40 of the original study group

Posts.Title: Psa fluctuations after prostate removal

Posts.Content: I can certainly understand and identify with your concern. I've had many, dozens ?, of MRIs over the years due to bad back, knees, shoulder, neck. During the first ?? (many over the years) I never had a claustrophobia problem. I'd spent years crawling around very tight pipes, tunnels, and engine rooms with no thought of a problem. Then suddenly, about 2003, I became extremely claustrophobic during an MRI for my back. (I was 30-minutes into the MRI, which was an old style narrow tube with a closed end where your head ended up for a back image. I was listening to classical music and was half asleep when the technician says "Boy am I glad you are not claustrophobic - it is a real nuisance when people freak out in there." I quickly lost it! My heart accelerated, my breathing almost stopped and I started sweating like crazy. As I recall I made it thru that one but the next several MRIs were downright frightening.) Since that time MRIs, CT scans, and radionuclide cardiac stress tests (the sensor presses on your chest) have been a real issue for me and cause me a lot of stress leading up to the event. My 3T mpMRI (June this year) for the prostate was in a newer Siemens machine and it was a whole lot LESS problematic (scary!) than the older enclosed machines. The tunnel is wide open at both ends and is at least 50% wider than the older style. They put me in feet first so that my shoulders and head were outside the tube. Additionally, and most important for my mental state, I had to keep my arms above my head while lying there. My claustrophia is worst when I feel like my arms and hands are pinned in such a fashion I cannot help myself ESCAPE. The machine used for my 3T mpMRI did not cause that irrational sensation. AND, my GP has given me an Rx for Adivan 0.5mg (Lorazepam), which is a very mild anti-anxiety medication. I take one 90-minutes before they put me in the tube and I feel almost NO concerns and can even fall asleep if the technician does not talk to me. I also feel no effect from the Adivan, it does not seem to make my thinking slow or cloudy and does not seem to impair my judgement, or at least my wife says she cannot tell when I take it.

Then suddenly, about 2003, I became extremely claustrophobic during an MRI for my back. (I was 30-minutes into the MRI, which was an old style narrow tube with a closed end where your head ended up for a back image. I was listening to classical music and was half asleep when the technician says "Boy am I glad you are not claustrophobic - it is a real nuisance when people freak out in there." I quickly lost it! My heart accelerated, my breathing almost stopped and I started sweating like crazy. As I recall I made it thru that one but the next several MRIs were downright frightening.) Since that time MRIs, CT scans, and radionuclide cardiac stress tests (the sensor presses on your chest) have been a real issue for me and cause me a lot of stress leading up to the event. My 3T mpMRI (June this year) for the prostate was in a newer Siemens machine and it was a whole lot LESS problematic (scary!) than the older enclosed machines. The tunnel is wide open at both ends and is at least 50% wider than the older style. They put me in feet first so that my shoulders and head were outside the tube. Additionally, and most important for my mental state, I had to keep my arms above my head while lying there. My claustrophia is worst when I feel like my arms and hands are pinned in such a fashion I cannot help myself ESCAPE. The machine used for my 3T mpMRI did not cause that irrational sensation. AND, my GP has given me an Rx for Adivan 0.5mg (Lorazepam), which is a very mild anti-anxiety medication. I take one 90-minutes before they put me in the tube and I feel almost NO concerns and can even fall asleep if the technician does not talk to me. I also feel no effect from the Adivan, it does not seem to make my thinking slow or cloudy and does not seem to impair my judgement, or at least my wife says she cannot tell when I take it.

Posts.Title: How bad is the MRI?

Posts.Content: The folks on this forum are knowledgeable, experienced, and well versed in all aspects of our journeys thru the twisted Prostate Cancer path. We encourage you to ask every question that comes to mind. No question is too minor and I suspect you will be overwhelmed, at least for a while, with the amount of information you will be provided. When I started down the PCa path last May and came to realize I really did have Cancer and really did need to treat it - I was overly confident in my scientific and medical knowledge. It didn't take long for me to understand that there are a LOT of very well educated, both formal and practical, men here who have been there and done that and now want to share that knowledge and experience. Despite what I thought I knew, these folks quickly taught me what I needed to know. I also quickly discovered that many of these folks can really explain PCa puzzles in crystal clear and easy to understand words. Ask for whatever help you need to "come to terms" with this new experience. It is OK to be uncertain, frustrated, confused, and even angry. I vented my frustration several times and was pleased at how much better I felt and how supportive the forum members were.

The results suggest the benefits of surgery in men with advanced prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Recent Diagnosis ... New Member

Posts.Content: Found Details on Reuters - WSJ is mis-representing the research with that headline! (Reuters Health) - - In men with localized prostate cancer discovered because they had symptoms or noticed during a work-up for another medical problem, radical prostate surgery leads to an average of three extra years of life compared to a “watchful waiting” approach, researchers say. The benefit of surgery was most pronounced in men who were under age 65 when their tumor was diagnosed, a new, long-term Scandinavian study found. The results, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, don’t apply to prostate cancer detected during screening, such as with blood tests to measure prostate specific antigen (PSA). How can such a reputable news organization so distort scientific data?

AgeInfo.Phrase: men who were under age 65 when their tumor was diagnosed

Posts.Title: Wall Street Journal

Posts.Content: The discussion about BCR, Ultrasensitive PSA, ADT, SRT... and what us post RP guys need to know when deciding about additional treatment due to non-zero PSA is the big thing in my life now. I suspect it will be for the rest of this year. My first post RP PSA is October 9 and my surgeon seemed to indicate I should plan on some radiation. The several recent discussions here, thanks Allmo, give me hope that my single focal EPE and 2mm SM on only one of 16-slides might let me slide on past that glow in the dark device, at least for a few more years. I want to read the original medical publications and data. I have a strong biology and even stronger training in advanced statistics. I want to understand a lot of the technical and numeric stuff that is not in the abstracts. HOW do I access things like Journal of Urology without out paying $39.95 per PDF download? There are many professional publications I want to read but cannot afford, given my current understand of access policy and cost. Thanks for any advice.

Posts.Content: My 6-week test was on October 9 with a good result (0.021) BUT my highly experienced surgeon (1,600 RALPs) told me the 3-month test is the one that is really important for prognostic value. But, he was so pleased with my 0.021 he wants to wait until mid-January 2019 for the next test. That means he thinks the FIVE Month PSA test is critical to him. Surgeon told me the PSA level is often still dropping at 6-weeks and the 6-week test is of little prognostic value but a low number is of great psychological value.

Posts.Title: Recent Diagnosis ... New Member

Posts.Content: "Had a go around with my urologist's office trying to get my PSA tested via ultra-sensitive. Asked for ultra-sensitive (<0.02, but didn't get it). Apparently an office nurse is not knowledgeable in the distinctions. He said he'd huddle with them and make it clear what a <0.1 test is and what ultra-sensitive is." I am currently engaged in the same struggle - my surgeon ordered an µPSA in early October and it came back 0.021. I now want to return to my medical urology oncologist for the followup and have an appointment January 9. The surgeon's office is 61-miles from home the medical guy is 2-miles. The urologist's office sent me an e-mail with a PDF attached, which is the lab order for a PSA test. Took the printed pdf to the lab to verify it is a µPSA test (same lab as did the October µPSA test). The lab tech and the lab manager both looked at the doctor's order and said they did not know, and could not know, if it is an ultra-sensitive test. They said they just submit the blood sample to Labcorp and Labcorp's technician will decide what kind of test to run. I've sent an message, via the patient portal, to my medical urologist asking if the order is for a µPSA test but have received no reply in two business days.

Posts.Content: Because BCR is fairly common For me T1c 6 of 12 cores + [email protected](3+3) [email protected] (3+4) age 71 10.4 PSA at time of biopsy 100%cores in Left + 100% in Right - Sloan Kettering Nomograph https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/prostate/pre_op gives probabilities prior to Radical Prostatectomy PROBABILITY OF CANCER-SPECIFIC SURVIVAL AFTER RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY 99% at 10 and 15-years (ONLY 1% chance my PCa will kill me before age 86) PROGRESSION-FREE PROBABILITY AFTER RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY 77% at 10-years and 66% at 15-years (1 in 3 chance I will have BCR by age 86) I think the following explains my high probability of BCR by age 86 (stats are from MSK) ORGAN-CONFINED DISEASE 35% (there is a 2 in 3 chance my PCa has spread beyond the prostate capsule) SO - in my particular case MSK thinks I have a 99% chance of NOT DYING due to PCA before age 86 but a 33% chance of BCR by age 86 My urologist (26-years board certified) is not so optimistic! He told me I have a 50% chance of BCR within 10-years but a 99% CSSR at age 85.

Posts.Title: Observation, Statistics, Coincidences?

Posts.Content: The Good News about positive surgical margins is in this November 2017 Discovery (Johns Hopkins) article: https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brad...to-perspective Quoting Jeffery Epstein from the article: " “it is not uncommon for the margins to be positive – to have tumor at the cut edge, which potentially could indicate that some cancer has been left behind.” However, he adds, “only about half of prostate cancers with positive margins recur after surgery.” This also means that half of men who have positive margins never have a recurrence of cancer." "Because Epstein has looked at tens of thousands of prostate specimens in his distinguished career, he knows that the positive surgical margin itself is not as important as some other factors." " In a current study of 4,082 consecutive patients undergoing radical prostatectomy between 2010 and 2014 at Johns Hopkins, Epstein and colleagues showed that men who had a lower Gleason score at the margin were less likely to have a return of PSA after surgery, and “we conclude that the Gleason score of the cancer at the positive margin site should routinely be documented. This might spare men who have lower-grade cancer at the margin from post-operative radiation therapy.” I sure hope they are correct!

Posts.Title: Update on PC detection from my Urologist

Posts.Content: The Good News about positive surgical margins is in this November 2017 Discovery (Johns Hopkins) article: https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brad...to-perspective Quoting Jeffery Epstein from the article: " “it is not uncommon for the margins to be positive – to have tumor at the cut edge, which potentially could indicate that some cancer has been left behind.” However, he adds, “only about half of prostate cancers with positive margins recur after surgery.” This also means that half of men who have positive margins never have a recurrence of cancer." "Because Epstein has looked at tens of thousands of prostate specimens in his distinguished career, he knows that the positive surgical margin itself is not as important as some other factors." " In a current study of 4,082 consecutive patients undergoing radical prostatectomy between 2010 and 2014 at Johns Hopkins, Epstein and colleagues showed that men who had a lower Gleason score at the margin were less likely to have a return of PSA after surgery, and “we conclude that the Gleason score of the cancer at the positive margin site should routinely be documented. This might spare men who have lower-grade cancer at the margin from post-operative radiation therapy.” I sure hope they are correct!

So - it is only natural for someone who has gone the RP/RALP route to quickly ask "What led you down the decision path to the treatment you chose" and then compare that reasoning to the reasoning that let me, and many others to RP.

Posts.Title: Started Treatment Today ADT + EBRT

Posts.Content: PSA 44-days after RALP = 0.021 My RALP surgeon, whose card reads "Specializing in Urology Oncology and Robotic Surgery", has done over 1,600 RALPs and has been practicing for over 25-years. Today I met with him to review the 0.021 PSA results. He looks at the lab paper, looks at the RALP pathology report and says: "Remember we were concerned about the pathology and surgical margins? This .021 is good for six-weeks post surgery but is marginal for denying the need for radiation. Let's wait three months and see what the PSA result is at that time." My wife then asked "how much radiation?" and he says "seven weeks - but let's wait three months to decide." And... here I thought a 0.021 was a solid indicator of no immediate need for SRT. My wife thinks the surgeon is skeptical that the PSA measure will stay that low. I know that in the first appointment I had with him, 6-days after the surgery, he looked at the pathology report and said "it looks like you have radiation in your future this winter." I guess he really does not think he got all the PCa tissue and expects to see the PSA start to climb during the next couple months. Disappointing but I guess not unexpected. I want to be an optimist and he wants to guarantee my future.

Posts.Title: Started Treatment Today ADT + EBRT

Posts.Content: July 18 review of 3T mpMRI and 4KScore Urologist says MRI provides no useful diagnostic information but provides clear target and guidance of biopsy. 4KScore says that 34% of men who were biopsied with my age, DRE, PSA, Free PSA, inTact PSA, and hK2 values were found to have PCa with a Gleason score of 7 or greater I guess the good news is that 2 out of 3 men like me DID NOT have an aggressive PCa! They will try to schedule the TRUS 12-Core biopsy for next week and the urologist assures me he will get at least two samples from the 0.30 cc tumor/lesion identified on the MRI. Dr. Blitz stressed that even an "aggressive" cancer at this point has a relatively slow progression, particularly with such a small lesion, and there is plenty of time to deal with it.

Posts.Title: 6-weeks Post RALP PSA = 0.021 & Surgeon says it is marginal for SRT

Posts.Content: Adencocarcinoma in 6 of 13 specimens Highest Gleason Score 7 ( 3 + 4 ) Highest PTI = 100% Five (5) Samples in Right side were all Benign prostatic tissue Gleason 6 (3 + 3) 70% of one sample Left Lateral Base but no % reported for 2nd sample from LLB 50% of one sample Left Lateral Mid 20% of one sample Left Base Gleason 7 ( 3 + 4) 100% of sample Left Lateral Apex 20% of sample Left Mid 60% of sample Left Apex HGPIN Right Lateral Apex What do I make of the 7 ( 3 + 4 )?? It seems to me that the treatment strategies for 3+4 is rapidly evolving. My inclination is to ask for some genetic testing to see if AS is appropriate. But, I have no concerns about ripping that sucker out and being done once and for all and damn the side effects. As long as I can get back on my bicycle before Christmas and can sail my dinghy before Spring. I have an appointment with my urologist at 1 PM EDT Friday August 10 to discuss the next steps. I would appreciate any suggestions for questions I might ask him and for pointers to articles and forum threads about strategy for dealing with 3+4.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I recommend treatment of 3+4. It's also a high volume and density of cancer. The density on one side is very high. I wonder how unusal that is, and is no cancer on the other side suspect? I see the volume on the one side as an adverse condition, imo. Curious to hear what the doctor says. 18cc prostate 0.3cc tumor identified by MRI average involvement in all 12-cores is 27% but is 53% in the cores showing positive Staging from American Cancer Society staging page: The tumor can be felt by digital rectal exam or seen with imaging such as transrectal ultrasound and is in one half or less of only one side (left or right) of the prostate [cT2b] The tumor can be felt by digital rectal exam(NO in my case) or seen with imaging (equivocal MRI in my case) such as transrectal ultrasound. It is in more than half of one side of the prostate [cT2b] or it is in both sides of the prostate[cT2c] Mine is 100% of one side and none on the other so I guess my lottery number is cT2b WHOOPS! ^(&()&)( I did not notice that the staging definitions above only apply to Gleason 6. I fit all the criteria for cT2b BUT have a Gleason 7 (3+4) so what is my staging/grade with a PSA of 10.3? AJCC Stage IIB? Grade Group 2? The cancer has not yet spread outside the prostate. It might (or might not) be felt by digital rectal exam or seen with imaging such as transrectal ultrasound [T1 or T2]. How does one express that? IIBT2

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: Had my biopsy done August 3 at a local surgery center under the gentle care of Propofol. I checked in at the surgery center at 1 PM and was on my way home by 4:30 PM, which included a 30-minute extra wait because the doctor was delayed at another hospital. My wife had to drive me home and the recovery nurse walked us to the car to verify that my wife was actually driving the car as we left. My urologist has been in practice 26-years and prefers to do the biopsy while the patient is under "Conscious sedation ", which is accomplished with Propofol. I remember talking to the doctor and nurse/anesthesiologist about college basketball, she squeezed my hand and said, "you'll relax now", and then I was in the recovery room with my wife holding my hand. Propofol is not an anesthetic but inhibits the formation of memory so I have no remembrance of the biopsy. My urologist will do the biopsy in his office with lidocaine but his many years of experience tells him Propofol results in a relaxed, compliant patient and he has a better working field. I've had two colonoscopies, an endoscopy, and two cardiac conversions done using Propofol with no adverse side effects. I highly recommend it.

Posts.Title: Biopsy with or without anaesthesia?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I recommend treatment of 3+4. It's also a high volume and density of cancer. The density on one side is very high. I wonder how unusal that is, and is no cancer on the other side suspect? I see the volume on the one side as an adverse condition, imo. Curious to hear what the doctor says. 18cc prostate 0.3cc tumor identified by MRI average involvement in all 12-cores is 27% but is 53% in the cores showing positive Staging from American Cancer Society staging page: The tumor can be felt by digital rectal exam or seen with imaging such as transrectal ultrasound and is in one half or less of only one side (left or right) of the prostate [cT2b] The tumor can be felt by digital rectal exam(NO in my case) or seen with imaging (equivocal MRI in my case) such as transrectal ultrasound. It is in more than half of one side of the prostate [cT2b] or it is in both sides of the prostate[cT2c] Mine is 100% of one side and none on the other so I guess my lottery number is cT2b WHOOPS! ^(&()&)( I did not notice that the staging definitions above only apply to Gleason 6. I fit all the criteria for cT2b BUT have a Gleason 7 (3+4) so what is my staging/grade with a PSA of 10.3? AJCC Stage IIB? Grade Group 2? The cancer has not yet spread outside the prostate. It might (or might not) be felt by digital rectal exam or seen with imaging such as transrectal ultrasound [T1 or T2]. How does one express that? IIBT2

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: I met with my Medical Oncologist/Urologist January 9, 2019. This is the first time we have talked since he sent me to the RALP surgeon in mid-August 2018. My MO is 25-year board certified urologist. He retired from doing open RPs when RALP procedures became common and efficient. He still does a lot of urological surgery but wants to focus on the medical oncology aspects of his practice. He said my surgical pathology report is hard to interpret from a prognostic perspective. He said the EPE+ and SM+ are negative indicators and probably predict future biochemical recurrence (BCR). Then he continued saying my SM and EPE were small (< 2mm), single focal, and G6 so he would discount their negative value in the prediction of future BCR. There is no current indicator that a future course of radiation is needed or even predicted for me. There is no way to predict, given my pathology, what the course of my PCa will be. It is truly wait and see. I asked him about Hypofractionation IF radiation became necessary. He said than he and his radiological oncologist were using hypofractionation on a more frequent basis and were becoming much more comfortable with it for Salvage Radiation Therapy. No discussion of dosage but he indicated they usually did five treatments. But, at this point radiation is at least six-months in the future due to my low PSA ( 0.018 ). The monitoring plan is every three months for a couple years. The BIG news to me is that he DOES NOT want to use Ultrasensitive PSA tests. He says a two digit test is all he needs and the three digit test just provides noise that confuses the patient. He again reminded me of the slow growth of PCa, even post-RALP. I suggested the trendline provided by µPSA is useful for catching an increasing PSA score earlier than could with a two-digit test and he called BS. He feels the two-digit test is "exquisitly sensitive" and provides plenty of advanced information about the post-RALP patient's PSA dynamics. He stressed the dynamics are the key - not the absolute level. He then strongly, adamantly, described the 0.2 ng/ml for two consecutive PSA tests three months apart as his gold standard for a BCR diagnosis. I then asked about genetic testing of the surgical specimens. His answer was "I usually do that genetic testing when trying to convince the patient they need to take a course of action or to avoid a treatment. In your case, today, the PSA test shows no reason to do anything except wait three-months. In the future, with a rising PSA value we might want the genetic information to determine how aggressive we want to be with radiation and hormone. At this time genetics provides no useful information, BUT if you want I will order it." I chose to wait another three months. Then he told me I had been doing my Kegels all wrong. He wants me to do 100 long duration Kegels per day, every day, forever. Every time I stand up, sit down, reach, do anything that stresses my bladder or abdomen I am to do a Kegel and HOLD IT to exhaustion. I said that might be a long time - He laughed and said "I bet it is less than 10-seconds if you are really squeezing the correct muscles." He said short dynamic Kegels are of little value and repetitions of longer Kegels are not much better. He stressed I need to do them every time I put stress on the abdomen and hold till tired.

DoctorRecommended.Sample: He wants to concentrate on the non-oncology side of surgery and the diagnostic side of prostate cancer. He recommended a robotic surgeon whose practice involves many robotic prostatectomies each week....My MO referred me to a highly experienced RALP surgeon (1,600 RALPs and over 12-years experience doing them) whom the MO worked with on a daily basis. The RALP surgeon reviewed all my tests and told me there was No Hurry to make a decision and suggested I also talk with a Radiation Oncologist to learn more about RT as a primary treatment....The RALP surgeon reviewed all my tests and told me there was No Hurry to make a decision and suggested I also talk with a Radiation Oncologist to learn more about RT as a primary treatment. The RALP surgeon said he would be comfortable waiting up to 4-months to do the surgery....He is a both a board certified surgeon (one fellowship) and a board certified urologist (different fellowship), but he is apparently opposed to surgery except in dire circumstances. He wants to do my biopsy 'cause my 4KScore, which he recommended, says I have a 34% chance of a significant cancer despite his knowing the tumor is very small....He recommended a robotic surgeon whose practice involves many robotic prostatectomies each week. His total robotic prostatatecomy count is in the several thousand range....
